session_title: Welcome to IRE25 + first-timers networking
description: Welcome to the conference! Hear from IRE staff about tips and tactics to navigate our conference like a pro. Then, stick around for a speed round of networking with fellow attendees and IRE staff and board.  This session is sponsored by Sinclair, Inc. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

session_title: Broadcast track: 30 story ideas that work in any market
description: Where to search for stories in your market - tried and true, in-depth and quick turn, with consumer ideas too.

speakers.bio: Dan Krauth is an award-winning investigative journalist with WABC-TV. His investigations have led to changes in local and state laws ranging from how squatters are defined under state law in New York to how plastic surgeons are disciplined in Florida. He started as a producer in Rockford and has worked at stations in Fort Wayne, Grand Rapids, West Palm Beach and Miami before moving to New York City.

Cierra Putman is an investigative reporter with WTHR’s 13 Investigates, driven by curiosity, tenacity and a passion for digging deeper. A University of Missouri graduate, she began her career in Texas and Upstate New York, later reporting in Providence and Orlando. She joined WTHR in 2021 after honing her investigative skills as a general assignment reporter. Her work has earned a Gracie Award, regional SPJ first place honors and regional Emmy nominations and awards.

Mallory Sofastaii is an award-winning investigative reporter at WMAR-2 News in Baltimore, Maryland, where she’s worked since 2016. She created “Matter for Mallory,” a consumer segment that led to federal indictments in a nationwide moving scam. Her reporting on EBT theft helped prompt federal reimbursement legislation. Mallory’s work focuses on uncovering fraud, resolving consumer complaints, and driving change through impactful, solutions-based journalism.

Katie Wilcox is the I-Team Executive Producer at 12News in Phoenix, where she leads her team to produce data-driven investigations that expose waste, fraud and abuse. Katie also worked as a data journalist in Denver at 9NEWS and Rocky Mountain PBS. Her work has prompted legislation and policy changes in Colorado and Arizona. Katie grew up in southwest Iowa and graduated from the University of Iowa with her bachelor’s degrees in economics and journalism.

session_title: Climate on the record: Crafting investigations with legal documents
description: Covering the story of the climate crisis is so much more than chasing heat waves, oil spills, and sea level rise. Often, the most crucial stories about global warming and its effects on communities are embedded in dockets, spreadsheets, permits, and financial records. This panel will explore how to harness records, legal documents, and data to tell off-the-beaten-path climate stories.
track: Climate, Beat reporting, Criminal legal system, Local news, Public records, Story ideas, Research

speakers.bio: Audrey Mei Yi Brown (they/them) is the environmental health equity reporter at the San Francisco Public Press. They are also a Report for America corps member and a USC Annenberg Center for Health Journalism data fellow. Previously, they were a contributing editor at KneeDeep Times and worked at the San Francisco Chronicle. Audrey is a graduate of Columbia Journalism School. They grew up in San Francisco and still call the city home.

Nina B. Elkadi is an investigative reporter at Sentient. Her work explores corporate influence within the agricultural industry, the environmental impacts of factory farming, and how negligence impacts consumers and workers. Her work also appears in National Geographic, Inside Climate News, Civil Eats, High Country News, Ambrook Research, JSTOR Daily, Barn Raiser, and more. She splits her time between Washington D.C. and her hometown of Iowa City.

Jennifer Hijazi is a reporter covering air pollution and climate change for Bloomberg Law’s environment desk. She focuses on environmental justice, regulations, and litigation. Previously, she built the climate law and litigation beat at E&E News and has bylines at PBS NewsHour, Vox, Science Magazine, Courthouse News, and Scientific American. She is the DC chapter president of the Arab and Middle Eastern Journalists Association and The Uproot Project.

Méndez González is an award-winning environmental investigative reporter for Puerto Rico’s Center for Investigative Journalism. He is focused on stories about Puerto Rico, where he was born and raised. He has worked with teams such as the Miami Herald’s I-Team and El Nuevo Día’s Investigative Unit. He earned a Master’s in Information Design and Data Visualization from Northeastern University and has been a fellow with Climate Tracker and The Uproot Project.

session_title: Everything you wanted to know about starting a newsletter

speakers.bio: Daniel Lathrop is an independent investigative data journalist and newsroom technologist for digital and broadcast outlets. You have probably seen his work at NerdWallet, Scripps News, or The New York Times.

session_title: Excel 1: Getting started with spreadsheets
description:
In this introduction to spreadsheets, you'll begin analyzing data with Excel, a simple but powerful tool. You'll learn how to enter data, navigate spreadsheets and conduct simple calculations like sum, average and median. 

This session is good for: Data beginners. Laptops will be provided.

speakers.bio: Stephen Stock is chief investigative reporter at WVUE Fox8 New Orleans and contributing correspondent for Gray’s InvestigateTV. Specializing in public corruption, safety and transportation, Stock was a founding member of CBS News and Stations Innovation Lab and helped build investigative teams in San Francisco, Miami and Orlando. He teaches at IRE, newsrooms and universities around the US. He’s won a Peabody, du-Pont, national SPJ, three Murrows, six AP awards and 18 Emmys.

session_title: How nonprofit foundations are funding local investigative journalism
description: How does a newsroom with only eight news reporters have a two-person dedicated investigative team? Are nonprofit foundations, even those that don't typically fund journalism, the answer to dwindling revenue and corporate support for investigative reporting? Can this funding model succeed in communities without deep-pocketed donors and foundations? We will tackle these questions and more with a panel that includes journalists as well as representatives of foundations both large and small that are on the cutting edge of nonprofit funding of investigative journalism.

speakers.bio: Ventura County Community Foundation

Tony Biasotti is an investigative reporter with the Ventura County Star, a position funded by a grant from the Ventura County Community Foundation. He has been with The Star since 2022 and was also a reporter there from 2005 to 2010; in between, he spent a decade freelancing and a few years as executive editor of the Pacific Coast Business Times. He is a graduate of the University of California, Santa Barbara, and a product of its student newspaper.

Mauricio Palma has been with Silicon Valley Community Foundation since 2005. As director of community partnerships, he leads grant programs in arts and culture, faith and neighborhoods, local journalism and the Portraits of Community Action initiative. He also facilitates SVCF’s Community Advisory Council, a group of leaders advising the foundation’s president and CEO.

Tracie Powell is a leading voice in advancing racial equity in journalism and the founder of The Pivot Fund, which invests in independent hyperlocal community news organizations. A former Shorenstein Fellow, Powell served as the founding fund manager of the Racial Equity in Journalism Fund at Borealis Philanthropy. She is the immediate past board chair of LION Publishers and holds degrees from Georgetown University Law Center and the University of Georgia.

session_title: How to use Census data to power your stories — from quick turns to investigations
description:
Have you ever wondered how many people in your county make $100,000 or more per year? How about the number of people who were born in Ukraine, or the neighborhood with the largest number of Black homeowners? In this hands-on session, you will learn how to answer these types of questions by downloading and analyzing data from data.census.gov, the official web platform of the U.S. Census Bureau that houses its most popular surveys and programs. You’ll come away with a new skill you can use on a wide range of stories, from quick turnarounds to deep-dive investigations. Best of all: no coding required. 

This session is good for: all levels of experience. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

speakers.bio: Susie Neilson is an investigative reporter at the San Francisco Chronicle. Her work has prompted numerous changes to laws and regulations, including a California-wide ban on a debunked lie detector used to interrogate prisoners. An investigation she co-reported into fatal police chases, Fast & Fatal, led to sweeping policy reforms and was a finalist for the 2025 Pulitzer Prize in National Reporting, among other honors. She is a graduate of UC Berkeley and Northwestern.

session_title: Investigating the wild world of sports
description: From sports betting to labor disputes and corruption, the sports world is ripe for investigation. Come to this panel to hear from journalists who have covered a wide range of topics in the sector to learn how to turn your investigative lens to this industry.

speakers.bio: Kenny Jacoby is an investigative reporter for USA TODAY. His investigations have centered on issues in sports, higher education and law enforcement. He is fluent in public records requests, spreadsheets and web scraping in Python.

David Purdum has covered the intersection of sports and gambling for 17 years, the last 10 with ESPN. A former newspaper writer, editor and producer, David chronicled the push for expanded legalization of betting all the way to the Supreme Court. He continues to track the aftermath of that game-changing ruling, which has resulted in 40 states launching legal betting markets.

Elaine Teng is a senior editor in ESPN's investigative and enterprise unit, where she works on investigations, breaking news, longform features and cross-platform projects. She was previously a writer and editor at ESPN The Magazine, and the managing editor of The New Republic.

Yami Virgin, an Emmy and AP Award-winning Investigative Reporter and Anchor at KABB/WOAI in San Antonio, is recognized in Texas and Wisconsin. She hosts and produces the Edward R. Murrow Award-winning podcast, "Immigration Crisis: The Fight for the Southern Border." Known for endless sources at local, state, and national levels, Yami brings two decades covering immigration, crime, and border policy. She is finishing a Master's in Digital Audience Analytics.

session_title: Investigative reporting in rural America
description:
Rural communities across the country are shrinking, but what happens when a place nearly empties out? Over the past year, we’ve focused our reporting in Alexander County, Illinois, at the confluence of the Ohio and Mississippi rivers—a place The Wall Street Journal declared the fastest-shrinking in America after the 2020 Census. But it’s not alone. Much of rural America is at a crossroads, caught between economic struggles and political uncertainty, trying to figure out how to survive while pushing back against national narratives that often miss the full picture.

This session will challenge the idea that rural places are just sad, dying communities. We’ll talk about how to highlight voices of strength and resilience while also tackling the policies shaping these places in unique ways. Some issues, like food deserts and child care, hit both urban and rural areas, but the challenges are steeper when funding is limited and people and resources are more spread out.

We’ll also dig into underreported issues—farming, forestry, and the role of education from preschool to universities—that serve as lifelines for rural communities. And we’ll look at what’s at stake with policy shifts under a second Trump administration. Just as important, we’ll talk about how to cover all of this with the balance and nuance rural people deserve. That includes working with student reporters and regional universities to help fill news deserts, and how big media companies can partner with local reporters to move beyond clichés and get a real understanding of rural life on the inside.

speakers.bio: Ilana Newman is a reporter and multimedia producer for the Daily Yonder, a rural focused newsroom. She lives in rural Southwest Colorado and covers issues of land, energy, water and economics in the rural Mountain West.

Molly Parker is an assistant professor of journalism at SIU Carbondale and an investigative reporter with Capitol News Illinois and ProPublica’s Local Reporting Network. She is co-director of the Saluki Local Reporting Lab and covers how government systems fail rural families and communities. Parker is a co-winner of the Robert F. Kennedy and Katherine Schneider journalism awards.

session_title: Master class: Writing the investigative narrative (pre-registered attendees only)
description:
Learn how to make your investigative writing compelling and powerful. We cover everything from defining an investigative narrative to how to report, organize, write and self-edit your own! Topics include:
-Understanding the investigative narrative
-How to pitch
-Turning sources into characters
-Writing a scene
-Self-editing tips and techniques
-Organizing and writing a deeply reported investigative narrative.

Preregistration is required and seating is limited.

speakers.bio: Bethany Barnes is the deputy investigative editor at the Tampa Bay Times. Barnes previously worked at The Oregonian, where her coverage of Portland Public Schools prompted the Education Writers Association to name her the nation’s best education reporter. Before that, she was a reporter in Las Vegas. Barnes is one of four journalists who put together Local Matters, a free weekly newsletter that rounds up the nation's best local investigative reporting.

Rebecca Woolington is the deputy managing editor for investigations at the Tampa Bay Times. Since joining the Times in 2018, her work has chronicled the rise and fall of a troubled small-town mayor, discrepancies in the state’s counting of coronavirus deaths and dangerous working conditions inside a lead factory. The latter earned her and her reporting partners the 2022 Pulitzer Prize for investigative reporting, a George Polk Award and several other national honors.

session_title: One-on-one coaching for audio journalists (Thursday)
description: Audio journalists can sign up for a one-on-one coaching session at various times during the conference. Click here to sign up: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/10C084CA8AC29A4FBCE9-57105620-audio#/

session_title: One-on-one with Barry Nash & Co. (Thursday)
description:
Barry Nash and his team return to IRE to provide personalized coaching sessions. If you have questions about any aspect of your delivery — your appearance, how you use your voice, how you can perform most effectively in the field or in the studio — this is an opportunity you won’t want to miss. Barry has been working with talent at all levels of experience and ability for over 30 years.

Please note: Participants should bring recent footage on a flash drive, webpage/online link, or storage drive (Google or Dropbox).

Click here to sign up: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/10C084CA8AC29A4FBCE9-57105395-barry#/

session_title: Open mic: Legal discussion: Journalists and journalism under attack
description:
This is one of five “Open Mic” sessions where you can listen to AND participate in a lively discussion about important issues facing our industry and impacting our daily work. All are welcome to attend!
*These sessions will not be recorded.

session_title: Records for covering education, and overcoming FERPA denials
description: This session provides great records for investigating K-12 and higher education – some classics and some you might not have run across. Then, experts provide tips for wrangling them out of officials’ grubbies by overcoming common denials, particularly FERPA.

speakers.affiliation: University of Florida / Brechner Freedom of Information Project
speakers.bio: David Cuillier directs the Brechner FOI Project at the University of Florida College of Journalism and Communications. He was a data journalist before earning his doctorate from Washington State University in 2006. He co-authored The Art of Access: Strategies for Acquiring Public Records, is former president of the National Freedom of Information Coalition and Society of Professional Journalists, and a member of the National Archivist's FOIA Advisory Committee.

speakers.affiliation: University of Florida / Brechner Freedom of Information Project
speakers.bio: Sydney Sims is the Outreach Coordinator for the Brechner Freedom of Information Project at the University of Florida. She leads training, communications, and public education efforts to advance transparency. A former journalist, Sims reported for outlets including Capital B News, WABE, and the Columbus Ledger-Enquirer. Originally from Atlanta, she holds a degree in journalism from Auburn University and now resides in Gainesville, Florida.

Matt Topic runs the media and intellectual property practice at Loevy + Loevy. Matt and his team have litigated hundreds of state and federal open records cases.  Matt also represents several news publishers in copyright cases against OpenAI and Microsoft.

Patrick Wall is an editor and reporter at the Times-Picayune | Advocate newspapers in Louisiana, where he leads the education team. He previously reported for Chalkbeat, a nonprofit news organization focused on education. He began his career as a fourth-grade teacher, and his writing about schools has appeared in The Washington Post, The Atlantic, Mother Jones and USA Today, among other publications.

session_title: Reflecting on 50 years of investigations
description: Join us for a thought-provoking conversation that celebrates IRE and the evolution of investigative journalism over the past five decades. This session will explore key themes such as the dynamics of the reporter-editor relationship, the impact of collaborative projects across multiple newsrooms, and the growing role of university and international partnerships in investigative work. Panelists will share their insights on how these collaborations have enriched journalism and enhanced the quality of investigations. Attendees can expect a rich discussion filled with valuable lessons, historical perspectives, and visions for the future of investigative reporting.

speakers.bio: Brant Houston is Knight Chair of Investigative Reporting at the University of Illinois. He served as the executive director of IRE for a decade. Before IRE, he was an investigative reporter at daily newspapers. He has co-authored “The Investigative Reporter’s Handbook” and authored “Computer-Assisted Reporting: A Practical Guide” and "Changing Models for Journalism: Reinventing the Newsroom." He is board chair for the Global Investigative Journalism Network.

Jim is the managing editor of Oregon Journalism Project, a nonprofit newsroom focused on investigative journalism across the state. He is an IRE award winner, a former board president, and author of five award-winning nonfiction books, including "Vendetta: Bobby Kennedy vs. Jimmy Hoffa."

speakers.affiliation: Big Local News at Stanford University
speakers.bio: Cheryl Phillips teaches data and investigative journalism at Stanford and co-directs Big Local News, a data-sharing collaborative. A former journalist at The Seattle Times and other outlets, she has contributed to Pulitzer-winning and finalist work, including two for breaking news. Most recently, she worked on an overdose investigation with The Baltimore Banner and The New York Times that won a George Polk Award and a Pulitzer Prize. She is a former IRE board president.

Thompson is an award-winning investigative correspondent and senior editor for investigations for NPR. Before joining NPR in 2019, she spent 22 years covering law enforcement and political corruption for The Washington Post, and was part of teams that won the Pulitzer for National Reporting in 2002 and 2016. She was the reporting coach on the NPR podcast "No Compromise," which won the Pulitzer Prize for Audio Reporting in 2021.

session_title: The internet is forever: How to uncover hidden information
description: Individuals and organizations are increasingly scrubbing their digital footprints, but journalists can often still track down what has been removed. This session will teach attendees how to uncover deleted records, scrubbed public data, and hidden connections using investigative techniques and open-source intelligence. Panelists will discuss tools and tricks to recover removed content from government databases, court records, and business filings, how to track changes on websites and archive critical information before it disappears, and how to investigate digital footprints. The session will also cover best practices for journalists to protect their own privacy while conducting sensitive investigations.

speakers.bio: Anna Massoglia is an independent investigative analyst. She serves as director of investigations at the Sunlight Research Center and as an advisor to multiple newsrooms, academic institutions and nonprofits. Anna previously led OpenSecrets’ editorial and investigations team. She holds degrees in political science and psychology from North Carolina State University and a J.D. from the University of the District of Columbia School of Law.

Samantha Sunne is a freelance journalist based in New Orleans and the Interim Editor at MuckRock. She has received several national grants and awards for investigative reporting and teaches at conferences, universities, and newsrooms around the world. Her first book, co-authored with trainer Mike Reilley, “Data + Journalism: A Story-Driven Approach to Learning Data Reporting,” is used in journalism classrooms around the country.

session_title: Turning documents into data using AI
description:
Carefully used, artificial intelligence can be very helpful to journalists. One of the best use cases is extracting information from unstructured text - think documents, transcripts and reports - so that it can be more easily organized. In this hands-on session you’ll walk through some examples using both paid and free versions of large language models. 

This session is good for anyone; experience with coding is helpful but not required. Attendees will need to bring their own laptop (no tablets) for the training.

speakers.bio: Derek Willis teaches and does data journalism at the Philip Merrill College of Journalism at the University of Maryland. He's been coming to NICAR since the late 1990s.

session_title: Broadcast track: How to get investigative content / I-team on air more without diluting your brand

speakers.bio: Natalia Martinez is a multiple award-winning investigative journalist and Executive Producer for WAVE Originals. For 15 years her work has focused on corruption, law enforcement and violence. She produces documentary films and special content at WAVE News and Gray Media, pioneering a new approach to in-depth story-telling. Her latest released documentary, 23 Seconds: A Louisville Mass Shooting received praise for its approach to reporting on a mass shooter.

Julie is a national-award-winning investigative correspondent for CBS News California. Her investigations, Capitol accountability reports, and solutions-oriented journalism air on CBS stations across California. Her work has prompted recalls, government investigations, and new laws and has been honored with dozens of the industry’s top journalism awards.

session_title: Excel 2: Formulas & sorting
description:
Much of Excel's power comes in the form of formulas. In this class, you'll learn how to use them to analyze data with the eye of a journalist. Yes, math will be involved, but it's totally worth it! This class will show you how calculations like change, percent change, rates and ratios can beef up your reporting.

This session is good for: Anyone who is comfortable navigating Excel. Laptops will be provided.

speakers.bio: Ali Ingersoll works as the investigative content producer at NBC Philadelphia. She previously reported in Raleigh, Buffalo, and London, covering topics ranging from urban planning to criminal justice, education, and technology. Ali studied Broadcast Journalism at Penn State and also graduated from Cardiff University, earning her master's degree in Computational and Data Journalism. She enjoys spending time with her dog, Potter, as well as running, cycling, reading, and practicing yoga.

session_title: Filing a better FOIA request
description:
This workshop will show you how to increase your chances of receiving records that reveal significant new information to help advance your story.

Who and what can help identify the records you should ask for in the first place? And how can you make it more likely that you’ll receive a useful response? We will look at strategies for formulating and following up on public records requests — treating them as a distinct reporting task, often requiring interviews and other digging to help pinpoint what records could be most helpful to ask for, and relationship-building to successfully shake them loose. We will also examine how to make the most of records that you receive to help find more stories and potential sources – people can lead us to records, and records can lead us to people.

speakers.bio: Josh Eidelson is a senior report for Bloomberg News and Businessweek, covering the workplace. His work has been honored by groups including the Loeb Foundation, the Society for Advancing Business Editing and Writing (SABEW) and the Sidney Hillman Foundation. Send him tips!

Marta Jewson is an education reporter at The Lens, New Orleans' first investigative nonprofit newsroom. She's covered New Orleans schools for 15 years through the nation's largest education reform experiment. Jewson was a founding member of the outlet's Charter School Reporting Corps. The CSRC covered 40+ independent school boards and was instrumental in holding new charter schools accountable to sunshine laws during the rapid expansion of charter schools in the city.

Suzy is a national enterprise reporter for NBC News, based in Washington, D.C., focusing on federal agencies and their impact on everyday people. Her reporting has also appeared in Esquire, New York magazine, The New York Times, The Economist, Slate, and The Wall Street Journal Asia, among other publications. Previously, I was a staff reporter at The Washington Post, where I was a founding writer for Wonkblog and a national reporter for MSNBC.

session_title: Finding the story: Beyond crime stats
description:
In a true-crime-obsessed world, go beyond splashy crime statistics to understand how the justice system really works for those who are caught up in it. 

This hands-on class will show you how to identify datasets from other corners of the justice system — jails and prisons, probation and parole, pardons and commutations, different kinds of court hearings — and how to find the story within them. 

Basic knowledge of working with spreadsheets is helpful, but not required. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.
track: Criminal legal system, Story ideas, Beat reporting, Public records, Research

speakers.bio: Brittany Hailer joined The Marshall Project after serving as the director of the Pittsburgh Institute of Nonprofit Journalism, a news outlet she co-founded in 2021. She won the best investigative journalism award in the 2022 Nonprofit News Awards for reporting on jail deaths and helped build Pennsylvania’s first-ever jail death database as a reporting fellow for the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting. She reports on conditions of incarceration for adults and children.

Danielle Ohl is an investigative reporter for Spotlight PA, where she covers the justice system. She previously worked for the Capital Gazette in Annapolis, where she earned a Pulitzer Prize special citation alongside her newsroom for covering the mass shooting of her colleagues.

session_title: Finding the story: Trade data
description:
USA Trade, part of the U.S. Census, is an incredible tool for data journalists across most beats, especially those relating to global economics, trade, tech, and foreign policy. Whether it’s a story on manufacturing or supply chains, or tariffs and their impact on certain goods and trade flows – USA Trade has very comprehensive, district-level data that can help frame larger trends and analysis. The website itself, however, is not the most intuitive to figure out. This session will demonstrate how to use USA Trade and discuss some ways to understand and use the data in your reporting. You will need to make a free account on https://usatrade.census.gov/ to follow along. This session is good for everyone, especially for those to whom U.S. import/export data would be useful. 

No data experience is necessary! Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

speakers.bio: Paroma Soni is a Data and Graphics Reporter at Politico, where she covers trade, agriculture, and immigration. She was previously an Associate Visual Journalist at FiveThirtyEight. Based in New York City, she is also on the IRE Board.

session_title: From the outside, looking in: Covering communities and topics you are not part of
description: Investigative reporters are often asked to cover topics that impact or intersect with communities they are not part of. So, how do you build trust, report equitably, and communicate sincerely about your desire to help? This panel discussion will go over ways to connect with communities to build trust, cultivate sources and create open lines of communication.

speakers.bio: Natalia Alamdari is a senior reporter at the Flatwater Free Press covering rural communities in Nebraska. She's reported from cornfields, one-student classrooms, small-town quinceañera dress shops and even a hotel of Ukrainian refugees and Nebraskan volunteers in Poland. Her reporting on Nebraska prisons won a 2023 Great Plains Journalism Award. Previously, Alamdari worked at newspapers in Missouri, Texas and Delaware.

Hannah Critchfield is a reporter on the Tampa Bay Times’ investigations team. Her work has spotlighted potentially unlawful arrests of undocumented people, companies concealing worker deaths and overdoses caused by a virtually unregulated substance.

speakers.affiliation: Los Angeles Center for Investigative Journalism
speakers.bio: Albert Serna Jr. is the executive editor and founder of the Los Angeles Center for Investigative Journalism based in Los Angeles' San Gabriel Valley. Serna has covered cops, Crime, national politics, FOIA and extremism at the national and local level. He has a passion for community-centered investigations that serve under-reported communities and people.
Connor Sheets is an investigative and enterprise reporter at The Los Angeles Times.
Omar Waheed is a business and investigative reporter at Madison365. His work is centered on marginalized communities, equity, accountability, labor and workforce development.

session_title: Investigations following breaking news
description: The best investigations deftly combine narrative in the "day two" story after breaking news as more information may trickle out. We chat about using the tools of storytelling to make people and policymakers care about harms, wrongdoing and matters of accountability. We'll give an overview of how to report, write, structure and edit the story in the days and weeks after news breaks and unpack the challenges that even longtime reporters and editors struggle with along the way.

speakers.bio: Joey is an investigative reporter on The Boston Globe’s Spotlight Team. He was previously a municipal government reporter and associate editor at the Miami Herald for 11 years. He's covered corruption, controversial land deals, hurricanes and disasters. He was part of the team that won the 2022 Pulitzer Prize for Breaking News Reporting for coverage of the collapse of a residential condo building in Surfside, FL.

Anne Ryman is an investigative reporter at ABC15 Arizona in Phoenix. Before that, she was an investigative reporter at The Arizona Republic. She is part of the newspaper's 2018 Pulitzer Prize-winning team in explanatory reporting.

Walter Smith Randolph is the Executive Producer of Investigations at CBS News New York, an Adjunct Assistant Professor at the CUNY Newmark Graduate School of Journalism, and The National Association of Black Journalists' Vice President-Broadcast. The New York City native is a graduate of Villanova University and the CUNY Newmark Graduate School of Journalism.

session_title: Making the most out of your mentorship connection
description: Ready to start giving back as a mentor but aren't sure where to start? Want something specific – work feedback, job advice, networking – as a mentee? Join this conversation members of IRE’s mentorship subcommittee to learn how to navigate a successful mentor-mentee relationship.

speakers.bio: Ashley Graham is the chief investigator and 6 p.m. anchor in Shreveport, Louisiana. She holds a Bachelor's degree in English from Emory University and a Master of Science in Journalism degree from Northwestern University. Her work in Michigan, Florida, and Louisiana brings viewers an in-depth look at issues that directly affect them.

Josh Hinkle is KXAN’s director of investigations and innovation, leading the station’s duPont and IRE Award-winning investigative team on multiple platforms. He also leads KXAN’s political coverage as executive producer and host of “State of Texas,” a weekly statewide program focused on the Texas Legislature and elections. In 2021, he was elected to the IRE Board of Directors and currently serves as its vice president.

Emily Le Coz is executive editor-in-chief of Suncoast Searchlight, a nonprofit investigative newsroom on Florida’s west coast. A longtime investigative reporter and editor, she has worked at USA TODAY, GateHouse Media, the Sarasota Herald-Tribune, and the Jackson Clarion-Ledger. Her work has earned national recognition, including the Robert F. Kennedy Journalism Award, the APME Public Service Award, and finalist honors for the Goldsmith and Selden Ring awards.

session_title: Managing the investigation
description: Editing a data-driven or investigative story comes with its own challenges. We'll talk about how to manage quick-turn and enterprise projects. Topics include vetting ideas, time management and keeping channels of communication open inside the newsroom. We'll also look at a litmus test for whether a story is worth further investigation.

speakers.bio: Cindy Galli is formerly the executive producer of ABC News’ award-winning investigative unit, where she oversaw a team of reporters and producers specializing in government fraud, corporate corruption, racial injustice, consumer, and environmental issues. Cindy also built and oversaw a collaborative team that produced investigations with and across ABC’s owned stations and affiliates nationwide. Cindy currently serves on the IRE board of directors.

Andrea Gallo is the senior investigations editor for The Times-Picayune | The Advocate, overseeing investigative and enterprise stories for Louisiana's largest newspaper. She is an award-winning journalist and public records enthusiast.

Kevin Keeshan is EVP for News Editorial for NBC Universal Local. He has editorial oversight for the consumer and investigative units. During his 13-year tenure, the division has won 21 national Murrows, five Peabodys, five duPonts, and three IRE Awards. Before he arrived at NBC, Keeshan spent 22 years at ABC, the last 11 as VP for News at KGO in San Francisco.

Michael Sallah is a two-time Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter and editor who has led investigations into international money laundering, police abuses and public corruption that have resulted in grand jury inquiries, legislative reforms, and the recovery of millions in tax dollars.

session_title: Master class: From scoop to screen: Transforming investigative TV reports into compelling shows and documentaries, and vice versa - pre-registered attendees only
description:
Do you have a series of investigative TV stories that would make the perfect longform show but you don’t know where to start?
Maybe your boss said, “Hey, you should try producing something for streaming,” and you’re worried about finding the time.
Or you may have always wanted to produce a full documentary, but that isn’t really part of your job.
In this workshop, seasoned investigative TV journalists and documentary producers guide you through the dynamic process of producing a long-form show, with best practices for finding the right idea, getting started, staying organized, and executing your script and video. We’ll explore a variety of workflows for adapting a series of TV stories into a cohesive show, or how to start with a full-fledged documentary or primetime show, while adding TV newscast coverage later.
Learn how to expand the scope of your reporting, deepen character arcs, and structure a long-form narrative that captivates and informs!
We’ll explore:
How to identify a broader story arc
Maintain viewer interest over an extended period
Strategies for pitching the project
Ways to add value for your station and your viewers
Visual and narrative pacing for a longer format
Key decisions to make before you get started

Pre-registration is required and seating is limited.

speakers.bio: As Managing Editor of Investigative Content for Cox Media Group, Jodie manages national collaborations and investigations for eight local TV stations. She spent more than 20 years as an investigative reporter at WRC in Washington, WSB in Atlanta, and WFTV in Orlando. She’s earned some of journalism’s top honors, including an IRE Award, a duPont Award, a Goldsmith Special Citation and was a 2024 Pulitzer Prize finalist for Public Service. She has served on IRE’s Board of Directors since 2019.

A.J. Lagoe is an investigative reporter for KARE-TV in Minneapolis. His reporting has led to criminal convictions, legislative hearings, and new state and federal laws. A two-time recipient of the IRE Award, A.J. has also been recognized with many of journalism’s other highest honors, including the George Polk Award, along with multiple Peabody and duPont Columbia Awards.

Cristin Severance is the Investigative Reporter and Documentary Producer at WRAL, where she leads the station’s award-winning Documentary Unit with a mission to expose the truth and inspire change. She spent 20 years as an investigative reporter across the country, including in Dallas, Portland, San Diego, and Cleveland, before joining WRAL, one of the only dedicated documentary teams in local television news.

​​Chris Vanderveen is the Director of Investigations at Denver's KUSA-TV. He is a Peabody, duPont-Columbia, and IRE Award recipient. His investigations have focused on everything from ineffective helicopter fuel systems to dangerous police restraint techniques. He lives in Denver and likes pugs, people and fulfilled open record requests.

session_title: Media lawyer Q&A
description: Does your investigation involve complex legal questions and you're unsure how to proceed? Bring your questions for a personal discussion with some prominent media law experts.
track: Attacks on the press, Public records

speakers.bio: Ross Garber is the principal of The Garber Group LLC, a law firm based in Washington, D.C. He also teaches Government Investigations and Impeachment Law at Tulane Law School in New Orleans. His clients have included public officials, journalists, and a variety of organizations in government investigations and high-stakes civil cases. He is a contributing author of the book Ethics in the Public Sector. Ross was previously a legal analyst for CNN.

Maggie Mulvihill is a veteran reporter, data journalism trainer, news entrepreneur, First Amendment advocate, and attorney. An Associate Professor of the Practice in Computational Journalism at Boston University, Mulvihill’s students have won numerous regional and national awards, including this year's IRE top student honor for a collaboration with The Howard Center for Investigative Journalism at the University of Maryland.

speakers.affiliation: Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press
speakers.bio: Jennifer Nelson is a senior staff attorney with the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, where she leads its pre-publication and pre-broadcast review practice, oversees the publication of and updates to the Reporters Committee’s legal guides, and supervises its hotline for journalists. Nelson also regularly represents news organizations and journalists in public records, court access, and legal defense matters before federal and state courts.

Matt Topic runs the media and intellectual property practice at Loevy + Loevy. Matt and his team have litigated hundreds of state and federal open records cases.  Matt also represents several news publishers in copyright cases against OpenAI and Microsoft.

session_title: Pitching a great investigative project
description:
The most important step in launching an investigation is focusing on the idea. What do you investigate?  How do you get there?
What are the best ways to vet an idea?
There is both a how to:  what is the process organizations  use to brainstorm or pitch investigative proposals and
how do they evaluate ideas to move ahead with the best:

speakers.bio: Nicole Dungca is an investigative reporter at The Washington Post. She is the co-host of the podcast Broken Doors, which examined the use of no-knock warrants in the American justice system, and one of the authors of Searching for Maura, an illustrated investigation into the Smithsonian Institution's collection of human remains. She currently serves as the president of the Asian American Journalists Association.

Matt Krupnick is a Chicago-based reporter and editor specializing in inequity/inequality, education, investigative work, data journalism and the environment. His work has been published by ProPublica, The New York Times, The Guardian, The Washington Post and the Hechinger Report, among other national and international publications.

Brian M. Rosenthal is an investigative reporter at The New York Times and an adjunct professor at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. He is currently the president of the IRE Board of Directors.

Brad Schrade is an investigative editor at The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. He previously worked as an investigative reporter at The Tennessean and The Minneapolis Star Tribune, where he was part of a team that won a 2013 Pulitzer Prize for a series that exposed a rise in deaths across Minnesota's daycare system. He began his career as a reporter, covering a variety of beats, including police, courts, education, city hall, and state government.

Claudia Vargas is an investigative reporter at NBC10 Philadelphia and Telemundo62. Her stories have focused on police accountability, housing, and environmental issues. Claudia has worked on several award-winning documentaries. The most recent, “Finding Carlesha” has more than 1.3 million views and recently won the regional Edward R. Murrow Award for News Documentary. Claudia previously worked at the Philadelphia Inquirer and Democrat & Chronicle (Rochester, NY.)

session_title: Show & Tell: Anything goes (traditional)
description:
Sign up to “Show & Tell” us about your best work and get constructive feedback from the moderator and audience. 

Sign-ups are required for presenters. Each presenter will have 15 minutes to share their work and receive feedback. All are welcome to attend!

Sign up here: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/10C084CA8AC29A4FBCE9-57104292-show

*These sessions will not be recorded.

speakers.bio: Rick Yarborough is Senior Investigative Producer at NBC Washington where he launched the NEWS4 I-Team in 2011.  His work has been recognized with multiple national awards, including a Peabody,  duPont-Columbia University, Gerald Loeb Award, Scripps Howard Foundation, National Headliners, National Press Club & Fourth Estate Award, along with many regional Emmys and Murrows.  He also leads the OUT DC Employee Resource Group for LGBTQ+ and Ally employees.

session_title: What is (and isn't) a good fit for AI-assisted journalism?
description: This session details how the New York Times A.I. Initiatives team integrates product design, machine learning, and editorial expertise to help create stories with A.I. and build tools for investigative journalism. We will present real-world examples of how the industry uses machine learning in investigative reporting, demonstrate our tools, and help reporters triage what is a good fit for A.I. – and what isn't. The presentation will conclude with an open discussion.

speakers.bio: Juliana Castro Varón is a designer, doodler and technologist. She's the Senior Design Editor of AI Initiatives at the New York Times and the founder of the open-access book publisher Cita Press. Previously, she was a fellow at the Berkman Klein Center for Internet & Society at Harvard. Juliana is the author of Papel Sensible (Espasa, 2022), and her cartoons appear regularly in The New Yorker.

Dylan Freedman is a machine-learning engineer and journalist on the A.I. Initiatives team at The New York Times, where he assists with reporting and builds tools to help the newsroom. He was most recently at The Washington Post, where he built open-source tools and software for elections. He previously led development at DocumentCloud and worked on a machine-learning research team at Google.

session_title: Are you afraid of the AI?
description: Artificial intelligence –– for better or worse –– is here to stay and its influence on newsgathering, news cycles, and the future of journalism is only growing. This panel will focus on helping journalists understand AI 101 and the opportunities that AI is creating for journalists. This is a no holds barred, no dumb questions discussion that features journalists who are creating and building projects using AI and using it to make their jobs easier.

speakers.affiliation: Investigative Project on Race and Equity
speakers.bio: Marissa Evans is the investigations editor with the Investigative Project on Race and Equity. Previously a health reporter at the Los Angeles Times, she covered race, healthcare, and entertainment. While at the Star Tribune, where her investigative work exposed how the state allowed private hospitals to seize tax refunds from individuals with unpaid medical bills, leading to legislative action in 2021 aimed at ending the policy.

speakers.affiliation: Howard Center for Investigative Journalism, Arizona State University
speakers.bio: Mark Greenblatt is the executive editor and a professor at ASU's Howard Center for Investigative Journalism. He is a three-time Peabody Award winner, whose stories have also won the IRE Medal, two National Emmy Awards for investigative reporting, the duPont-Columbia Award, and the Livingston Award. He is devoting this chapter of his career to supporting the next generation of investigative leaders. Mark is the elected Treasurer and a Member of the Board of Directors for IRE.

Liz Lucas is an associate professor and the Houston Harte Chair in Journalism at Mizzou, where she teaches classes in problem solving with data and AI. Previously she was the senior training director at IRE.

session_title: Broadcast track: Here's the data, where's the story?
description: How do you get from “I got the data” to TV? Three broadcast journalists walk you through every step from getting the data to transforming what you find into an interesting TV story.

speakers.bio: David Barer is a senior investigative producer and reporter at KXAN News, where he has been stationed for 10 years. Barer's reporting has changed state law, led to numerous bills being filed in the Texas legislature, and won dozens of regional accolades, as well as national Edward R. Murrow, Society of Professional Journalists, and Walter Cronkite awards.

Lori Jane Gliha is a national investigative reporter for Scripps News. This year, she was honored with the prestigious duPont-Columbia Award, an IRE Award, and a NY Press Club Award for her investigation into Maine's deadliest mass shooting. She has also been nationally recognized for her extensive, exclusive reporting on fentanyl deaths among babies and young children, as well as for her reporting on the use of ketamine by paramedics to sedate agitated people.

John Kelly is Vice President of Data Journalism for CBS News, leading teams focused on data, open-source intelligence and investigative reporting for the network's news programs such as CBS Evening News and 60 Minutes, as well as 15 owned local CBS Stations and cbsnews.com. He previously led similar teams for ABC News and USA Today.

session_title: Excel 3: Filtering & pivot tables
description:
A look at the awesome power of pivot — and how to use it to analyze your dataset in minutes rather than hours. We'll work up to using a pivot table by first sorting and filtering a dataset, learning how to find story ideas along the way.

This session is good for: Anyone familiar with formulas, sorting and filtering in Excel or another spreadsheet program. Laptops will be provided.

speakers.bio: Ryann Grochowski Jones is the director of data journalism at ABC News and Owned Television Stations. Previously, she was the data editor at ProPublica and an investigative data reporter at inewsource in San Diego, California. Ryann received her master's degree from the University of Missouri School of Journalism, where she was a data librarian at IRE/NICAR. Ryann began her career as a municipal beat reporter for her hometown newspaper in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania.

Maia Rosenfeld is a data journalist on the ABC News & Owned Stations Data Team. Based in Philadelphia, Maia wrangles data into scoops for local stations across the country. She reports national data-driven investigations for ABC News, collaborating with producers to find the people behind the numbers and share their stories. Maia specializes in finding creative ways to address data challenges. Before joining ABC she produced national investigations at Scripps’ DC Bureau.

session_title: Finding the story: Campaign finance data
description:
A hands-on introduction to searching for, finding and using federal campaign finance data for beginners. This class will cover using the new Federal Election Commission website to find and download different types of campaign finance data. We'll also review things to know about the data, including common pitfalls.

This session is good for: people who want an introduction to finding and working with federal campaign finance data. Knowing Excel will be helpful. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

speakers.bio: Soorin Kim in an investigative data reporter at ABC News covering the second Trump presidency. She specializes in following money in politics -- how political contributions, lobbying and other influence operations move those in power. During the 2024 election, she covered President Donald Trump's reelection campaign as a campaign embed reporter.

session_title: Funding the future of investigative journalism
description: Tips and tricks from some of the leading journalism foundations on applying to grants. Do's and don'ts of writing an application, creating a budget, being realistic about your impact and more.

speakers.bio: Eric Ferrero is the Executive Director of the Fund for Investigative Journalism, which directly provides grants and other support to journalists for specific investigative projects. Over the last twenty years, he has served in senior leadership roles at nonprofit and philanthropic organizations that support and partner closely with journalists to uncover groundbreaking stories, including the Open Society Foundations, Innocence Project, and Amnesty International.

Jane Sasseen is executive director of the McGraw Center for Business Journalism at CUNY’s Newmark Graduate School of Journalism, which provides grants for business and financial investigative stories. Previously, she was senior editor and Washington bureau chief for BusinessWeek, politics editor-in-chief for Yahoo News, and Paris bureau chief of International Management magazine. She is a recipient of the Gerald Loeb Award, the top prize in financial journalism.

speakers.affiliation: USC Annenberg Center for Health Journalism
speakers.bio: Jacqueline Stenson is the manager of projects at the USC Annenberg Center for Health Journalism, where she collaborates with journalists nationwide on major investigative and explanatory stories. She previously worked with multiple media outlets, including NBC News/MSNBC, The New York Times Syndicate and Condé Nast. Her freelance work has been published in the Los Angeles Times, Reuters, TODAY, Health and more. She has also taught for the UCLA Extension Writers’ Program.

session_title: How to find data on Indigenous communities and what to do when it doesn't exist
description: When we look at the data on Indigenous peoples, including American Indians and Alaska Natives, we are able to see that there is a substantial amount of data from health care to education undercounted and misclassified, often cited as a lack of uniformity on how it's collected over generations by governments. We'll talk about best practices as Indigenous data sovereignty, the idea that Indigenous Peoples should decide how to collect, own, and use their own data, globally gains traction.

speakers.bio: Dana Hedgpeth is a Native American journalist at The Washington Post. She has over 30 years of experience as a reporter, covering a range of topics, including defense spending, D.C.’s rail and bus systems, courts, local governments, and crises. Most recently, she was part of a team that did an investigation into deaths and abuse at Indian boarding schools that won the Maynard Justice Award of the Poynter Journalism Prize.

Dianna Hunt is national editor/news director at ICT/Indian Country Today. She directed and edited the Pulitzer Prize-finalist breaking news coverage of Hurricane Harvey while metro editor at the Houston Chronicle, and also worked for the Dallas Morning News, Fort Worth Star-Telegram and other publications. She served three terms on the IRE board and is currently on the boards for the Fund for Investigative Journalism and Investigative Editing Corps.

session_title: How to land your first job: Roundtable for early-career journalists
description: Join us for a conversation about how to navigate the journalism job hunt, build relationships with mentors and set yourself up for success in an industry that can often feel daunting. We'll chat about our paths to our current roles and be on hand to answer your questions, big and small.

speakers.bio: Ashley is an engagement reporter at ProPublica. She started my career in local television news at NBC in Washington, D.C. After leaving NBC, she became an audience engagement editor at the Center for Public Integrity.

Olivia is the Washington Federal Affairs Reporter at The Washington Post, covering the Trump administration's impact on the D.C. Region. Previously, she covered city government at the Tampa Bay Times, where she was named 2024 Outstanding New Journalist by Florida's chapter of the Society of Professional Journalists.

Josh Hinkle is KXAN’s director of investigations and innovation, leading the station’s duPont and IRE Award-winning investigative team on multiple platforms. He also leads KXAN’s political coverage as executive producer and host of “State of Texas,” a weekly statewide program focused on the Texas Legislature and elections. In 2021, he was elected to the IRE Board of Directors and currently serves as its vice president.

session_title: Investigating for-profit health care
description: Health care is a wildly profitable business, accounting for nearly 20 percent of the American economy. In your community there may be companies putting revenue before care. Our panelists have years of experience covering a range of companies, including for-profit (and even so-called non-profit) hospital systems, clinics, behavioral hospitals, elder care facilities like assisted living and memory care, and pharmaceutical firms. We will show you how to find these stories and how to report them out, with lists of story ideas, sources, how to get data and how to find experts who can propose solutions.

speakers.bio: Phil Barber is a reporter for the Santa Rosa Press Democrat, an hour north of San Francisco. He was a sportswriter for many years before shifting to news in the early months of the pandemic. Phil’s has since done investigative reporting on subjects including real estate fraud, wage theft, political extremism, corporate elder neglect and forced sterilization of people with developmental disabilities. He grew up in the Sacramento Valley.

Mary Fricker is a business reporter who retired from The Santa Rosa (Calif.) Press Democrat. She freelances and publishes repowatch.org, which won SABEW’s Best in Business digital blog. Other awards: three IRE awards, McGill Medal for Journalistic Courage, UCLA Gerald Loeb Award, George Polk award, AP awards for business reporting. She co-authored the best-selling “Inside Job – The Looting of America’s Savings and Loans.” She graduated from the College of William & Mary.

Elizabeth Koh is an investigative reporter on the Boston Globe’s Spotlight Team, writing about health care, social services and government accountability. Previously, she was a Seoul correspondent for The Wall Street Journal and a state politics reporter at the Miami Herald. She has been a Pulitzer finalist twice: in 2021 with Journal colleagues for stories on Covid-19 in nursing homes, and in 2025 as part of a Globe team covering the collapse of a major hospital chain.

speakers.affiliation: Mother Jones/ Center for Investigative Reporting
speakers.bio: Hannah Levintova is the special projects editor and an investigative reporter at Mother Jones and the Center for Investigative Reporting. Her work focuses on uncovering financial wrongdoing in areas that impact daily life, from housing to healthcare, with a particular emphasis on private equity. She holds an MBA from Columbia Business School, where she was also a Knight-Bagehot Fellow in Business Journalism.

Jessica Silver-Greenberg is an investigative business reporter at the New York Times, where she writes about what happens when big business collides with all kinds of people — residents of nursing homes, patients, credit card customers, workers, and consumers. Recently, she has focused on the intersection of money and health care.
Katie Thomas is an investigative reporter at the New York Times. Her work explores the intersection of money and health care, focusing on how business decisions affect the lives of real people.

session_title: Investigating war crimes in an active, sealed-off war zone
description: In this panel, journalists will share their experience producing collaborative investigations between journalists inside Gaza and their counterparts outside the war zone. Join this session to learn strategies that journalists can use for verifying on-the-ground critical reporting, and to learn from the panelists' experience covering the war in Gaza.

speakers.bio: Yahya Abou-Ghazala is an award-winning reporter and producer with CNN’s investigative unit, based in Washington, DC. His work with the unit involves reporting and producing in-depth investigations for both digital and television audiences.

Kavitha Chekuru is an independent journalist and documentary filmmaker. Her work has primarily focused on human rights and justice, including the war in Gaza, the US bombing campaign in Afghanistan, enforced disappearances in Mexico and the killing of land rights activists across Latin America. Her reporting has been recognized with a Peabody Award, the George Polk Award and seven News and Documentary Emmy nominations.

Hoda Osman is a freelance investigative journalist and editor based in New York. She is Executive Editor at Arab Reporters for Investigative Journalism, where she oversees international projects. She worked on the Gaza Project, investigating attacks on journalists in Gaza, and is currently a co-producer on a PBS Frontline film about Syria. She previously worked with ABC, CBS, France24 and the Associated Press, and trains journalists worldwide in investigative reporting.

Maryam Saleh is the investigations editor at Rest of World, which covers the use and misuse of technology outside the West. She was previously a senior editor at The Intercept, where she edited features and investigations on the war in Gaza, the death penalty, and environmental racism. At Reveal from The Center for Investigative Reporting, she was the lead editor on an award-winning project exposing a wave of legislation to increase police involvement in elections.

session_title: Show & Tell: Crime and corruption investigations
description:
Sign up to “Show & Tell” us about your best work and get constructive feedback from the moderator and audience. 

Sign-ups are required for presenters. Each presenter will have 15 minutes to share their work and receive feedback. All are welcome to attend!

Sign up here: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/10C084CA8AC29A4FBCE9-57104177-show

*These sessions will not be recorded.

session_title: Tips and tools to level up your investigative project
description: Come meet Big Local News, a small but mighty organization dedicated to supporting local investigative reporting with data and newsroom tools. We’ll showcase some of those tools and guide you to resources you can use to collaborate on data journalism projects, harvest data and documents at scale, and track institutions for accountability reporting, from police agencies to state legislatures.

session_title: Tracking the hundreds of lawsuits filed against the Trump administration
description: We combined scraping, Google Sheets, Slack alerts, the knowledge of an experienced legal reporter and other resources to track the hundreds of lawsuits filed against the Trump administration so far. In this session, we’ll review how we carried out a large-scale reporting project involving the courts.
track: Reporting and writing strategies, Public records, Business

speakers.bio: Cam Baker is a senior news assistant on the Data Journalism team at The New York Times. They previously worked as a freelancer, for The Intercept and at the Dart Center for Journalism and Trauma at the Columbia Journalism School. They have degrees from the Columbia Journalism School and McGill University.

Seamus Hughes is the publisher of Court Watch. Hughes is also a New York Times research journalist working on many stories related to the federal court system. In 2022, he was a small part of a New York Times team that won a Pulitzer Prize for National Reporting on law enforcement in America. He also works with Bloomberg Law News for their investigative team. He previously worked as a research journalist with Rolling Stone and Daily Beast.

session_title: When government data disappears: How to cross-check, preserve, and investigate
description: From vanishing government websites to manipulated economic data, journalists are facing increasing challenges in verifying official information. This session will cover how to investigate missing or altered government records and ensure the integrity of public-interest reporting. Panelists will discuss how to verify whether government data has been changed or removed, how to find alternative sources when public records disappear, and how to archive and preserve crucial datasets before they become inaccessible. This session is designed for journalists who rely on public records, government websites, or large datasets and need to ensure their information remains reliable and available.
track: Reporting and writing strategies, Beat reporting

speakers.bio: Jay Hunter is the founder of Hunter Index, a not-for-profit organization covering the personal finances of politicians. He previously worked in editorial and product roles in various news organizations, including CQ Roll Call, The Economist, and The Washington Post. A proud Yinzer, Jay graduated from The Ohio State University before beginning his career in journalism and tech.

Jason Leopold is an investigative reporter at Bloomberg News. He is a recipient of the Gerald Loeb award, a George Polk award, and he has twice been a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize. In 2020, TRAC identified Leopold as "the most active individual FOIA litigator” in the US. In 2016, Leopold was awarded the FOI award from IRE and was inducted into the National Freedom of Information Hall of Fame. He publishes the weekly newsletter, FOIA Files.

Anna Massoglia is an independent investigative analyst. She serves as director of investigations at the Sunlight Research Center and as an advisor to multiple newsrooms, academic institutions and nonprofits. Anna previously led OpenSecrets’ editorial and investigations team. She holds degrees in political science and psychology from North Carolina State University and a J.D. from the University of the District of Columbia School of Law.
Michael is a freelance data journalist and investigative researcher. He currently works as a data specialist with Sunlight Research Center.

session_title: IRE Board of Directors meeting
description: The IRE Board of Directors will meet on Thursday from 2-5 p.m. in Studio 6 (4th floor) as part of the annual conference. The meeting is open to all IRE members.

session_title: Beyond the Ivies: Major higher ed stories you shouldn’t miss
description: Universities around the U.S. are facing political scrutiny at federal, state and local levels—affecting nearly every beat in your newsroom. Amid the spotlight on budget cuts and anti-DEI laws, are you missing the stories that may impact your community the most? Come to this panel to learn about the under-covered stories in higher education and how to cover them on your beat. Your viewers, readers and listeners might be shocked to know what's happening at colleges and universities nationwide. This session is sponsored by Lumina Foundation. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

speakers.bio: Meredith Kolodner is an investigative reporter at The Hechinger Report, a nonprofit news organization focused on education, where she has written about for-profit colleges, student debt and racial equity. She previously covered schools for The New York Daily News and was an editor at Inside Schools and The Investigative Fund (now known as Type Investigations). Her work has appeared in many outlets, including NBC News, The New York Times and The Washington Post.

Arionne Nettles is a professor, culture reporter, and audio aficionado who serves as the Garth C. Reeves Eminent Scholar Chair and instructor for digital journalism at Florida A&M University. As a journalist, her stories often examine Chicago's history, culture, and racial and class disparities. She is the author of We Are the Culture: Black Chicago’s Influence on Everything and Journalism for Dummies.

session_title: Broadcast track: Make it memorable! Storytelling in investigations
description: What makes a broadcast investigation not just good, but unforgettable? This panel dives into the craft and storytelling techniques that elevate powerful broadcast investigations. Learn how to shape complex reporting into stories that resonate and stay with viewers.

speakers.bio: A.J. Lagoe is an investigative reporter for KARE-TV in Minneapolis. His reporting has led to criminal convictions, legislative hearings, and new state and federal laws. A two-time recipient of the IRE Award, A.J. has also been recognized with many of journalism’s other highest honors, including the George Polk Award, along with multiple Peabody and duPont Columbia Awards.

Cristin Severance is the Investigative Reporter and Documentary Producer at WRAL, where she leads the station’s award-winning Documentary Unit with a mission to expose the truth and inspire change. She spent 20 years as an investigative reporter across the country, including in Dallas, Portland, San Diego, and Cleveland, before joining WRAL, one of the only dedicated documentary teams in local television news.

​​Chris Vanderveen is the Director of Investigations at Denver's KUSA-TV. He is a Peabody, duPont-Columbia, and IRE Award recipient. His investigations have focused on everything from ineffective helicopter fuel systems to dangerous police restraint techniques. He lives in Denver and likes pugs, people and fulfilled open record requests.

session_title: Excel: Importing and data prep
description:
Don't give up if your data isn't presented in a neat Excel file. This session will teach you how to get data into Excel and prepare it for analysis. We will look at how to import text files, deal with data in a PDF, and get a table on a web page into Excel.

This session is good for: Anyone comfortable working in Excel. Laptops will be provided.

speakers.bio: Katie Wilcox is the I-Team Executive Producer at 12News in Phoenix, where she leads her team to produce data-driven investigations that expose waste, fraud and abuse. Katie also worked as a data journalist in Denver at 9NEWS and Rocky Mountain PBS. Her work has prompted legislation and policy changes in Colorado and Arizona. Katie grew up in southwest Iowa and graduated from the University of Iowa with her bachelor’s degrees in economics and journalism.

session_title: Following the anti-trans federal actions
description: As Republican administrations continue attacks on trans people across the country in health care, education, military service and behind bars, reporters need to be ready to cover this far reaching topic with accuracy, nuance, and care. Come to this session to hear how to tackle these important stories, how to push back on rhetoric and euphemism, and how to tell honest, truthful stories about trans people in your communities.
track: Gender & reproductive rights, Beat reporting, "Equity - inclusion - accessibility"

speakers.bio: As a Report for America corps member, Gisselle Medina covers religion, culture, and community development for Fresnoland. They recently won two CA News Publishers Association awards for coverage of LGBTQ+ issues and religion. Their work has appeared in the LA Times, The Oaklandside, and The Frisc. Medina holds a master’s in journalism from UC Berkeley, where they also studied English, and was a 2023 White House Correspondents’ Association scholarship recipient.

Lewis Raven Wallace is a journalist based in Durham, North Carolina, the author of The View from Somewhere: Undoing the Myth of Journalistic Objectivity, and a co-founder of Press On, a southern movement journalism collective. He’s a 2021 Ford Global Fellow, and currently the Abolition Journalism Fellow at Interrupting Criminalization. His book, Radical Unlearning, will be released in October. He is white and transgender, and was raised in the Midwest with deep roots in the South.

session_title: From text to TV (and everything in between): How investigative journalists have adapted over the years
description: This moderated conversation will explore the challenges and triumphs that journalists face when they're ready (or forced) to pivot. Panelists will share personal anecdotes that illustrate their experiences, providing insight into the strategies they employ to remain relevant and impactful in an industry marked by rapid change. You'll walk away with practical advice and insights that can benefit aspiring and seasoned journalists alike.

speakers.bio: Neal Bennett is a long-time journalist who now recruits journalists for The E.W. Scripps Company. His focus is on hiring print journalists interested in transitioning to broadcast roles, as well as recruiting early-career and college students. He was a news director and digital director for stations in Florida, Virginia, South Dakota, and Missouri. He holds both a bachelor's and a master's degree from the University of Florida.

Laura Frank is Executive Director of the Colorado News Collaborative (COLab), where 200 news outlets and colleges partner to end the “Fried and Frozen Dilemma” facing news outlets. Laura is a founder and chair emerita of the Institute for Nonprofit News, led investigative reporting teams to duPont and Murrow awards, received entrepreneurial fellowships at Columbia and USC, and is the Wolzien Visiting Professor at the University of Denver.

Jared Kofsky produces in-depth stories for ABC News platforms, including Good Morning America, World News Tonight, ABC News Live, and ABCNews.com, working from both the field and the network’s headquarters in New York. He is also an on-air investigative contributor for ABC News Radio affiliates around the country. Jared previously served as the investigative producer for WCSC-TV in South Carolina and as a digital reporter covering New Jersey real estate for Jersey Digs.

Anne Ryman is an investigative reporter at ABC15 Arizona in Phoenix. Before that, she was an investigative reporter at The Arizona Republic. She is part of the newspaper's 2018 Pulitzer Prize-winning team in explanatory reporting.

Independent filmmaking is the latest chapter in Olive Talley’s award-winning journalism career that spans network television, newspapers, radio and an international wire service. She is a three-time Emmy finalist, Pulitzer finalist in investigative reporting, and winner of numerous awards, including the George Polk, Headliners. She is a former IRE board member and Nieman fellow.

session_title: Integrating data into your curriculum: A workshop for educators teaching data - pre-registered attendees only
description:
Have you ever thought about teaching data journalism? Maybe to a class of college students, a cohort of curious reporters at your newsroom, or even just a protégé that wants to know what you know? This 3-hour class will get you started on the fundaments of teaching data skills to the uninitiated at any level. We'll talk about how to structure a lesson, explain fundamental concepts, lead hands-on exercises, and more. No previous data or coding experience is required. 

This session is good for anyone interested in teaching data journalism! Preregistration is required and seating is limited. You must bring your own laptop (no tablets) to this training, and you will need a free Google account to participate.

speakers.bio: Laura Jael Kurtzberg is a data visualization specialist, cartographer and news applications developer with a particular interest in environmental stories. Laura has worked at the intersection of data journalism and design with organizations like InfoAmazonia, Ambiental Media, WLRN Public Media and Mongabay.

Liz Lucas is an associate professor and the Houston Harte Chair in Journalism at Mizzou, where she teaches classes in problem solving with data and AI. Previously she was the senior training director at IRE.
Journalist and educator working from San Juan, Puerto Rico.

session_title: Investigating climate change
description: Learn how to execute climate reporting across any beat in the newsroom, explore how to turn policy and data analysis into visual investigations, and come away with different story ideas to cover climate issues at the national, state and local levels. We'll look at how to cover potential solutions to fight climate change, as well as the obstacles society is facing in trying to decarbonize. Panelists will discuss the current challenges to climate reporting and how to overcome the issue of disappearing datasets to support environmental investigations.
track: Climate, Research, Story ideas, Beat reporting

speakers.bio: Michael Biesecker is a global investigative reporter for The Associated Press. Biesecker’s work tracking potential war crimes in Ukraine was recognized with the 2022 IRE Gold Medal, as well as the top award for investigative reporting from the Overseas Press Club of America. He was a contributor to the AP team that won the 2023 Pulitzer Prize for Public Service. Biesecker also teaches investigative and environmental reporting at Georgetown University.

Allison Prang is a freelance journalist based in Washington, D.C., who primarily writes about climate issues. Her work has appeared in The New York Times, Canary Media, Business of Fashion, States Newsroom, and numerous other outlets. She was formerly a full-time reporter for The Wall Street Journal, POLITICO, American Banker and The Post and Courier in Charleston, South Carolina.
Tracy J. Wholf is a senior coordinating producer of climate and environmental coverage for CBS News and Stations, based in New York.

session_title: Make your resume, CV and bio stand out
description: Well-known as a mentor and career coach to journalists of many backgrounds, learn how to polish and enliven your bio, resume, CV, etc, with Benét Wilson. This session will address how to revamp resumes, cover letters, career navigation outlook and networking prowess.

speakers.bio: Benét J. Wilson is the lead credit cards writer for Bankrate. She was previously director of the Poynter-Koch Media and Journalism Fellowship. Before that, she was a senior editor and writer for The Points Guy. She serves on the boards of Mercer University’s Center for Collaborative Journalism and the Institute for Independent Journalism. She graduated from American University in Washington, D.C., with a B.A. in broadcast journalism and resides in Baltimore, MD.

session_title: Master class: Outlining and structure: The writer's missing manual (pre-registered attendees only)
description:
Outlining might be the single best thing you can do to make you a better, faster writer. This isn't the roman numeral outlining your middle school teacher taught you. We'll take a story from the ground up, showing how early considerations about structure and framing develop into a draft.

Preregistration is required and seating is limited.

speakers.bio: Matt Apuzzo is international investigations editor for the New York Times. He is based in London, where he manages a team of six reporters and works with bureau chiefs around the world. A former investigative reporter in Washington and Brussels, he has won or shared in three Pulitzer Prizes.

session_title: Navigating record requests within the criminal legal system
description: Impactful reporting on the criminal justice system hinges on a journalist’s ability to access detailed information about the inner workings of that system. This information has always been hard to come by and is only growing more so during a time of declining transparency. In this panel, attendees will have the opportunity to learn from their peers who are experts in obtaining data, court records, and public records from criminal justice agencies and using that information to tell powerful stories about everything from fatal police chases to jail deaths.
