The panelists will offer concrete recommendations for obtaining records and story ideas worth investigating in attendees' own communities.

speakers.bio: Fola Akinnibi is a reporter with Bloomberg CityLab.

Laura Bennett is the founder of The Center for Just Journalism, an organization dedicated to fostering a media environment that equips people with the information they need to build safer communities. CJJ connects journalists with reliable information on critical public safety and criminal legal issues and helps reporters, editors and educators identify and implement practice changes that foster rigor, curiosity and nuance, rather than sensationalism and anecdotes.
Ethan Corey is the research and projects editor at The Appeal, where he also serves as interim managing editor.

Paige Pfleger is the criminal justice reporter at WPLN news in Nashville, where she has investigated gun dispossession, domestic violence and juvenile justice as a fellow with ProPublica’s Local Reporting Network. Her work was a finalist for a Livingston Award and an Investigative Reporters and Editors Award, and she has appeared nationally on NPR, The Washington Post, Marketplace and more.

session_title: Show & Tell: Photographers and editors: Show your best visuals
description:
Sign up to “Show & Tell” us about your best work and get constructive feedback from the moderator and audience. 

Sign-ups are required for presenters. Each presenter will have 15 minutes to share their work and receive feedback. All are welcome to attend!

Sign up here: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/10C084CA8AC29A4FBCE9-57103793-show

*These sessions will not be recorded.

speakers.bio: Leah is the executive producer of investigations and special projects for WSB-TV in Atlanta. She has worked in the consumer space for more than a decade. Her work highlighting Social Security overpayment issues with Justin Gray along with other investigative teams from Cox Media Group earned her multiple awards including a 2024 Goldsmith. She is passionate about solutions-based journalism giving people a platform to share their stories to educate others.

session_title: Somehow I manage: A conversation about making the leap from reporting to editing
description: You wondered what they did all day. You swore you'd never do it. Then, a crazy thought occurred: What if you became an editor? We'll have a conversation with investigative and data editors who made the transition from reporting in the last few years. They'll discuss why they went to the dark side, what they love about it (the red lightsabers), how they feel about managing reporters, what surprised them, whether they'd go back to reporting and — the million dollar question — if they ever miss writing. This panel is best suited for reporters and other journalists who are curious about one day moving into management, as well as new-ish editors who want to talk shop.
track: Beat reporting, "Equity - inclusion - accessibility", Gender & reproductive rights, Story ideas

speakers.bio: Ryan Gabrielson is the San Francisco Chronicle's investigative editor. He was previously a national reporter at ProPublica, where his stories exposed major flaws in forensic science evidence, nonprofits reaping enormous profits, and predatory auto lending practices. Gabrielson's work has received numerous national honors, including a Pulitzer Prize, two George Polk Awards, a Livingston Award for national reporting, and a pair of Sigma Delta Chi Awards.

Lisa Gartner is an editor at The Washington Post, where she leads the long-term investigations team. She has previously served as the investigative editor for the San Francisco Chronicle and as an investigative and enterprise reporter for the Philadelphia Inquirer and the Tampa Bay Times. She has been recognized with the Pulitzer Prize for Local Reporting and the George Polk Awards for Education and Justice reporting, among other honors.

Yoohyun Jung is the data editor at the Boston Globe, leading a team of computational journalists. She was previously the deputy data editor and data reporter at the San Francisco Chronicle. Jung began her career in Arizona as a cops reporter, then developed as a data journalist with the help of IRE and NICAR.

Kathleen McGrory is an editor for the New York Times’ Local Investigations Fellowship program. She was previously a reporter on ProPublica’s national staff. Before that, McGrory was an investigative editor and reporter at the Tampa Bay Times. There, she and a colleague won the 2021 Pulitzer Prize for local reporting and were finalists for the 2019 Pulitzer Prize for investigative reporting. She started her career at the Miami Herald.

session_title: The data sonification toolkit: Learn to make your data sing
description:
Data sonification, the practice of turning data into sound and music, is a creative method that can greatly enhance data journalism and improve audience connection. In a world where data visualization is heavily relied upon, sonification presents a perfect opportunity to make digital media more accessible and emotionally impactful.
In this workshop, you will learn how to transform your journalistic work with data-driven audio. Using the Data Sonification Toolkit as a guide, we will cover basic concepts, methods, tools, and customization processes of sonification. Following a demonstration, participants will have the opportunity to create their own sonification pieces. A selection of datasets and recipes will be provided. Participants are also welcome to experiment with their own dataset.

This session is good for anyone interested in audio and making data come alive. No coding experience required! Please bring a laptop for the hands-on portion.

speakers.affiliation: University of Michigan & Reynolds Journalism Institute
speakers.bio: Aura (Auralee) Walmer is a data scientist, artist, and information designer interested in the interplay of data, art, and audio. She is a research fellow with the Reynolds Journalism Institute, and has been developing The Data Sonification Toolkit, a resource website for learning about sonification. She intends to further develop this project through workshops that help journalists use sonification and have fun with data.

session_title: Uncovering hope in hard times: How to strengthen your investigation with a solutions mindset
description: Are solutions to the wrongdoings exposed in your investigations often an afterthought? We’ll talk about how reporting out potential solutions at the outset – and connecting early and often in creative ways with those most affected by the issues – will not only increase the odds your stories will prompt real change, but will connect you more deeply to sources with differing viewpoints. (Not easy to do in today's world.) And that's not all! We’ll also show you how this framing can help you build bridges to audiences you’ve struggled to reach.

speakers.bio: Ashley is an engagement reporter at ProPublica. She started my career in local television news at NBC in Washington, D.C. After leaving NBC, she became an audience engagement editor at the Center for Public Integrity.

John Diedrich is an investigative reporter at the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel. Through the O’Brien Fellowship at Marquette University, Diedrich examined gun deaths in Wisconsin, focusing on solutions with gun owners and showing that accidental shootings are not charged uniformly. Earlier work revealed an electrical fire risk to renters and dangers in factories and hospitals. He was a Pulitzer Prize finalist in Public Service and won a George Polk award, among others.

speakers.affiliation: USC Annenberg Center for Health Journalism
speakers.bio: Michelle Levander founded the USC Center for Health Journalism in 2004 and has built its work on collaboration, investigations, and engagement. Journalists have published over 4,200 articles with the Center, receiving top honors, influencing laws, and driving policy change across the nation. A veteran reporter and editor, Levander has honors from the Overseas Press Club of America, the InterAmerican Press Association, SPJ LA, and NorCal Emmys. A former InterAmerican Press Association Fellow in Mexico, she holds a master’s degree in journalism from Columbia University.

Christiaan is the founder and executive editor of The Current. His work has appeared in The New York Times, NPR, Gambit, Offbeat, 64 Parishes, USA Today Network and The Advocate. He is a member of the Institute for Nonprofit News’ Emerging Leaders Council.

Raquel Rutledge is investigations editor at The Examination, a nonprofit startup focusing on global health investigations. As a longtime investigative reporter (formerly of The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel), she has received the nation's highest honors in journalism, including the Pulitzer Prize for Local Reporting. Her investigations have not only informed the public but also led to reforms at local, national, and international levels.

session_title: Using open source tools to localize national data
description: There are a number of national newsrooms and industry organizations that are designing products to support journalists who want to localize various datasets for maximum accountability and community impact. We will gather a few leaders in this space to demo the products they’ve created for local journalists, which include embeddable data graphics, help and research desks, record crowdsourcing and archiving projects, and more.

speakers.bio: Nicole Lewis is the engagement editor for The Marshall Project. She rejoined TMP after serving as a senior editor of Slate's Jurisprudence section in 2022. She is the lead reporter on a first-of-its-kind political survey of the incarcerated, which received an honorable mention in 2020 from IRE's Philip Meyer Award for the project’s pioneering use of social science research methods. Nicole is based in Brooklyn, New York.

Aaron Mendelson is the news developer for The Trace’s Gun Violence Data Hub. Previously, he was an investigative and data journalist at the Center for Public Integrity and at Los Angeles NPR affiliate KPCC/LAist. His work has spanned beats and formats and has been recognized with an IRE Award.

speakers.affiliation: Big Local News at Stanford University
speakers.bio: Cheryl Phillips teaches data and investigative journalism at Stanford and co-directs Big Local News, a data-sharing collaborative. A former journalist at The Seattle Times and other outlets, she has contributed to Pulitzer-winning and finalist work, including two for breaking news. Most recently, she worked on an overdose investigation with The Baltimore Banner and The New York Times that won a George Polk Award and a Pulitzer Prize. She is a former IRE board president.

Samantha Sunne is a freelance journalist based in New Orleans and the Interim Editor at MuckRock. She has received several national grants and awards for investigative reporting and teaches at conferences, universities, and newsrooms around the world. Her first book, co-authored with trainer Mike Reilley, “Data + Journalism: A Story-Driven Approach to Learning Data Reporting,” is used in journalism classrooms around the country.

session_title: Audio track: Bringing data and public records to life in audio
description: The data that journalists work with is often messy, and they rarely provide us with clear-cut or sweeping conclusions. How can we bring complicated numbers, especially in finance and science, to the listeners in a way that makes sense? How can we unearth public recordings that are often never heard? Panelists will share their strategies for breaking down complex concepts, finding the human stories behind the data, and crafting compelling audio narratives with public records.
track: Reporting and writing strategies, Data analysis

speakers.bio: Jess Clark covers education for the Kentucky Center for Investigative Reporting. Jess has reported on K-12 education for public radio audiences for the past 10 years.

Huo Jingnan is a reporter curious about how people navigate information landscapes and all the actors shaping that journey. Previously, she was an associate producer on NPR's Investigations team. The projects she was a part of have won awards including Edward Murrow Award, The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine's Communications award, Silver Gavel Award, and have also been nominated for Emmy Awards and George Foster Peabody awards.

Sukey Lewis is a criminal correspondent and host of On Our Watch, a podcast from KQED about the shadow world of law enforcement accountability. In 2018, she co-founded the California Reporting Project, a coalition of newsrooms across the state focused on obtaining previously sealed internal affairs records. Sukey has also investigated the bail bonds industry, California's wildfires and the high cost of jail phone calls.

Halle Parker covers public health inequities and environmental health for the news nonprofit Verite News in New Orleans. Before Verite, she covered environmental issues in Louisiana — with a special focus on environmental justice — for WWNO, the Times- Picayune / New Orleans Advocate and the Houma Courier. She also helped start, produce, host and report the podcast "Sea Change." Her work has appeared on Up First, Morning Edition and All Things Considered.

session_title: Broadcast track: From boring to blockbuster: Tricks and tools to up your visual game
description: In this panel, learn about how to make the non-visual story come to life for TV: color grading, editing, After Effects, framing interviews, etc.

speakers.bio: With over 20 years of producing, shooting, and editing award-winning investigations, Anna is now focusing on building a new consumer investigation brand in Denver with Steve On Your Side. When not advocating for Colorado consumers, you will find her in the aisles of King Soopers, vigilantly cross-checking the shelf price versus the charge at the checkout.

session_title: Covering serial murder, cold cases and missing and unidentified persons
description: Writing about unsolved and complex cases involving missing and murdered people and their killers presents unique challenges. Learn how to use the latest OSINT techniques, obscure archives and intense interviews to dive into these tough stories in the United States - and Mexico.
track: Beat reporting, Criminal legal system, Reporting and writing strategies

speakers.bio: Peter Barth is an investigator at Bellingcat whose work focuses on organized crime.

Rocío Gallegos is a journalist in Ciudad Juárez. Co-founder and editorial director of La Verdad Juárez, an investigative journalism site, and co-founder of the Juárez Journalists Network. She worked as a reporter, editor, and information coordinator during the two periods that have most marked Ciudad Juárez: the homicides of women and the violence of 'the war' against drug trafficking.

Lise Olsen is an investigative reporter, editor and author whose latest book is The Scientist and the Serial Killer: The Search for Houston's Lost Boys (Random House 2025). Her first book, Code of Silence, won the IRE Book Award in 2022. She is a former IRE board member and, from 1996 to 1998, directed the IRE Mexico Project.

session_title: Deep dive: Cultivating sources
description: When it comes to developing and maintaining sources—an intimate, demanding, all-consuming process—two of the best are Olivia Carville and Corey Johnson, reporters who know how to get inside major companies and government agencies, or schools, prisons and churches. They’ll talk about how their backgrounds have helped guide them in cultivating sources with compassion; the art of the cold call; taking care with victims of trauma; building trust; keeping sources on-side; and the good that can come from leaning into your humanity.

speakers.bio: Olivia Carville is an investigative reporter for Bloomberg. Her work has influenced legislation and exposed corporate wrongdoing in New Zealand, Canada, and the United States. A winner of the 2024 Polk Award, Olivia was twice named Global Business Journalist of the Year by the Women's Economic Roundtable. She is also an adjunct professor of Columbia Journalism School and serves as president of the New York Financial Writers' Association.

Corey Johnson is an investigative reporter on ProPublica’s national team. For nearly two decades, he has specialized in public service journalism and overcoming excessive secrecy. His accomplishments include the Pulitzer Prize for Investigative Reporting, the George Polk Award, two IRE Gold Medals, and his work has triggered government reforms, criminal investigations, a reparations program and the creation of a new law.

session_title: Finding a needle in a haystack: How to manage document-heavy investigations
description:
Searching for relevant evidence for a story through a never-ending pile of documents, legal forms, contracts, emails, videos, or cell phone data can be taxing and time-consuming, even for the best investigative teams out there. 

The team at Everlaw will demonstrate their tools to help with automatic transcription of audio and video (think bodycam footage, depositions, interview recordings), making documents text-searchable through optical character recognition, file management tools (like search, labeling, AI summaries), analysis tools (like data viz and topic clustering), and story-building tools (drafting, citations, and AI writing assistance). They'll show how newsrooms like the San Francisco Chronicle, ProPublica and Fast Company uncover key information using their tool.

You'll also learn about Everlaw’s free offering for journalists, which includes unlimited users, training and support at no extra cost.
track: Reporting and writing strategies, Public records

speakers.bio: Andrei Baiu is Everlaw’s Senior Customer Support Specialist and senior technical expert. Having worked on the Everlaw platform since 2022, Andrei brings a wealth of experience in product, artificial intelligence, and user applications of the tool.

Chris Miles is a senior media and tech adviser, working with Everlaw to scale the company’s work with journalists. Chris began his career as a reporter and has spent nearly a decade developing tools for journalists worldwide, including as a founding member of the original CrowdTangle team.

Joanne Sprague is the Director of Everlaw for Good, leading the company’s global work with journalists, publishers and non-profit organizations. Joanne has spent over two decades in the non-profit and tech for social impact space, and has worked to scale the Everlaw for Good program since 2023.

session_title: Free, easy data viz
description:
Need a chart, map or other visualization to make your work stand out? Come learn how to quickly create an attractive, effective data visualization using free tools. By the end of the session, you'll have a good idea of some of the tools available for data visualization, their strengths and weaknesses, and how difficult it might be to get started with each. 

This session is good for beginners. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

speakers.bio: Aaron Mendelson is the news developer for The Trace’s Gun Violence Data Hub. Previously, he was an investigative and data journalist at the Center for Public Integrity and at Los Angeles NPR affiliate KPCC/LAist. His work has spanned beats and formats and has been recognized with an IRE Award.

session_title: Geospatial analysis in R
description:
Learn how to use spatial functions in R to level up your reporting. We’ll explore tools for mapping, spatial joins, buffering and calculating distance — all using a single package. We’ll center a story published by The Baltimore Banner on gun violence around schools to showcase an application of these functions and demonstrate best practices for basic geospatial analysis.

This session is good for beginner and intermediate journalists with some familiarity with R. Laptops will be provided.

speakers.bio: Ryan Little is the data editor at The Baltimore Banner, a nonprofit newsroom covering Maryland. He leads a team of data reporters whose in-depth, data-driven investigations include its Pulitzer Prize-winning overdose series. His work analyzing data and scraping the web has won multiple national awards and prompted a Department of Justice inquiry. Little is a dedicated mentor to aspiring data journalists and frequently speaks on data’s role in uncovering vital stories.

session_title: Investigating Trump
description: On this panel, journalists will discuss how to investigate Trump in such turbulent times, where the administration and even the public seem so adversarial to their job. Learn how to investigate the current administration in your city or town.
track: Beat reporting, Attacks on the press, Reporting and writing strategies

speakers.bio: Hannah Allam is a DC-based ProPublica reporter covering national security, with an emphasis on counterterrorism and militant movements. She joined ProPublica from The Washington Post, where she was part of two Pulitzer Prize-winning teams. She also spent a decade as a foreign correspondent for McClatchy, leading bureaus in Baghdad during the Iraq War and in Cairo during the Arab Spring. Her war coverage was honored by the Overseas Press Club and the George Polk Awards.

session_title: Investigating hunger
description: Food insecurity in the U.S. is at the highest level in a decade with nearly 14% of households - 47 million people -- struggling to put meals on the table. Nearly 300 million face hunger crises worldwide. This panel will offer ideas, sources, tools and techniques for investigating the political, corporate and climate forces that are driving up hunger locally and globally.

speakers.bio: Ayurella Horn-Muller is a staff food and agriculture writer at Grist and the author of "Devoured: The Extraordinary Story of Kudzu, the Vine That Ate the South." Prior to that, she reported for Axios and Climate Central. Her work can also be found in CNN, National Geographic, El País, the Associated Press, The Atlantic, Mother Jones, The Guardian and WIRED. She has received awards from the Society of Professional Journalists and the Green Eyeshade Awards.
Murphy is a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter on ProPublica’s national desk, where he writes about the government, companies and power. He also co-founded the “Local Matters” newsletter.

Deborah Nelson is a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and former IRE president on faculty at the University of Maryland, home of the Howard Center for Investigative Journalism. Most recently, she has co-authored Reuters series on the environmental drivers of disease and on the global hunger-relief crisis.

Thin Lei Win is an award-winning multimedia journalist specialising in food and climate issues. She is lead reporter for the Food Systems Newsroom of Lighthouse Reports, a nonprofit collaborative news outlet focusing on public interest investigations, curates her own newsletter Thin Ink, and also writes for various international media. She previously worked as an international correspondent for the Thomson Reuters Foundation, the nonprofit arm of Thomson Reuters.

session_title: Real estate investigations: Covering the government, private sector and private equity sectors
description: Learn how public records and data about real estate can fuel your investigations of companies and agencies operating in the home mortgage and commercial property spaces. From foreclosures and contracts to federal programs covering veterans, to private equity transactions that can compromise public services, we’ll decode the jargon, documents and data available for real estate investigations.

speakers.bio: Gordon Russell is deputy editor of The Boston Globe's Spotlight Team. Before moving to Boston in 2024, he served as managing editor of investigations for The Times-Picayune and The Advocate, where he worked for 25 years.

Caitlin Thompson is an investigative reporter at Honolulu Civil Beat in Hawaiʻi where she covers everything from ocean safety to the courts. Previously, she was on the investigations team at NPR where her reporting on a real estate company offering sale-leaseback deals to cash-strapped homeowners sparked a Senate investigation, contributed to the closure of the company and won the Barlett & Steele Outstanding Young Journalist Award.

session_title: Show & Tell: Breaking news investigations on deadline
description:
Sign up to “Show & Tell” us about your best work and get constructive feedback from the moderator and audience. 

Sign-ups are required for presenters. Each presenter will have 15 minutes to share their work and receive feedback. All are welcome to attend!

Sign up here: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/10C084CA8AC29A4FBCE9-57103906-show

*These sessions will not be recorded.

speakers.bio: Mahsa Saeidi is a veteran investigative reporter, licensed attorney and four-time Emmy Award-winning journalist. She joined the investigative unit at CBS News New York in March 2024.

session_title: Using LinkedIn to find your next job
description: LinkedIn is considered the professional social networking site with over 100 million users in the U.S. alone with global reach. Many recruiters use LinkedIn as part of their candidate search especially with the chaos of social media platforms being less used among journalists disturbed by their owners currying favor with the current presidential adminstration. As a professional or student, it's the popular place to network and look for job opportunities and had a bit of a glow up so perhaps your profile should too

speakers.bio: Matt worked in TV news for over 20 years before transitioning into recruiting—currently, Talent Acquisition News Leader for E.W. Scripps.

Benét J. Wilson is the lead credit cards writer for Bankrate. She was previously director of the Poynter-Koch Media and Journalism Fellowship. Before that, she was a senior editor and writer for The Points Guy. She serves on the boards of Mercer University’s Center for Collaborative Journalism and the Institute for Independent Journalism. She graduated from American University in Washington, D.C., with a B.A. in broadcast journalism and resides in Baltimore, MD.

session_title: 60 opioid settlement (and other public health) stories in 60 minutes!
description: This fast-paced, interactive session will share 30 opioid settlement story ideas and  30 public health reporting angles on other overlooked and urgent issues. You’ll get practical tips on covering high-volume medical marijuana doctors, controversial incarceration programs, and the human toll of the Trump administration’s funding cuts. Whether on a daily deadline or digging into a months-long investigation, you’ll leave with fresh ideas and tools to go deeper.

speakers.bio: Drew Hawkins is the public health reporter for the Gulf States Newsroom, a collaboration among public radio stations in Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and NPR. He covers stories related to health care access and outcomes across the region, with a focus on the social factors that drive disparities.

Ed Mahon reports on addiction treatment, the opioid epidemic, medical marijuana, and other public health issues for Spotlight PA. His reporting has earned national recognition, including a 2018 finalist slot for the Livingston Awards for Young Journalists and a 2021 investigative award from the Institute for Nonprofit News. He serves as president of the Pennsylvania Legislative Correspondents' Association, representing journalists reporting from the state Capitol.

Aneri Pattani is a senior correspondent at KFF Health News, covering mental health and substance use. Her multi-year series tracking opioid settlement funds made her a finalist for the Livingston Award and was featured on Last Week Tonight with John Oliver. Her audio stories have been heard on NPR and Science Friday. Pattani received a bachelors in journalism from Northeastern University and a masters in public health from Johns Hopkins University.

session_title: Broadcast track: Sourcing in this new "no comment" world
description: Can't get anyone to talk to you on the record? Reaching out for accountability interviews and getting "no comment"...or worse, no response at all? We'll discuss creative ways to make sure your reporting is well-rounded, even if you can't get people to talk to you on camera.

speakers.bio: Daniela Molina is an award-winning national investigative producer with InvestigateTV. Over the last couple of years, Molina has worked on consumer investigations and other hard-hitting topics, such as military medical malpractice. She is also the host of a Spanish financial segment called Cuidando su billetera.

Dannah Sauer is an award-winning investigative producer based in New Orleans. She has worked to expose public corruption, misbehaving police officers, racial disparities, and injustices faced by exonerated persons. Dannah’s work has launched local and federal investigations, which have resulted in policy changes.

session_title: Covering corporate behavior: What they do (not what they say) and their big plans for the future
description: Companies are great spinning stories that present themselves as heroes. But behind the scenes, their behavior often fails to mirror that reality. Learn how to scour company behavior (on deadline!) using the Violation Tracker database to explore the backgrounds of companies across 450 federal, state, and local regulatory agencies (including EPA, OSHA, state attorneys general offices, etc). And beyond the regulatory landscape — in many agencies rapidly degrading under the new administration – learn how sources and other records can help expose misconduct. Also get info on the states' version of Project 2025, being pushed by the American Legislative Exchange Council (ALEC). Similar to the national Project 2025, the states-level version seeks to, among other things, empower fossil fuel companies, undermine public education, repress voting rights, and more. Journalists are great at exposing the misbehavior of elected officials – walk away with tips on applying that same sharp scrutiny to company leaders. This session is sponsored by Bloomberg. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

speakers.bio: David Armiak is research director and an investigative journalist with the Center for Media and Democracy. David joined CMD in 2015, has conducted extensive investigations on dark money, corporate corruption, and right-wing networks, and is responsible for filing and analyzing hundreds of public records requests every year.

Arlene Martínez joined Good Jobs First, a nonprofit corporate and government watchdog, in 2020. Before joining GJF, (which maintains the Subsidy, Violation, and Tax Break Tracker databases), she was a reporter with the USA TODAY Network/Ventura County Star, The Morning Call, the LA Times and Hispanic Link News Service, where her work focused on the choices people in power make when it comes to who and what gets prioritized.

Nadine Sebai is an award-winning investigative reporter whose work has appeared on The Public’s Radio and PBS Frontline. She co-reported Underage and Unprotected, a national investigation into migrant teens working in U.S. seafood processing facilities. Nadine is currently directing a documentary about her own medical condition, using her investigative lens to explore the medical system’s handling of misunderstood neurological disorders.

session_title: Freelancers: Create entrepreneurship systems that work for you
description: With mass layoffs and an unstable job market, more journalists are freelancing, out of need or by choice – and many are creating their own newsletters or startup businesses. This session will cover how to create systems that take work off your plate! You’ll see a demo of the Institute for Independent Journalists’ interactive online freelance startup guide, which helps answer the key questions for ramping up a side hustle into a full-time business. Panelists will share tools for setting your rate, networking to find great assignments, building relationships with clients, and juggling multiple projects. Participants will leave the session with a slew of new tools and strategies for becoming an emotionally and financially sustainable freelancer.

speakers.bio: Ann Marie Awad is the editorial director for the Institute for Independent Journalists and a freelance audio journalist based in Denver, Colorado. Awad created and hosted the award-winning podcast "On Something," and they sit on the board of directors for the Association of Independents in Radio. They have produced podcasts for Audible, WAMU, and Sonos, among others.

session_title: Investigating border surveillance and deportation flights with open-source tools
description:
Border surveillance and deportation flights lack transparency by design, yet their movements often leave visible traces. This session will introduce participants to the field of open-source flight tracking, focusing on how to monitor and analyze aircraft through case studies on deportation flights and border surveillance missions.

Designed for beginners but with room for advanced workflows, the session will walk through the basics of identifying aircraft, reading ADS-B data, and using free tools like ADS-B Exchange and adsb.lol. You’ll learn how to match flight tracks to known deportation routes, identify suspicious flight patterns, and archive tracking data.

The session will also touch on more advanced techniques, including how to automate tracking of known aircraft over time and visualize flight paths across months or years.

No prior technical experience required. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets).

speakers.bio: Jack Sapoch is an open source investigative journalist at Lighthouse Reports, where he works on cross-border investigations into migration, border enforcement, and state violence. He combines remote sensing, digital forensics, and 3D modeling to reconstruct incidents and expose hidden systems of control. His work has contributed to investigations which have been recognized with honors including the IRE Award, the Sigma Award, and the One World Media award.

session_title: Networking: Radio and audio journalists
description: For audio journalists and those aspiring to do investigative audio/radio/podcast journalism. Meet others who are audio-focused and audio-interested, including award-winners, program and podcast producers, print-to-audio converts, audio track panelists, and others enamored with audio storytelling. Engage in conversations with their own driveway moments. An informal gathering with an opportunity to make connections.

speakers.bio: Howard Berkes spent 38 years as an NPR Correspondent with eight years on the NPR Investigations Team. He has earned more than 40 journalism awards for investigative, breaking news, sports, science, business, health and feature reporting. Howard was awarded a Harvard Nieman Fellowship in 1997. After retiring from NPR, he helped launch Public Health Watch, an investigative nonprofit newsroom focused on public, environmental & occupational health.

Kate Howard is an editorial director at the Center for Investigative Reporting, which produces Reveal and Mother Jones. Previously, she was managing editor at the Kentucky Center for Investigative Reporting, where her team was a Peabody Award finalist for the investigative podcast Dig. Howard was a local news reporter working in newspapers and radio for nearly 14 years. She is a board member for IRE and Louisville Public Media, and she's based in Louisville, Kentucky.

session_title: Open mic: How do we save investigative units during unprecedented cuts?
description:
This is one of five “Open Mic” sessions where you can listen to AND participate in a lively discussion about important issues facing our industry and impacting our daily work. All are welcome to attend!
*These sessions will not be recorded.

session_title: Responsibly and creatively reporting on children and teens
description: Reporting on sources under the age of 18 often requires deep sensitivity, advanced planning and inventive approaches to gathering records. From the child welfare and education systems to the sexual abuse of children by law enforcement to teens in residential treatment facilities and group homes, come learn from a panel of reporters about how to initially approach children and their families as sources; how to make kids feel comfortable in an interview setting; how to navigate issues of consent; how to obtain juvenile court records; where to mine for information on systems charged with caring for kids; and more.

speakers.bio: Jenn Abelson is an investigative reporter for the Washington Post and co-host of the investigative podcast, Broken Doors. She has spent more than a decade writing about exploited youth and co-authored a memoir with a teenager, "I Have the Right To: A High School Survivor's Story of Sexual Assault, Justice, and Hope."

Jessica Contrera reports in-depth stories about systemic issues and the people impacted by them. She is a part of The Post's narrative accountability team. With Jenn Abelson, John Harden and a team of Post journalists, she reported "Abused by the Badge," a series exposing how hundreds of U.S. police officers have sexually abused children while officials have failed to take basic steps to stop predatory cops.

Bennett Haeberle is an investigative reporter with NBC Chicago, WMAQ-TV. He has 22 years of experience as a reporter - including more than a decade in an investigative journalism. He's been an IRE member since 2014. His work has been honored with multiple awards including National Headliners Awards, 13 regional Emmys and Murrows. His investigations cover a broad array of topics from government policies; to acts of injustice and stories that impact vulnerable populations.

Eli Hager is a reporter for ProPublica who covers social safety net programs and issues affecting lower-income families and children. He was a Pulitzer Prize finalist in 2022 for his investigation of foster care agencies in Alaska and elsewhere that pocket the Social Security benefits of orphaned and disabled children. Previously, he was a staff writer for The Marshall Project.

session_title: There’s a disability angle on your beat
description: Get real-world examples of reporting that centers the people with disabilities, rather than writing and reporting around them. This session will be packed with tips and insights to help journalists across beats bolster their coverage of disability-related issues and elevate the voices and needs of this key segment of our communities.

speakers.affiliation: UC Berkeley Graduate School of Journalism
speakers.bio: Jennifer LaFleur teaches data journalism at UC Berkeley’s Graduate School of Journalism. She was previously a senior editor at the Center for Public Integrity. She has also worked at American University, Reveal from the Center for Investigative Reporting, ProPublica and several newspapers. She is a former IRE training director and previously served on IRE’s board. She is a board member of the Fund for Investigative Journalism.

Amy Silverman is a journalist, teacher and author in her hometown, Phoenix. She's executive producer of KJZZ-NPR's The Show and a columnist for PHOENIX magazine. Amy often focuses on intellectual disability and how to make journalism more accessible to and inclusive of people with ID – like her daughter, Sophie, who has Down syndrome. Amy's work has appeared on This American Life, ProPublica and Slate, among others. More at amy-silverman.com

session_title: Turn your questions into data with an LLM
description:
Learn how journalists at Bloomberg Industry Group used a large language model to turn questions into data as part of an investigation showing that voting rights claims dropped following a recent U.S. Supreme Court decision.

This session is good for people with some experience working with data. Laptops will be provided. You will also need to sign up for a ChatGPT account to participate in the hands-on exercise: https://openai.com/index/chatgpt/

speakers.bio: Diana Dombrowski is an investigative reporter for Bloomberg Industry Group based in New York. She worked in USA Today network newsrooms in Wisconsin and New York before joining in 2024.

Umar Farooq is an investigative data journalist at Bloomberg Industry Group. He was formerly a national reporting fellow at ProPublica, and a Foreign Correspondent for Reuters, Al Jazeera English, and the Los Angeles Times.

Gary Harki is the investigations editor for Bloomberg Industry Group. His 2020 investigation into the strip-searching of children by Virginia prisons led to the halt of the practice and numerous changes to state law. In 2019, he won the Al Nakkula Award, honoring outstanding police reporting for his series on jailing people with mental illness. Previous stops include Spotlight PA, The Virginian-Pilot, The O’Brien Fellowship at Marquette and The Charleston Gazette.

session_title: Using court records to break stories
description: PACER, the federal court records system, is antiquated and hard to navigate. Using skills developed over years, Seamus Hughes has helped the media break national stories about topics ranging from terrorism and public corruption to corporate espionage. Seamus Hughes is back to give us tips and suggestions on how to use PACER to tell a story.
track: Criminal legal system, Story ideas, Public records

speakers.bio: Seamus Hughes is the publisher of Court Watch. Hughes is also a New York Times research journalist working on many stories related to the federal court system. In 2022, he was a small part of a New York Times team that won a Pulitzer Prize for National Reporting on law enforcement in America. He also works with Bloomberg Law News for their investigative team. He previously worked as a research journalist with Rolling Stone and Daily Beast.

session_title: Vetting the great investigative idea

speakers.bio: Rose Ciotta is a Pulitzer Prize-winning investigative editor who co-edited a project on school violence for The Philadelphia Inquirer that was awarded the 2012 Gold Medal for Public Service. She's a senior investigations editor at the Atlanta Journal-Constitution. She founded Investigative Editing Corps, linking editors with local news organizations to do investigative reporting. She attended Stanford University as a JSK Fellow and is a former member of the IRE board.

Ron Nixon is Director of the Associated Press Local Investigative Reporting Program. Previously, he was AP’s Vice President for News and Head of Investigations, Enterprise, Partnerships, and Grants. He has overseen investigations that have won several awards, including the 2023 Pulitzer Prize for Public Service, a George Polk Award, three News and Documentary Emmys, a National Edward R. Murrow Award, and a George Foster Peabody Award, as well as several other honors.

session_title: What is the Data Liberation Project, and how do you use it?
description:
The Data Liberation Project is an initiative to identify, obtain, reformat, clean, document, publish, and disseminate government datasets of public interest. Come learn how you can get involved to save, archive, publish and share data!

No data experience is necessary! Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.
track: Tools & Tech, Data analysis, Data viz

speakers.bio: Maggie Dougherty is a freelance journalist and a master’s student at the Northwestern University Medill School of Journalism, where she is in the Medill Investigative Lab, working on stories about mental health and policing with MindSite News. She recently completed an internship with MuckRock through the Northwestern Media Law & Government Transparency Practicum. She currently covers local Illinois news in Springfield as a reporting fellow for Capitol News Illinois.

speakers.affiliation: Big Local News at Stanford University
speakers.bio: Cheryl Phillips teaches data and investigative journalism at Stanford and co-directs Big Local News, a data-sharing collaborative. A former journalist at The Seattle Times and other outlets, she has contributed to Pulitzer-winning and finalist work, including two for breaking news. Most recently, she worked on an overdose investigation with The Baltimore Banner and The New York Times that won a George Polk Award and a Pulitzer Prize. She is a former IRE board president.

Samantha Sunne is a freelance journalist based in New Orleans and the Interim Editor at MuckRock. She has received several national grants and awards for investigative reporting and teaches at conferences, universities, and newsrooms around the world. Her first book, co-authored with trainer Mike Reilley, “Data + Journalism: A Story-Driven Approach to Learning Data Reporting,” is used in journalism classrooms around the country.

session_title: Welcome reception
description:
Celebrate IRE’s 50th anniversary in style with new and old IRE friends at Generations Hall, an old sugar mill built in the 1820s, while listening to the sounds of a local DJ. There will be light bites and a cash bar, with two drink tickets for each person. This off-site venue is about a 20-minute walk from the hotel.

Ahead of time, don't miss the second line marching to the lobby starting at 6 p.m. The Welcome reception is sponsored by Bloomberg.

session_title: Mentor program breakfast (invitation-only event)
description: If you signed up for the conference mentor program, come meet your match at this invitation-only breakfast.

session_title: One-on-one coaching for audio journalists (Friday)
description: Audio journalists can sign up for a one-on-one coaching session at various times during the conference. Click here to sign up: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/10C084CA8AC29A4FBCE9-57105620-audio#/

session_title: Behind the story: "Tráileres, trampa para migrantes” (Cargo trucks: A trap for migrants)

speakers.affiliation: Latin American Center for Investigative Journalism (CLIP)
speakers.bio: Àngela Cantador is a journalist who graduated in Journalism and Humanities from Universitat Pompeu Fabra in Barcelona. She works at the Latin American Center for Investigative Journalism (CLIP) as a journalist and data coordinator. At CLIP, they uncover abuses of power in Latin America, focusing on migration, disinformation, environmental issues, and corruption through collaborative, cross-border investigations with local media and on-the-ground reporters.

Brenda Medina is a bilingual investigative reporter with the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ). Before joining ICIJ in 2021, she was a senior reporting fellow at ProPublica. She also reported for El Nuevo Herald and the Miami Herald, covering immigration, minorities, and public corruption. Brenda is from the Dominican Republic and immigrated to the United States in 2003.

Ronny Rojas is an investigative reporter for Noticias Telemundo and a professor at the Craig Newmark School of Journalism at CUNY. He has led cross-border collaborative projects with newsrooms in the U.S. and Latin America. His work has been recognized with multiple awards, including a National Emmy, NAHJ’s Al Newhart and University of Florida investigative journalism awards, the Ortega y Gasset Award, and the Robert F. Kennedy Journalism Award.

session_title: Bridging the newsroom and the classroom: Tackling big projects with student journalists
description: This session is sponsored by Scripps Howard Fund. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

speakers.affiliation: Howard Center for Investigative Journalism, University of Maryland
speakers.bio: Kathy Best has led the Howard Center for Investigative Journalism at the University for Maryland since 2019, helping students win an IRE medal and three IRE awards for best student investigations. This year, her students were named Pulitzer finalists in investigative journalism for their collaboration with AP and Frontline. She was previously executive editor of The Seattle Times and Missoulian in Missoula, MT, and a top editor at newsrooms in St. Louis and Baltimore.

speakers.affiliation: Howard Center for Investigative Journalism, University of Maryland
speakers.bio: Kathy Best has led the Howard Center for Investigative Journalism at the University for Maryland since 2019, helping students win an IRE medal and three IRE awards for best student investigations. This year, her students were named Pulitzer finalists in investigative journalism for their collaboration with AP and Frontline. She was previously executive editor of The Seattle Times and Missoulian in Missoula, MT, and a top editor at newsrooms in St. Louis and Baltimore.

Brant Houston is Knight Chair of Investigative Reporting at the University of Illinois. He served as the executive director of IRE for a decade. Before IRE, he was an investigative reporter at daily newspapers. He has co-authored “The Investigative Reporter’s Handbook” and authored “Computer-Assisted Reporting: A Practical Guide” and "Changing Models for Journalism: Reinventing the Newsroom." He is board chair for the Global Investigative Journalism Network.

Maggie Mulvihill is a veteran reporter, data journalism trainer, news entrepreneur, First Amendment advocate, and attorney. An Associate Professor of the Practice in Computational Journalism at Boston University, Mulvihill’s students have won numerous regional and national awards, including this year's IRE top student honor for a collaboration with The Howard Center for Investigative Journalism at the University of Maryland.

Brian Patrick O’Donoghue is a University of Alaska professor emeritus who has worked for weeklies coast to coast, covering politics, crime, sports in print on TV. He is the author of The Fairbanks Four: Murder, Injustice, and the Birth of a Movement.

session_title: Broadcast track: Consumer confidential
description:
Consumer investigations resonate and impact viewers from every walk of life. They are both far-reaching and relatable. It’s why now more than ever, newsrooms are investing in strong, thought-provoking, consumer-driven investigative stories.
In this panel, you’ll hear from experienced consumer investigative journalists and producers. We’ll explore the various ways you can make your consumer investigations impactful. From knowing when a story is a daily turn or a more involved investigation, to showcasing how the nation’s federal consumer protection agencies directly impact your community. We will also discuss how to incorporate solutions-based journalism in your reports and utilize consumer advisors to help make your investigations stronger.

speakers.bio: Leah is the executive producer of investigations and special projects for WSB-TV in Atlanta. She has worked in the consumer space for more than a decade. Her work highlighting Social Security overpayment issues with Justin Gray along with other investigative teams from Cox Media Group earned her multiple awards including a 2024 Goldsmith. She is passionate about solutions-based journalism giving people a platform to share their stories to educate others.

Justin is the Consumer Investigator for WSB-TV in Atlanta. His investigations have led to changes in state laws & federal rules. He’s won numerous awards including a Murrow, multiple Emmys & he was on the 1st broadcast team named a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize for Public Service. Gray was previously WSB’s DC Correspondent & also worked at WAGA-TV in Atlanta & stations in Philadelphia, CA & WV. He has a MS in Journalism from Columbia & a BA in History from Emory.

Caresse Jackman is an award-winning National Consumer Investigative Reporter at InvestigateTV-Gray Media. Before InvestigateTV, she was a consumer investigative reporter at WSMV in Nashville, Tennessee. She has prior reporting experience at WWL in New Orleans, WJRT in Flint, Michigan, and WCBI in Columbus, Mississippi.

session_title: Cleaning and extracting data: 30 tips in 60 minutes
description:
Let's put those documents to work for you! In this session we'll review need-to-know methods for getting the most out of your dirty datasets, regardless of whether you're working in Excel or knee-deep in Python.

This session is good for beginner and intermediate journalists with some familiarity with data spreadsheets. Laptops will be provided.

speakers.bio: Jonathan Soma is the Knight Chair in Data Journalism at Columbia Journalism School, where he directs both the Data Journalism Master of Science program and the summer intensive Lede Program. He regularly publishes tutorials on everything from basic Python and analysis to ai2html and machine learning. At the moment, he unfortunately cannot stop talking about AI, and in his free time, he runs a tiny cat rescue.

session_title: Covering the F.A.A.
description: Transportation is always a beat moving but the last year has seen an increase of high-profile crashes, delays and gutting of federal agencies with already shortstaffed departments in the aviation industry. Learn from those who have covered this topic soaring on our news feeds while raising serious questions about public safety and the integrity of the Federal Aviation Adminstration.

speakers.bio: Cary Aspinwall is an investigative reporter for The Marshall Project. She previously reported for The Dallas Morning News and is a co-founder of The Frontier. Her work has been recognized with a Gerald Loeb Award, as a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize in local reporting, and the National Magazine Awards for public interest.
Kate Kelly is an investigative reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times. She covers money, power and influence. She is an experienced broadcaster and the author of three books.

Peter Robison is an investigative journalist for Bloomberg News and author of the New York Times business bestseller Flying Blind: The 737 MAX Tragedy and the Fall of Boeing. He’s been part of teams recognized with prizes including a Gerald Loeb Award and the Overseas Press Club’s Malcolm Forbes award. A native of St. Paul, Minnesota, Robison has a history degree from Stanford University, and lives in Seattle, with his wife and two sons.

session_title: Disclosing AI: What audiences want and how newsrooms can respond
description: News consumers want transparency when journalists use artificial intelligence in reporting. Recent survey and interview data from Trusting News shows audiences not only expect AI disclosure but also prefer detailed explanations about how AI was used and which tools were involved. This research also showed audiences are particularly uneasy about AI’s role in data analysis. This session will explore how investigative journalists can meet audience expectations while maintaining trust and credibility. Trusting News will share best practices, newsroom-tested disclosure strategies, and real-world examples of AI transparency in investigative reporting. Attendees will leave with actionable insights on how to effectively communicate AI use, address audience concerns, and ensure human oversight remains central in AI-assisted investigations.

speakers.bio: Joy Mayer is the founder and executive director of Trusting News, a project that equips journalists to actively earn trust and helps journalists and the public understand each other. She and her team train newsrooms on strategies for demonstrating credibility and actively earning trust. She launched Trusting News in 2016 after a 20-year career in newsrooms and as a professor at the Missouri School of Journalism.

session_title: Document crowd competition: 40 ideas in 40 minutes
description: This session invites attendees to compete for prizes for offering the coolest, most unique public records that every journalist should request. Each person gets one minute to come up to the mic and explain their record. The idea will be entered into a list of the screen, and then at the end attendees vote for their favorite. The top three win fabulous IRE merchandise. The 2024 winners, among 37 ideas offered, were Twitter drafts, public official Spotify wraps, and U Visa certification denials.

speakers.affiliation: University of Florida / Brechner Freedom of Information Project
speakers.bio: David Cuillier directs the Brechner FOI Project at the University of Florida College of Journalism and Communications. He was a data journalist before earning his doctorate from Washington State University in 2006. He co-authored The Art of Access: Strategies for Acquiring Public Records, is former president of the National Freedom of Information Coalition and Society of Professional Journalists, and a member of the National Archivist's FOIA Advisory Committee.

Christina Jedra is an investigative reporter for Honolulu Civil Beat. She uses sourcing and public records to illuminate local issues, from building permit holdups to military contamination. In 2024, Christina and her Civil Beat colleagues were recognized as finalists for the Pulitzer Prize for their breaking news coverage of the deadly Maui wildfires. Christina previously worked for The News Journal in Delaware and The Capital in Annapolis, Maryland.

speakers.affiliation: University of Florida / Brechner Freedom of Information Project
speakers.bio: Sydney Sims is the Outreach Coordinator for the Brechner Freedom of Information Project at the University of Florida. She leads training, communications, and public education efforts to advance transparency. A former journalist, Sims reported for outlets including Capital B News, WABE, and the Columbus Ledger-Enquirer. Originally from Atlanta, she holds a degree in journalism from Auburn University and now resides in Gainesville, Florida.

session_title: Finding the story: Crime stats
description:
There’s a lot of data out there on policing and crime but so much of it is bad for a variety of reasons. In this session we’ll separate the good from the bad and discuss stories just waiting to be written in your community.

Basic knowledge of working with spreadsheets is helpful, but not required. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

speakers.bio: Jill Castellano is a data reporter for The Marshall Project. Jill has worked for ABC-owned television stations, The Salt Lake Tribune, The Desert Sun, inewsource and USA TODAY, earning a Pulitzer Prize for explanatory reporting in 2018 for her work on the deaths of undocumented border crossers. Jill was editor-in-chief of the University of Pennsylvania student newspaper, The Daily Pennsylvanian.

Maia Rosenfeld is a data journalist on the ABC News & Owned Stations Data Team. Based in Philadelphia, Maia wrangles data into scoops for local stations across the country. She reports national data-driven investigations for ABC News, collaborating with producers to find the people behind the numbers and share their stories. Maia specializes in finding creative ways to address data challenges. Before joining ABC she produced national investigations at Scripps’ DC Bureau.

session_title: Google Sheets 1: Getting started with spreadsheets
description:
In this introduction to spreadsheets, you'll begin analyzing data with Google Sheets, a simple but powerful tool. You'll learn how to enter data, navigate spreadsheets and conduct simple calculations like sum, average and median. 

This session is good for: Data beginners.

You must bring your own laptop (no tablets) to participate in this class, and you will need a free Google account to participate.

speakers.bio: Yoohyun Jung is the data editor at the Boston Globe, leading a team of computational journalists. She was previously the deputy data editor and data reporter at the San Francisco Chronicle. Jung began her career in Arizona as a cops reporter, then developed as a data journalist with the help of IRE and NICAR.

session_title: Income inequality:  A force that is tearing our communities apart
description: In your community, it’s likely that the wealthy are getting richer, leaving the rest of your community behind. Why? Mainly because laws that used to treat citizens equally now favor the rich. In every community we need to be showing how this Gilded Age threatens our nation. Our panelists have years of experience covering this important issue. They will tell you how to find these stories and how to report them out, with lists of story ideas, sources, how to get data and how to find experts who can propose solutions.

speakers.bio: Jeff Ernsthausen is a senior data reporter at ProPublica, where he was part of a team that produce The Secret IRS Files, a series based on the taxes of the wealthiest Americans. Prior to that, he was a data reporter on the investigative team at the Atlanta Journal-Constitution. He previously worked as an economic analyst for the Federal Reserve.

Mary Fricker is a business reporter who retired from The Santa Rosa (Calif.) Press Democrat. She freelances and publishes repowatch.org, which won SABEW’s Best in Business digital blog. Other awards: three IRE awards, McGill Medal for Journalistic Courage, UCLA Gerald Loeb Award, George Polk award, AP awards for business reporting. She co-authored the best-selling “Inside Job – The Looting of America’s Savings and Loans.” She graduated from the College of William & Mary.

Mary Sanchez is a syndicated columnist with Tribune Content Agency and a familiar face and voice in Kansas City media. Sanchez’s contributions include time as the senior reporter for Kansas City PBS and a metro columnist for The Kansas City Star; member of the Star’s editorial board, in addition to her years spent reporting on race, class, immigration, criminal justice and educational issues.

James B. Steele has received virtually every major national reporting award, including two Pulitzer Prizes,  two National Magazine awards and six IRE awards for his investigative reporting. He is the co-author with his longtime reporting partner, the late Donald L. Barlett, of nine books, including two New York Times bestsellers. Steele and Barlett worked together for more than four decades at The Philadelphia Inquirer, Time and Vanity Fair.

session_title: Master class: So you wanna make a podcast? - pre-registered attendees only
description: This workshop is designed for the audio-curious who feel like they don't know where to start. What staffing do you need? How much might it cost? How long might it take? How can you make something that people will actually hear? How do you approach storyboarding, getting comfortable with the gear, scripting, voicing/tracking, storytelling? We'll cover enough of the basics that attendees will feel equipped to pitch and begin developing their ideas.

speakers.affiliation: Futuro Media / Futuro Studios / Latino USA
speakers.bio: Fernanda Echavarri is an award-winning bilingual journalist. She’s a Senior Producer and Editor at Futuro Media, where she makes special podcast series and the weekly show Latino USA on NPR. She was previously at Mother Jones Magazine and Arizona Public Media. She began her journalism career in newspapers 15 years ago. Fernanda is the recipient of a Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights Award, a National Edward R. Murrow Award, a Regional Emmy, and was a Peabody Award finalist.

Alison MacAdam is a freelance story editor. Her work includes The 13th Step, a 2024 Pulitzer Prize finalist; NPR's Embedded ("Tested" and "Capital Gazette" series); 544 Days; and the Peabody Award-winning Believed. Current work includes the investigative podcast In the Dark. Alison was a 2014 Nieman Fellow. She spent 15 years at NPR, where she produced and edited All Things Considered. She later became NPR's Audio Storytelling Specialist, a system-wide training role.

Brendan McCarthy is Spotlight Editor at the Boston Globe. He oversees the newsroom’s investigative work as well as its data team. He has led projects that have been awarded a Pulitzer Prize, Peabody Award, Columbia-Dupont Award, and IRE honors. He previously served as founding editor of the Kentucky Center for Investigative Reporting and worked as a reporter at The Times-Picayune in New Orleans.

Kristin Nelson is Head of Audio at the Boston Globe, working with producers, editors and reporters to capture the Globe's award-winning journalism for audio audiences. She recently worked with others to launch the Globe’s investigative podcast, Spotlight: Snitch City. Before that she produced other award-winning investigative podcasts and documentaries for the Boston Globe and CBC National Radio and Podcasts.

session_title: One-on-one with Barry Nash & Co. (Friday)
description:
Barry Nash and his team return to IRE to provide personalized coaching sessions. If you have questions about any aspect of your delivery — your appearance, how you use your voice, how you can perform most effectively in the field or in the studio — this is an opportunity you won’t want to miss. Barry has been working with talent at all levels of experience and ability for over 30 years.

Please note: Participants should bring recent footage on a flash drive, webpage/online link, or storage drive (Google or Dropbox).

Click here to sign up: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/10C084CA8AC29A4FBCE9-57105395-barry#/

session_title: Open mic: What keeps us up at night: News Director forum
description:
This is one of five “Open Mic” sessions where you can listen to AND participate in a lively discussion about important issues facing our industry and impacting our daily work. All are welcome to attend!
*These sessions will not be recorded.

session_title: Reporting on the expanding “War on Terror”
description: The American-led "War on Terror" is in its third decade and expanding aggressively and in unexpected ways under the Trump administration. This defining set of domestic and foreign policies touches immigration, incarceration, schooling, higher education, and journalistic practice. This panel brings together journalists and academics who have recently published work about "War on Terror" policies and expansion, and who can talk about the history of this "war," where it's headed, whom it is likely to affect, and how journalists can hold those steering it to account.
track: 50th Anniversary, Beat reporting, Criminal legal system, Security, Story ideas

speakers.bio: Nausheen Husain is a writer and professor at Syracuse University. Her reporting and research investigate civil rights issues and incarceration, and the news coverage of these topics, particularly as they intersect with the ongoing "War on Terror." She is from Chicago.

Akela Lacy is a senior politics reporter at The Intercept and co-host of The Intercept Briefing podcast. She previously worked at POLITICO and the Pulitzer Center. She is pursuing a PhD in political science at the Graduate Center at the City University of New York.

Sanya Mansoor is a freelance journalist based in New York City. She covers immigration, the war on terror and the domestic fallout of American foreign policy. Sanya was a staff writer at TIME Magazine and has bylines in The Guardian, The Cut, The Intercept, The Associated Press, Acacia Magazine, The Center for Public Integrity, The Miami Herald, The Texas Tribune and the Dallas Morning News.

Tanvi Misra is a freelance writer and investigative journalist primarily covering migration and justice issues. Her work has appeared in The Guardian, The Nation, Politico Magazine, New York magazine, The Atlantic, The Baffler, The New Republic, Harper's Bazaar, the BBC, Bloomberg CityLab, High Country News, Teen Vogue, NPR, and other publications. She teaches at City University of New York's Craig Newmark School of Journalism.

Aly Panjwani is a researcher and campaigner based in New York City. He researches and writes about surveillance, policing, and corporate power. He’s produced investigative work on ICE’s reliance on surveillance technology, the Bureau of Prison's secretive Communication Management Units, as well as the history of the Department of Homeland Security and its growing, intimate relationships with corporations.

session_title: SOLD OUT -- Master class: Reporting and writing for scene (pre-registered attendees only)
description:
When it comes to crafting scenes, we can learn a lot from people who write fiction and screenplays. But our challenges begin long before the writing. Our scenes have to be true not just emotionally, but factually. This class will look at ways to gather dialogue, the telling detail and other threads that we can then weave into a scene people will remember (all, of course, without sacrificing the element of accountability — because, that’s what we do). We’ll dissect song lyrics; chat about creating dread; read a scene on the page, then watch it dramatized on screen. Plus, the fabulous Pam Colloff will drop in and talk shop.

Preregistration is required and seating is limited.

speakers.bio: Ken Armstrong is an editor and reporter on Bloomberg’s global I-team. He’s won Pulitzers for investigative and explanatory reporting and shared in two staff Pulitzers for breaking news. Other awards include a Peabody for radio and the National Magazine Award for feature writing. He co-wrote the story that became the Netflix series, “Unbelievable.” He was the McGraw Professor of Writing at Princeton and co-authored the book “Scoreboard, Baby,” winner of the Edgar Award.

Pamela Colloff is a reporter at ProPublica and a staff writer at The New York Times Magazine. Her reporting explores the criminal justice system in the United States, particularly the ways in which it falls short of delivering justice. She is a seven-time National Magazine Award nominee, winning for reporting in 2020 and feature writing in 2014. Her ProPublica-New York Times investigation, "False Witness," received the IRE Award in 2019.

session_title: Working with sensitive and hard-to-reach sources
description: A key question in almost every investigation is how to work with potential sources who have vital information – but are reluctant to share it. They may be victims of crimes, incarcerated people, members of marginalized groups, even possible whistleblowers with access to confidential material. How can you earn their trust? And how can you ensure that they are not retraumatized or harmed by helping you? This panel will equip you with the tools to connect with sources in a variety of vulnerable circumstances.

speakers.bio: Emily Hopkins is an Indianapolis-based data reporter at Mirror Indy, focusing on accountability. They've investigated a variety of topics and institutions, including failures at the Indianapolis Housing Agency, Chicago's automated traffic enforcement system, financial issues at utilities in Michigan and Indiana, state responses to sexual abuse at an Indiana youth residential facility, and quality of care at Indiana nursing homes.

Matloff has pioneered security training for journalists around the globe, helping hundreds survive an increasingly dangerous profession. She is the senior safety advisor of the Dart Center and teaches at Columbia’s Graduate School of Journalism. Matloff has covered conflict on several continents and contributes to leading outlets such as the NYT and Guardian. Her work has won support from the FIJ, MacArthur Foundation, Fulbright Program & Stanford's Hoover Institution.

Julie Small reports on criminal justice for KQED News in San Francisco. Small co-reported “On Our Watch: New Folsom” with host Sukey Lewis. The podcast investigated the deaths of two correctional officers who reported corruption and abuse within an elite unit at a high-security prison in California. The 8-part series won the 2024 I.R.E. award for Long Form Audio.

Alissa Zhu is a reporter for The Baltimore Banner. She shares a Pulitzer Prize for a Banner and New York Times Local Investigations Fellowship project examining how Baltimore became the overdose capital of the U.S. Previously she worked at the Clarion Ledger in Mississippi, where she wrote about fatal prison riots and historic immigration raids, and the Springfield News-Leader in her hometown in Missouri, where she reported on local government.

session_title: Bolstering local reporting through collaborations with large newsrooms
description:
The outlets represented on this panel all have initiatives designed to support local investigative news. This panel will discuss the different initiatives' aims, approaches, accomplishments, and adversities. Attendees will glean insights into project management techniques and get tips for creating effective, multi-newsroom collaborations. 

This session is sponsored by The New York Times. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

speakers.bio: Sarah Blustain is an assistant managing editor at ProPublica, where she runs the Local Reporting Network. This collaborative program supports local newsrooms in creating high-impact, award-winning investigative journalism. A lifelong editor, Blustain most recently worked with a diverse group of freelance reporters at Type Investigations. Embracing the spirit of collaboration in the field, she hasn't edited a non-partnership investigation since 2013.

Ryan Little is the data editor at The Baltimore Banner, a nonprofit newsroom covering Maryland. He leads a team of data reporters whose in-depth, data-driven investigations include its Pulitzer Prize-winning overdose series. His work analyzing data and scraping the web has won multiple national awards and prompted a Department of Justice inquiry. Little is a dedicated mentor to aspiring data journalists and frequently speaks on data’s role in uncovering vital stories.

Ron Nixon is Director of the Associated Press Local Investigative Reporting Program. Previously, he was AP’s Vice President for News and Head of Investigations, Enterprise, Partnerships, and Grants. He has overseen investigations that have won several awards, including the 2023 Pulitzer Prize for Public Service, a George Polk Award, three News and Documentary Emmys, a National Edward R. Murrow Award, and a George Foster Peabody Award, as well as several other honors.

speakers.affiliation: Big Local News at Stanford University
speakers.bio: Cheryl Phillips teaches data and investigative journalism at Stanford and co-directs Big Local News, a data-sharing collaborative. A former journalist at The Seattle Times and other outlets, she has contributed to Pulitzer-winning and finalist work, including two for breaking news. Most recently, she worked on an overdose investigation with The Baltimore Banner and The New York Times that won a George Polk Award and a Pulitzer Prize. She is a former IRE board president.

Adam Playford is an investigations and data editor at The New York Times who works with reporters across the country through The Times's Local Investigations Fellowship. He previously was an editor at The Upshot, oversaw investigations and data at The Tampa Bay Times, and was an investigative reporter for Newsday and The Palm Beach Post.

session_title: Broadcast track: Collaborating for survival and surviving your collaboration

speakers.bio: As Managing Editor of Investigative Content for Cox Media Group, Jodie manages national collaborations and investigations for eight local TV stations. She spent more than 20 years as an investigative reporter at WRC in Washington, WSB in Atlanta, and WFTV in Orlando. She’s earned some of journalism’s top honors, including an IRE Award, a duPont Award, a Goldsmith Special Citation and was a 2024 Pulitzer Prize finalist for Public Service. She has served on IRE’s Board of Directors since 2019.

Cindy Galli is formerly the executive producer of ABC News’ award-winning investigative unit, where she oversaw a team of reporters and producers specializing in government fraud, corporate corruption, racial injustice, consumer, and environmental issues. Cindy also built and oversaw a collaborative team that produced investigations with and across ABC’s owned stations and affiliates nationwide. Cindy currently serves on the IRE board of directors.

David Hammer is the chief investigative reporter for WWL Louisiana in New Orleans. He is a 6-time regional Emmy winner, a 2025 national News Emmy nominee and has won Murrow, SPJ and Environmental Journalism awards. Over 15 years as a print and wire reporter and 13 years on TV, Hammer’s investigations have helped to put criminals in prison, expose corruption and abuse of power, improve public safety and change inequitable laws.

John Hillkirk, senior enterprise editor at KFF Health News, was a reporter or editor at USA Today for 33 years before joining KFF in 2016. John’s KFF HN reporting team has won three Gerald Loeb Awards, a Goldsmith Prize, a Polk Award, the Sigma Delta Chi award for public service journalism, the Batten Medal from the News Leaders Association, a Murrow Award, two National Press Club awards, and two Pulitzer Prize finalists.

Kara Kenney is an investigative reporter with WRTV (ABC) in Indianapolis. Her investigations into government fraud and waste have resulted in several changes to Indiana state law, including increased accountability for how schools report bullying, as well as greater transparency in school superintendent contracts. Kenney's investigations have earned her an Edward R. Murrow award, as well as awards from the Emmys, SPJ, and the Associated Press.

Ramon Antonio Vargas is an award-winning journalist and award-winning author who has lived in the New Orleans area his whole life. He is a news desk editor at the Guardian and previously worked for The Times-Picayune and New Orleans Advocate. He has covered crime, politics, sports, general news and investigated the New Orleans Catholic archdiocese's ongoing clergy abuse scandal.

session_title: Covering courts: Free tools & strategies to access records and navigate trials
description: Legal reporting has never been more critical. Courts are treasure troves of information, but how do you access all those records and proceedings? We’ll explore free tools, techniques and strategies to overcome obstacles and get the story. You’ll learn how to track cases from afar, combine digital tools with courthouse shoe leather reporting, learn legal arguments and hear about coalition-building strategies you can use to gain access to filings and proceedings in person – even when you’re not welcome.
track: Public records, Beat reporting, Criminal legal system, Tools & Tech

speakers.bio: Jeremy Chase is a partner in the media group at Davis Wright Tremaine LLP in New York.  He is an experienced First Amendment and intellectual property litigator, and has led DWT legal teams in securing access to government records via FOIA and state open records statutes on behalf of various news and entertainment clients, and has led the charge on various access matters involving the prosecutions of Donald Trump, George Santos, Sam Bankman-Fried and others.

William Palin is an attorney and software developer focused on the intersection of law and technology. He currently serves as the Case Law Lead at the Free Law Project. Prior to joining FLP, William was the Access to Justice/Technology Fellow at Harvard Law School and, more recently, an adjunct professor at the University of Hawai‘i. In his role at FLP, he collected and built a database of judicial financial disclosures that helped expose judicial misconduct.
