Frank is a New York courts reporter for Law360. A daily correspondent most days, he has live-blogged the civil and criminal trials of Donald Trump and helped negotiate press access. Frank’s in-depth reporting has revealed judicial misconduct by New York's chief judge and alleged corporate bribery on the high court of Thailand. Before covering law, Frank dug into political corruption in Albany and freelanced investigations for The New York Times.

Emily Saul is a reporter with the New York Law Journal and ALM covering courts and white collar crime. She previously covered courts for the New York Post and worked as a staff reporter for a now-shuttered podcast company owned by Sony Music Entertainment.

session_title: Covering housing authoritatively: How to expose the unseen challenges of renters
description: One in three U.S. residents is a renter, and the proportion is even bigger among communities of color and low-income families. Yet, reporting on the challenges of these communities is often neglected or falls into the same tropes of landlords versus tenants. How can we continue to move forward through data to build investigations, even when it's difficult to find the right sources? During this conversation, panelists will discuss tools for building nuanced investigations that focus on government accountability. They will also talk about the importance of narrative storytelling and human-centered stories.
track: Beat reporting, Reporting and writing strategies

speakers.bio: Alejandra Cancino is a senior reporter at Injustice Watch, a Chicago-based nonprofit newsroom. Her investigations focus on the intersection of government and business, combining data with personal stories to expose systemic failures. Her reporting has been recognized with local and national awards. Cancino is an IRE board member and a former board member of SPJs’ Chicago Headline Club, where she co-created a rigorous training program for young journalists of color.

Juan Pablo Garnham is the Communication and Policy Engagement Manager for Eviction Lab, a housing research center based in Princeton University. Previously he worked with The Texas Tribune, El Diario in New York City, CityLab, Univision and several outlets in his home country of Chile. Among his areas of interest are housing, homelessness, immigration and urbanism. He lives in Portland, Oregon.

Cecilia Reyes is a bilingual reporter on Business Insider's investigations team. Previously, Reyes worked at the Chicago Tribune. Her work on the series, "The Failures Before the Fires," exposed how government officials in Chicago were warned about safety issues in dozens of homes before fires killed 61 people. This reporting was honored with a Pulitzer Prize for local reporting in 2022. Cecilia graduated from Columbia University and was born and raised in Mexico City.

session_title: Deep dive: Working as a team: Lessons from a rockstar reporting duo
description: Margie Mason and Robin McDowell have been reporting partners for 20 years, helping produce one epic investigation after another, including “Seafood from Slaves,” which led to numerous arrests, the seizure of ships and the freeing of more than 2,000 people. If journalism has a fledgling heir to Barlett and Steele, it could be Mason and McDowell. They’ll talk about what makes their partnership tick; how they regularly swap hats, even though one revels in the Indiana Jones stuff and the other in Robert Caro-level detail and documentation; and how, through it all, they have never once had a fight.

speakers.bio: Margie Mason and Robin McDowell are Pulitzer Prize-winning AP investigative reporters who worked together for nearly two decades in Southeast Asia. Their reporting exposed slavery in the seafood industry, resulting in more than 2,000 men being freed; labor abuses on palm oil plantations; and massive companies profiting from American prison labor. It has led to convictions, changes in U.S. laws, import bans, and the release of a Minnesota man from prison.

session_title: Finding the story: Using data to report on statehouses
description:
Whenever journalists are told to follow the money, we know that always means having a strong grasp on the data that is used to advocate for bills and the backdrop of who may be funding what. Come learn how to dig into the data out there with some hands-on exercises.

Basic knowledge of working with spreadsheets is helpful, but not required. Laptops will be provided.

speakers.bio: Marina Villeneuve is an investigative reporter for The Hechinger Report. She previously worked as a statehouse reporter for The Associated Press, as a legal reporter covering Trump's legal battles for Salon, and as an investigative producer at a Boston television station. She is a board member of IRE and the New England chapter of the National Association of Hispanic Journalists. She earned a certificate in data journalism from Columbia University's Lede Program.

session_title: Google Sheets 2: Formulas & sorting
description:
Much of Google Sheets' power comes in the form of formulas. In this class, you'll learn how to use them to analyze data with the eye of a journalist. Yes, math will be involved, but it's totally worth it! This class will show you how calculations like change, percent change, rates and ratios can beef up your reporting.

This session is good for: Anyone who has taken Google Sheets 1 or has been introduced to spreadsheets.

You must bring your own laptop (no tablets) to participate in this class, and you will need a free Google account to participate.

speakers.bio: Huangpu is a government reporter at Spotlight PA, a non-profit newsroom covering Pennsylvania state policy and politics. She tracks legislation and its impact on communities across the state. A graduate of the Columbia Journalism School’s data journalism program, Huangpu previously worked at ABC’s World News Tonight and MSNBC.

session_title: Heat, floods, cold and fire: Covering the intersection of climate change and incarceration
description:
Incarcerated people are among the most vulnerable to climate disasters. From extreme heat and cold to hurricanes and wildfires that force chaotic evacuations—or leave people trapped in harm’s way—the climate crisis is exacerbating what are already dire conditions behind bars.

This panel brings together investigative journalists and editors covering their work on the dangers facing people incarcerated, how climate policy often overlooks incarcerated populations, and the challenges of holding institutions accountable. The panelists will also offer practical guidance on how others can investigate these issues in their own communities—accessing public records, analyzing climate risk data, and centering the voices of incarcerated people and their families.

speakers.bio: Keri Blakinger is an investigative reporter at the Houston Chronicle and author of the memoir Corrections in Ink. Last year, she was a Pulitzer finalist for her story about the Dungeons & Dragons players of Texas Death Row. This year, she produced an Oscar-nominated short documentary, “I Am Ready Warden.” She’s also worked at the NY Daily News, The Marshall Project and the LA Times and is a 2025 New America Fellow.

Alleen Brown is a freelance investigative journalist. She's a senior editor at Drilled and publishes the newsletter Eco Files. Her work focuses on the intersection of environmental crises and criminalization. While a staffer at The Intercept, she published an award-winning investigation mapping over 6,500 prisons against heat, wildfire and flood risk. Recently, she reported and hosted the podcast series Slapp’d, about a pipeline company’s lawsuit to take down Greenpeace.

Hannah Riley Fernandez is a writer, communications expert, and advocate based in Atlanta. She works at the Center for Just Journalism, supporting journalists and newsrooms who do reporting on public safety issues.

Wyatt Stayner is the deputy editor at Prison Journalism Project, where he trains incarcerated journalists and helps get their work published. Before PJP, he worked at community newspapers in Indiana and Washington State. He started as a county government reporter, then moved to covering prep sports. During his last reporting job on the health beat, he covered a measles outbreak and the COVID-19 pandemic.

session_title: Methods and techniques to investigate oligarchs: Lessons learned from around the world
description: US journalists are suddenly confronted with kinds of power abuse that investigative reporters have long tackled around the world. In this session, international reporters and editors will share some of the tools and follow-the-money techniques that have exposed the tactics and held the unelected allies of autocrats accountable in different regions, the trickle-down corruption of oligarchy, and conflicts of interest.

speakers.bio: Emilia is the executive director of the Global Investigative Journalism Network (GIJN). She was formerly data and research editor at the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ), where she participated in more than 20 ICIJ award-winning investigative collaborations, including the Pulitzer-winning Panama Papers. She has been a professor at the Central University of Venezuela and a contributor for the Washington Post and Armando.info, which she co-founded. She was previously the investigative reporting coordinator at IPYS Venezuela.

Maria Georgieva is an award-winning investigative journalist and former Russia correspondent, reporting for Swedish and international media. Her work exposes the human cost of Russian security service repression, investigations in Chechnya and across Russia. She has interviewed Navalny and Kara-Murza, uncovered Putin’s spies in Scandinavia, investigated Kadyrov’s campaign against Chechen dissidents, and the Kremlin’s use of patriotic memory projects and propaganda abroad.

Patricia Marcano is an investigative journalist and editor from Venezuela. She is part of the editorial team at Armando.info (a Venezuelan media outlet), and her work includes covering corruption, money laundering, and human rights violations, as well as coordinating the newsroom and the Venezuelan chapter of the FinCEN Files and the Pandora Papers. She is currently a Fulbright Scholar pursuing a master's degree in journalism at Ohio University and an Alfred Friendly Press Partners Fellow.

Hoda Osman is a freelance investigative journalist and editor based in New York. She is Executive Editor at Arab Reporters for Investigative Journalism, where she oversees international projects. She worked on the Gaza Project, investigating attacks on journalists in Gaza, and is currently a co-producer on a PBS Frontline film about Syria. She previously worked with ABC, CBS, France24 and the Associated Press, and trains journalists worldwide in investigative reporting.

session_title: Networking: LGBTQ+ journalists
description: What better way to savor Pride month than to be among your community. Join us to mix, mingle and build community. This session is for people who identify as part of the LGBTQ+ community. This session is sponsored by Verite News. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

speakers.bio: Sharif Durhams is a managing editor at the Atlanta Journal-Constitution who is responsible for key newsroom teams, including local and state government, breaking news and investigations. He served as a newsroom leader at The Washington Post, CNN and The News & Observer in Raleigh, North Carolina. He is the former president of NLGJA: The Association of LGBTQ+ Journalists.

Lauren McGaughy is the investigative reporter and editor for The Texas Newsroom, a collaboration of NPR stations in Texas. Her specialty areas include criminal justice, government transparency and ethics, and LGBTQ issues. This year, she is covering Elon Musk’s effect on Texas as part of a collaboration with ProPublica. Before joining public radio, she worked for newspapers in Texas and Louisiana. Lauren loves cats, cemeteries and comic books. Ask about her wig collection!

session_title: Show & Tell: Students, MMJs and early-career journalists
description:
Sign up to “Show & Tell” us about your best work and get constructive feedback from the moderator and audience. 

Sign-ups are required for presenters. Each presenter will have 15 minutes to share their work and receive feedback. All are welcome to attend!

Sign up here: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/10C084CA8AC29A4FBCE9-57103645-show

*These sessions will not be recorded.

session_title: So you think you want to write a book?
description: Do you have an investigative project you'd like to turn into a book? Are you searching for book ideas and mystified by the world of agents and advances? These reporters-turned-authors share their best advice on developing and selling a book proposal, financing the reporting and writing (we promise brass tacks!), and exploring options like indie publishers, podcasts, and docuseries.

speakers.bio: Jennifer Berry Hawes writes about the South for ProPublica. Before that, she was an investigative reporter at The Post and Courier in Charleston, South Carolina, where she was part of a team that won the 2015 Pulitzer Prize for public service. She was also a finalist in feature writing in 2019. Her book about the Emanuel AME Church mass shooting, “Grace Will Lead Us Home,” was a New York Times notable book of 2019 and a finalist for the Dayton Literary Peace Prize.

The stories of Jerry Mitchell, who leads the investigative reporting team for Mississippi Today, have helped put four Klansmen and a serial killer behind bars. A two-time Pulitzer Prize finalist and a winner of over 30 national awards, including a $500,000 MacArthur “genius” grant, he is the author of “Race Against Time,” which tells how his reporting helped convict four Klansmen involved in killing NAACP leader Medgar Evers, four little girls and three civil rights workers.

Thompson is an award-winning investigative correspondent and senior editor for investigations for NPR. Before joining NPR in 2019, she spent 22 years covering law enforcement and political corruption for The Washington Post, and was part of teams that won the Pulitzer for National Reporting in 2002 and 2016. She was the reporting coach on the NPR podcast "No Compromise," which won the Pulitzer Prize for Audio Reporting in 2021.

session_title: Web scraping with Python
description:
If you need data that's trapped on a website, writing some code to scrape the page could be your solution. This entry-level class will show you how to use the Python programming language to harvest data from a website into a data file. We'll introduce you to the command line and show you how to write enough code to fetch and parse content on the web.

This class is programming for beginners. Some basic familiarity with Python and HTML is helpful but not required. You must bring your own laptop (no tablets) to this training, and you'll need a Google account.

speakers.bio: Janelle is an investigative reporter covering downstate Illinois for the Illinois Answers Project. She was previously a data reporter at the Center for Public Integrity and the St. Louis Post-Dispatch.

session_title: Beyond the investigation: Managing stress, safety & mental wellness
description:
Let’s be honest, investigative journalism can take a serious toll. Long hours, emotionally difficult topics, graphic content, public scrutiny, and even safety threats — both online and in person — can contribute to burnout, anxiety, depression, and PTSD. And for newsroom leaders, managers, and editors, the responsibility extends beyond just the stories, it includes caring for the people who report them. Join this candid conversation to learn more about practical strategies for managing stress, setting healthy boundaries, supporting team members, and building safer, more sustainable newsroom cultures.

NOTE: This session will not be recorded, so participants may engage freely (but respectfully) regarding personal situations.

speakers.affiliation: Investigative Project on Race and Equity
speakers.bio: Marissa Evans is the investigations editor with the Investigative Project on Race and Equity. Previously a health reporter at the Los Angeles Times, she covered race, healthcare, and entertainment. While at the Star Tribune, where her investigative work exposed how the state allowed private hospitals to seize tax refunds from individuals with unpaid medical bills, leading to legislative action in 2021 aimed at ending the policy.

Marla Jones Newman is the VP of People and Culture of Mother Jones/Reveal. She is an alumnus of the Maynard 200 Executive Leaders training program and the Executive Program for Nonprofit Leaders at Stanford University. Marla has over 20 years of HR experience employing best human capital practices to attract and retain talent. Throughout her career, she has created and implemented Diverse, Equitable, Inclusive, and Belonging initiatives.

Gonzalo Magaña is an award-winning journalist and director of special projects and audience engagement at ABC10, TEGNA’s ABC affiliate in Sacramento, California. He created the ABC10 Originals team, focused on long-form and investigative reporting, and launched the station’s Race and Culture content in 2021. With over 20 years of experience, including 12 in Spanish-language news, he's earned multiple duPont-Columbia, Murrow, and Emmy Awards, and two Peabody Award nominations.

Matloff has pioneered security training for journalists around the globe, helping hundreds survive an increasingly dangerous profession. She is the senior safety advisor of the Dart Center and teaches at Columbia’s Graduate School of Journalism. Matloff has covered conflict on several continents and contributes to leading outlets such as the NYT and Guardian. Her work has won support from the FIJ, MacArthur Foundation, Fulbright Program & Stanford's Hoover Institution.

Naseem Miller is senior health editor at The Journalist’s Resource, a project of the Shorenstein Center at Harvard Kennedy School. In addition to covering health, she writes about the intersection of journalism and trauma. She’s also part of Dart Center’s training team. Miller was part of the Orlando Sentinel team named a 2016 Pulitzer Prize finalist for coverage of the Pulse nightclub mass shooting. She co-started and administers the Journalists Covering Trauma Facebook group.

Zack Newman is a freelance investigative data journalist based in Denver. His award-winning pieces have been published by publications of all sizes in the United States and New Zealand. They include BusinessDesk, Denver Gazette, Colorado Public Radio, 9NEWS, MSNBC, and more. His work spurred changes in laws and policies, exposed a human trafficking ring, and inspired the ACLU to sue the Denver Police. Newman's accolades include a Murrow, a Sigma Delta Chi, and an Emmy.

session_title: Broadcast track: "I don't watch TV news" How to get your content in front of the next generation of viewers
description: We know you’ve been told, ‘we need to focus on our younger demos, they’re not watching tv.’  But they are watching news. We’ll prove it to you, give you solutions to stop wasting time and start getting in front of as many people as possible. We’ll (try to) absolve you of your guilt about ‘monetization’ and definitely discuss whether dancing anchor videos are good brand builders for investigative reporters. We guarantee there is something you haven’t heard in this hour, hopefully more than one thing! Come with questions.

speakers.bio: Ben Bradley is a 10-time Emmy Award-winning investigative reporter who has spent more than 25 years covering news in Chicago. He joined WGN-TV in January 2017 as an anchor and investigative reporter. Before WGN-TV, Bradley spent 14 years at WLS-TV, ABC7 in Chicago, as a reporter and weekend morning anchor. While reporting for WLS, he has traveled the globe on various stories, including trips to China, Brazil, the Caribbean, and nearly a dozen states.

Ashlyn Lipori-Russie is the creator and host of Ask Ashlyn, an SMS and social media-based solution to news avoidance that invites users to ask questions about the news, as if speaking with a journalist friend. Ashlyn is an Emmy-nominated journalist with a diverse background in broadcast and digital news, including the Investigative Unit at NBC Bay Area, ABC 10News, and inewsource in San Diego.

Ted is part of the I-Team at News4 NBCWashington. Three years ago, he moved to DC after 21 years in Houston. Feel free to ask him about it, moving three teenage daughters across the country, or about his work. Ted likes to talk.

session_title: Data analysis with Python
description:
In this session, you'll learn how to analyze data using the popular Python data analysis library pandas. You'll learn about the benefits of scripting your data projects and enough syntax to load, sort, filter and group a data set.

This class is good for: People who are comfortable working with data in spreadsheets or SQL and want to make the leap to programming. You must bring your own laptop (no tablets) to this training, and you'll need a Google account.

speakers.bio: Sandra Fish is a kinda retired data journalist who specializes in political reporting, most recently at The Colorado Sun, as well as for New Mexico In Depth and other publications. She was a journalism instructor at the University of Colorado Boulder for eight years.

session_title: Exemption redemption: How to overcome public records exemptions
description: This session provides practical tips for how to overcome the most common exemptions in public record laws, including attorney-client, deliberative process, privacy, trade secrets, investigatory, vague/unduly burdensome, and other legal barriers such as FERPA and HIPAA. Bring up others and stump the experts!

speakers.affiliation: University of Florida / Brechner Freedom of Information Project
speakers.bio: David Cuillier directs the Brechner FOI Project at the University of Florida College of Journalism and Communications. He was a data journalist before earning his doctorate from Washington State University in 2006. He co-authored The Art of Access: Strategies for Acquiring Public Records, is former president of the National Freedom of Information Coalition and Society of Professional Journalists, and a member of the National Archivist's FOIA Advisory Committee.

speakers.affiliation: Reporters Committee for Freedrom of the Press
speakers.bio: Gunita Singh is an attorney at Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press using FOIA and public records laws to get government documents for journalists and newsrooms. She has co-authored two publications on the effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on access to public records. She serves as board chair of LION Publishers.

Matt Topic runs the media and intellectual property practice at Loevy + Loevy. Matt and his team have litigated hundreds of state and federal open records cases.  Matt also represents several news publishers in copyright cases against OpenAI and Microsoft.

session_title: Finding the story: Climate data
description:
Climate change touches every community and every beat. In this class, you'll learn how to identify and analyze datasets that reveal the wide-ranging impacts of climate change in your region, from hurricanes and wildfires to flooding. You'll explore greenhouse gas inventories, enforcement records, and environmental justice scorecards to uncover compelling stories that matter to your newsroom. 

This session is good for peole with some familiarity with Excel. Laptops will be provided.

speakers.bio: Naveena Sadasivam is an investigative journalist at Grist who covers the oil and gas industry and climate change. She previously worked at the Texas Observer, Inside Climate News, and ProPublica and has won accolades from the Society of Environmental Journalists, Society of Professional Journalists, Online News Association, and Radio Television Digital News Association. She is based in Oakland, California.

session_title: Google Sheets 3: Filtering & pivot tables
description:
A look at the awesome power of pivot — and how to use it to analyze your dataset in minutes rather than hours. We'll work up to using a pivot table by first sorting and filtering a dataset, learning how to find story ideas along the way.

This session is good for: Anyone familiar with formulas, sorting and filtering in a spreadsheet program.

You must bring your own laptop (no tablets) to participate in this class, and you will need a free Google account to participate.

speakers.bio: Tiff Fehr is a staff engineer and project editor previously with The New York Times and nbcnews.com (née msnbc.com). She focuses on custom software development, in addition to data journalism projects, such as The Times's Covid-19 data collection and its public data set.

session_title: How to pivot from the newsroom: Reinventing yourself without losing your investigative edge
description: Burnout, layoffs, or a desire for new challenges can push investigative reporters to consider career pivots—but leaving the newsroom doesn’t mean leaving your skills behind. This session explores how to transform your expertise into new careers, from freelancing and book writing to producing documentaries.

speakers.bio: Elaine Aradillas has spent her career writing about crime. For 15 years, she worked at PEOPLE magazine as a senior writer and covered high-profile national cases, including 20 mass shootings. Her expertise has been featured on Dateline, GMA, HLN and more. She co-authored a book and taught journalism at Syracuse University. She has three documentaries in development. She earned an MS at Columbia University’s Graduate School of Journalism and a BA at the University of Texas.

Eric Ferrero is the Executive Director of the Fund for Investigative Journalism, which directly provides grants and other support to journalists for specific investigative projects. Over the last twenty years, he has served in senior leadership roles at nonprofit and philanthropic organizations that support and partner closely with journalists to uncover groundbreaking stories, including the Open Society Foundations, Innocence Project, and Amnesty International.

session_title: Open mic: Fact vs. fiction: Let’s talk about getting both sides
description:
This is one of five “Open Mic” sessions where you can listen to AND participate in a lively discussion about important issues facing our industry and impacting our daily work. All are welcome to attend!
*These sessions will not be recorded.

session_title: Showcase: Reporters in peril over the decades
description: This panel will explore notable cases, from the Arizona Project to the Chauncey Bailey Project, as well as the real, life-threatening work that journalists continue to do. Panelists will examine how the landscape of reporting has evolved while the dangers persist. After all, you can silence the journalist, but the story will live on.

speakers.bio: Richard Behar is the Contributing Editor of Investigations for Forbes magazine; an associate producer of an upcoming docuseries on post-Soviet organized crime; and author of “Madoff: The Final Word” (2024). Prior: staffs of Fortune, Time, Forbes. Probes for BBC, CNN, PBS. Winner of 20+ journalism awards (re Scientology; mafias; terrorists; etc.). He launched Project Klebnikov, a global media alliance probing 2004 Moscow murder of his friend, Forbes editor Paul Klebnikov.

Rocío Gallegos is a journalist in Ciudad Juárez. Co-founder and editorial director of La Verdad Juárez, an investigative journalism site, and co-founder of the Juárez Journalists Network. She worked as a reporter, editor, and information coordinator during the two periods that have most marked Ciudad Juárez: the homicides of women and the violence of 'the war' against drug trafficking.

Lise Olsen is an investigative reporter, editor and author whose latest book is The Scientist and the Serial Killer: The Search for Houston's Lost Boys (Random House 2025). Her first book, Code of Silence, won the IRE Book Award in 2022. She is a former IRE board member and, from 1996 to 1998, directed the IRE Mexico Project.

Martin Reynolds oversees fundraising, client relations, and external affairs at the Maynard Institute, where he also serves as lead Fault Lines® diversity trainer. He co-founded Oakland Voices, now in its 15th year, and formerly directed the Reveal Investigative Fellowship. A former editor-in-chief of The Oakland Tribune, he served as a lead editor on the Chauncey Bailey Project. He sits on Cityside’s board and once recorded a live album in Havana, Cuba, as a lyricist.

session_title: The art of the business investigation
description: From getting CEOs to talk to deep diving into a company, a business investigation has its own sets of challenges. You'll hear from veteran print and broadcast journalists on navigating these challenges and how to turn a tip into a compelling corporate investigation. We will cover how to source up at companies you cover, especially those with NDAs, the aggressive nature of PR in business investigations and how to keep your cool when they are yelling at you and calling your editor as well as front running stories with press releases. This session is sponsored by Bloomberg. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

speakers.bio: Polly Mosendz is an award-winning investigative reporter at Bloomberg News who covers corporate wrongdoing. Prior to Bloomberg, she worked for Newsweek, The Atlantic, and The New York Observer. Polly is working on completing a master's degree in criminology, with a focus on white-collar crime. She has also served as a two-time member of the reporter advisory board during her decade at Bloomberg News.

Christopher Weaver is an investigative reporter at The Wall Street Journal. His investigations of abuses in Medicare, failures of the U.S. Indian Health Service, Covid-era nursing homes and more have triggered state and federal investigations, new legislation and overhauls of agencies. He was part of a Pulitzer Prize winning team for Medicare coverage in 2015, and was a finalist for the award in 2021.

As CNBC's senior investigative producer, Scott Zamost set up the investigative unit in 2017, overseeing long form pieces for all platforms. An IRE speaker or moderator since 2002, he was a senior investigative producer at CNN, a CBS News producer and worked in local news in Miami. He started his career as a newspaper reporter in Las Vegas.

session_title: The reporter and editor relationship
description: How do you get the most out of the best editors? How do you manage to improve your writing even with the less-than-best editors? We'll offer practical tips about enduring the difficult edit, overcoming tension, and getting past the struggles that lead to "good enough."

speakers.bio: Matt Apuzzo is international investigations editor for the New York Times. He is based in London, where he manages a team of six reporters and works with bureau chiefs around the world. A former investigative reporter in Washington and Brussels, he has won or shared in three Pulitzer Prizes.

Elaine Teng is a senior editor in ESPN's investigative and enterprise unit, where she works on investigations, breaking news, longform features and cross-platform projects. She was previously a writer and editor at ESPN The Magazine, and the managing editor of The New Republic.

Tisha Thompson is an investigative reporter and senior writer at ESPN. Her investigation of MLB superstar Shohei Ohtani and his interpreter Ippei Mizuhara won this year's IRE Award for sports reporting. She's also been honored with Peabody, Emmy, Loeb, Gracie, Murrow, Telly, Headliner and Sigma Delta Chi awards, and credits IRE/NICAR and its members with so much of her professional success.

session_title: Tracking right-wing influencers and movements
description: The 2024 presidential election made it clear: The far right is no longer just ascendant -- it's the beating heart of the Republican Party, and will be a fixture of our politics and newsrooms for years to come. This session will provide a crash course on some of the movement's many factions, including right-wing campus groups, extremist influencers, Christian nationalist lawmakers, and the secretive networks and billionaires fueling them. Panelists will cover the basics -- how to stay safe online, for instance -- while also providing an overview of the ideologies and tactics already reshaping American democracy and politics at every level.

speakers.bio: David Armiak is research director and an investigative journalist with the Center for Media and Democracy. David joined CMD in 2015, has conducted extensive investigations on dark money, corporate corruption, and right-wing networks, and is responsible for filing and analyzing hundreds of public records requests every year.

Robert Downen is a Texas Monthly senior writer who focuses on the far right, Christian nationalism and the billionaires who fund them. He previously covered threats to democracy at The Texas Tribune and, before that, was part of the Houston Chronicle team that uncovered widespread sexual abuse in the Southern Baptist Convention -- leading to historic reforms and a Department of Justice investigation.

Kyle Spencer is an award-winning journalist, former NYT contributor, and the author of the critically-acclaimed book Raising Them Right, the Untold Story of America’s Ultraconservative Youth Movement and Its Plot for Power (Ecco/Harper Collins). She is the founding editor of Reporting Right, a weekly pro-democracy journalism newsletter, and the CEO of the Pro-Democracy Information Lab, a 501(c)(3) organization that helps news outlets reach a broader audience with pro-democracy news.

session_title: Board candidate meet & greet
description: Before you vote, take this time to talk to the folks running for a seat on the IRE Board.

session_title: International luncheon (invitation-only event)
description: This invitation-only event is co-sponsored by Global Investigative Journalism Network and the Investigative Reporting Workshop. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

session_title: Audio track: Investigative stories you can feel: Engaging audience through voices
description: Not all investigative journalism has to be dense to be impactful. This panel explores how to craft stories that reveal deep truths while keeping the audience engaged and not overwhelmed. Panelists discuss the art of navigating liminal spaces—storytelling that exists as both hard-hitting exposés and character based narratives—to find nuance, and humanity.

speakers.bio: Najib Aminy is a reporter and producer at Reveal. His work has earned him accolades like the George Polk Award, Alfred E. duPont Award, and Edward R. Murrow Award. Before Reveal, he was Flipboard’s first news editor and has reported for Newsday and The Indianapolis Star. He’s a Stony Brook alum and a proud New York Knicks fan, and he's mainly working to feed his cat.

speakers.affiliation: Futuro Media / Futuro Studios / Latino USA
speakers.bio: Fernanda Echavarri is an award-winning bilingual journalist. She’s a Senior Producer and Editor at Futuro Media, where she makes special podcast series and the weekly show Latino USA on NPR. She was previously at Mother Jones Magazine and Arizona Public Media. She began her journalism career in newspapers 15 years ago. Fernanda is the recipient of a Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights Award, a National Edward R. Murrow Award, a Regional Emmy, and was a Peabody Award finalist.

Will James reports, produces, and hosts documentary podcasts for the Seattle NPR station KUOW. He co-created the audio documentaries Lost Patients, which was nominated for a 2024 Peabody award; The Walk Home, winner of a national Edward R. Murrow Award; and Outsiders, which TIME called a "narrative feat" and one of the best podcasts of 2020.
Anna Sussman is Editor at Large at Snap Studios, where she has been producing stories for 15 years. She is the host and creator of the limited-run series Fire Escape.

session_title: Broadcast track: The 10 most important lessons I've learned

speakers.bio: A Murrow, Emmy, and AP Award-winning WUSA9 Chief Investigative Reporter, Eric Flack grew up in Washington, DC, and was drawn to reporting at an early age. He worked on the school paper in high school and college, where he was a staff writer for the Daily Tar Heel. Eric is incredibly fulfilled by his lifelong dedication to local journalism, but nothing compares to the pride he feels for his two teenage children, Miles and Rosalee.

Joce Sterman is the senior national investigative reporter for InvestigateTV. Her stories are seen on 113 TV stations, their websites & included on the national shows InvestigateTV+ and InvestigateTV+ Weekend Edition. She's a National Murrow, National Headliner, and Sigma Delta Chi award winner whose work has resulted in Congressional investigations and federal legislation. Joce's former roles include reporting for WJLA/ABC7 in DC, and WMAR/ABC2 in Baltimore.

session_title: Deep dive: Two reporters talk writing
description: Pamela Colloff and Hannah Dreier are two of investigative journalism’s greatest writers. Their stories are both epic and intimate. They seem always to be in just the right place to capture just the right moment. They’re also huge fans of each other’s work. In this conversation moderated by Louise Kiernan (a third member of the writers’ pantheon), they’ll talk about their approach to stories, the choices they make along the way, and the power of narrative to create change.

speakers.bio: Pamela Colloff is a reporter at ProPublica and a staff writer at The New York Times Magazine. Her reporting explores the criminal justice system in the United States, particularly the ways in which it falls short of delivering justice. She is a seven-time National Magazine Award nominee, winning for reporting in 2020 and feature writing in 2014. Her ProPublica-New York Times investigation, "False Witness," received the IRE Award in 2019.

Hannah Dreier is a New York Times reporter who previously worked for The Washington Post, ProPublica and The Associated Press. She won the 2024 Pulitzer Prize for Investigative Reporting and the 2019 Pulitzer Prize for Feature Writing. Her most recent reporting, “Alone and Exploited,” focused on the reach of migrant child labor across the United States.

session_title: Extracting public records from secretive government agencies
description: Three reporters and their lawyer share strategies for steering your FOIAs through the bureaucratic abyss. We’ll help you craft smarter FOIAs, identify when it’s time to sue and whether you can afford to sue (usually you can!), and sharpen your wiles when a lawsuit won’t work. We’ll also show examples of what you can do with all your records when you get a bigger document dump than you ever imagined was possible!

speakers.bio: Alejandra Cancino is a senior reporter at Injustice Watch, a Chicago-based nonprofit newsroom. Her investigations focus on the intersection of government and business, combining data with personal stories to expose systemic failures. Her reporting has been recognized with local and national awards. Cancino is an IRE board member and a former board member of SPJs’ Chicago Headline Club, where she co-created a rigorous training program for young journalists of color.

Jason Leopold is an investigative reporter at Bloomberg News. He is a recipient of the Gerald Loeb award, a George Polk award, and he has twice been a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize. In 2020, TRAC identified Leopold as "the most active individual FOIA litigator” in the US. In 2016, Leopold was awarded the FOI award from IRE and was inducted into the National Freedom of Information Hall of Fame. He publishes the weekly newsletter, FOIA Files.

Matt Topic runs the media and intellectual property practice at Loevy + Loevy. Matt and his team have litigated hundreds of state and federal open records cases.  Matt also represents several news publishers in copyright cases against OpenAI and Microsoft.

Parker Yesko is a reporter for The New Yorker's Pulitzer Prize-winning podcast In the Dark. For Season 3 of the podcast, Parker examined why no U.S. Marines were punished for the 2005 killings of 25 civilians in Haditha, Iraq. She compiled the largest known database of alleged war crimes committed by American service members in Iraq and Afghanistan since 9/11. Parker's reporting for Season 2 helped to free a man, Curtis Flowers, from Mississippi's death row.

session_title: Federal decisions impacting your K-12 schools
description: Learn how changes under the Trump administration could impact schools, students, and tax dollars. This rockstar panel walks you through data and resources to explore how federal education policies are impacting immigrants, LGBTQ+ people and students with disabilities. Whether you cover local school districts, or federal education policy, we got you covered.

speakers.bio: Ileana Najarro is a staff writer at Education Week covering topics of race and opportunity, including the educational opportunities of English learners and immigrant students. She has previously written for the Tampa Bay Times and the Houston Chronicle.

Andy Pierrotti is a national award-winning investigative reporter with WANF-TV, CBS in Atlanta recognized with the duPont Columbia Award, George Foster Peabody, multiple Emmy and Edward R. Murrow awards.

Orion Rummler covers LGBTQ+ news for The 19th. His reporting includes health policy explainers, in-depth court coverage, statehouse news, and features on LGBTQ+ daily life. His reporting has won an Excellence in Journalism Award from the Association of LGBTQ+ Journalists and a national Edward R. Murrow Award, as part of his newsroom’s four-part series on what it means to choose pregnancy in post-Roe America.

Marina Villeneuve is an investigative reporter for The Hechinger Report. She previously worked as a statehouse reporter for The Associated Press, as a legal reporter covering Trump's legal battles for Salon, and as an investigative producer at a Boston television station. She is a board member of IRE and the New England chapter of the National Association of Hispanic Journalists. She earned a certificate in data journalism from Columbia University's Lede Program.

session_title: Google Pinpoint for research and investigations
description:
This session is sponsored by Google Trends. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

This session is good for: everyone. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

session_title: Google Sheets: Using string functions to manipulate data
description:
Maybe you converted a PDF or imported a table into a spreadsheet -- or maybe an agency gave you a poorly formatted file. You can use string functions to reformat your data and get your spreadsheets working for you. 

This session is good for: Anyone comfortable with using formulas and functions in Google Sheets.

You must bring your own laptop (no tablets) to participate in this class, and you will need a free Google account to participate.

speakers.bio: Ed Mahon reports on addiction treatment, the opioid epidemic, medical marijuana, and other public health issues for Spotlight PA. His reporting has earned national recognition, including a 2018 finalist slot for the Livingston Awards for Young Journalists and a 2021 investigative award from the Institute for Nonprofit News. He serves as president of the Pennsylvania Legislative Correspondents' Association, representing journalists reporting from the state Capitol.

session_title: IRE Conversation: Laid off? Find your support system
description: For anyone who has experienced a layoff, it can be so traumatic and devastating as much of our professional identity is interwoven with our personal values and purpose. It can feel like the end of the world but it is not. Come hear from those who have navigated such situations and lived to tell about it.

speakers.bio: Janelle is an investigative reporter covering downstate Illinois for the Illinois Answers Project. She was previously a data reporter at the Center for Public Integrity and the St. Louis Post-Dispatch.

Jonathan D. Salant is a Washington-based columnist for the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, a former president of the National Press Club and a member of the Society of Professional Journalists D.C chapter's Hall of Fame.

Mc Nelly Torres is an award-winning investigative journalist and former editor at the Center for Public Integrity where she led a team investigating inequality. Before, Torres worked as an investigative producer for NBC6 in Miami and co-founded FCIR.org. She is a product of newspapers including the Sun-Sentinel and the San Antonio Express-News. Torres was the first Latina elected to the IRE board of directors. In 2022, Torres was a recipient of the Gwen Ifill Award.

session_title: Master class: "I don't watch TV news" - How to get your content in front of the next generation of viewers - pre-registered attendees only
description:
If you’ve ever wondered how to turn an investigative story into a viral video shared by people around the world, this is the class for you. No tricks, no gimmicks, no dance trends, we promise. These are best practices shared by journalists who found success reaching people who want nothing to do with the traditional news model. We’ll share why we create content for different social platforms, but most importantly, we’ll show you how. By the end of this class, we want you to walk away with a video you’ve shot, edited and prepared to post that same day.

This class is led by some of our newer-generation IRE investigators who've  mastered the industry's challenge of reaching people where they're at.

Topics will include:
-The five second rule: Hook your audience in the first five seconds
-How to get rid of the news voice and be more conversational
-Important things to remember when editing video on your phone or computer
-Where to post, when, and how
-How to set up your content for maximum views
-Adding social media to your daily duties
-Owning your brand

speakers.bio: Ashlyn Lipori-Russie is the creator and host of Ask Ashlyn, an SMS and social media-based solution to news avoidance that invites users to ask questions about the news, as if speaking with a journalist friend. Ashlyn is an Emmy-nominated journalist with a diverse background in broadcast and digital news, including the Investigative Unit at NBC Bay Area, ABC 10News, and inewsource in San Diego.

Anastassia, Stassi for short, is an investigative reporter with a consumer focus with Atlanta News First Investigates. She previously worked as a general assignment and in-depth/investigative reporter in Los Angeles and Tampa. She also shoots and edits her stories in many forms including for broadcast as well as social media vertical video. She has a B.A. from USC and a Masters degree from Columbia Journalism School.

session_title: Master class: Art of the investigative interview (pre-registered attendees only)
description:
You need one final confirmation to run your story. It's the key piece of a months-long project, only one person can provide it, and you've got one shot to get it.

The entire story comes down to The Interview. Will you be ready?

We can help. Sign up for this half-day Master Class in interviewing and get a playbook for getting the information you need.

We'll cover all the crucial steps, from preparation to the conversation, confrontational interviews, talking with survivors, getting the most from witnesses, convincing those who don't want to talk with you and much more.

So the next time you dial that number, knock on that door or corner an official who’s been avoiding you, you’ll be ready.

Preregistration is required and seating is limited.

speakers.bio: Mark Horvit is a professor at the University of Missouri School of Journalism, where he teaches investigative reporting, a reporting project capstone and other stuff. He is also chair of the Journalism Professions faculty. Horvit previously served as executive director of  IRE and NICAR, where he conducted training in investigative reporting and data journalism throughout the world. Horvit worked as a reporter and editor for 20 years in Texas, the Carolinas and Florida.

Thompson is an award-winning investigative correspondent and senior editor for investigations for NPR. Before joining NPR in 2019, she spent 22 years covering law enforcement and political corruption for The Washington Post, and was part of teams that won the Pulitzer for National Reporting in 2002 and 2016. She was the reporting coach on the NPR podcast "No Compromise," which won the Pulitzer Prize for Audio Reporting in 2021.

As CNBC's senior investigative producer, Scott Zamost set up the investigative unit in 2017, overseeing long form pieces for all platforms. An IRE speaker or moderator since 2002, he was a senior investigative producer at CNN, a CBS News producer and worked in local news in Miami. He started his career as a newspaper reporter in Las Vegas.

session_title: R 1: Intro to R and RStudio
description:
Jump into data analysis with R, the powerful open-source programming language. In this class we’ll cover R fundamentals and learn our way around the RStudio interface for using R.
 
This session is good for: People with a basic understanding of data analysis who are ready to go beyond spreadsheets. Laptops will be provided.

speakers.bio: Holly is data editor at KFF Health News, a national nonprofit newsroom dedicated to health policy and health care coverage. Previously, she was an investigative reporter at The Dallas Morning News. She lives in Maryland.

session_title: Show & Tell: News director critique

speakers.bio: Josh Morgan is the News Director at KCTV5, the Gray Media station in Kansas City, and the home of the 4-time Super Bowl Champion Kansas City Chiefs! That said, he’s a Packers fan. Josh is a 19-year broadcast television veteran, with more than half of that time spent as a news director. He’s a former general manager, a two-time National Murrow winner, and is currently looking for a full-time investigative reporter to join his team!

Kim Saxon is the News Director for Atlanta News First, the flagship station of Atlanta-based Gray Media, and wrangler of an incredible eleven-person investigative team that has changed laws, policies, and lives. Kim has over 25 years in broadcast journalism, a B.S. in Business Administration and Law, duPont, Murrow, and Emmy Awards, one husband, four kids (all grown), three dogs, and one nearly complete fiction manuscript.

session_title: The investigative editor’s toolkit
description: Join this panel of award-winning multimedia investigative journalists who will share essential tips for effective investigative editing and project management. This discussion draws on the new online curriculum from the Howard Center for Investigative Journalism at the Walter Cronkite School of Journalism and Mass Communication at ASU. The series of 12 courses covers every step of the investigative editing process, from helping your reporters hone their investigative story ideas and prepare for key interviews, to directing multimedia productions, bulletproofing, legal review and managing the stress and occasional blowback that goes with investigative journalism.

speakers.bio: Len Downie is the former executive editor of The Washington Post, where he worked for 44 years as an investigative reporter, foreign correspondent and metro, national, and managing editor. The Post won a record 25 Pulitzer Prizes during his 17 years as executive editor. Since retiring from The Post, he has been a professor for 15 years at Arizona State's Walter Cronkite School of Journalism and Mass Communication.

speakers.affiliation: Howard Center for Investigative Journalism, Arizona State University
speakers.bio: Mark Greenblatt is the executive editor and a professor at ASU's Howard Center for Investigative Journalism. He is a three-time Peabody Award winner, whose stories have also won the IRE Medal, two National Emmy Awards for investigative reporting, the duPont-Columbia Award, and the Livingston Award. He is devoting this chapter of his career to supporting the next generation of investigative leaders. Mark is the elected Treasurer and a Member of the Board of Directors for IRE.

speakers.affiliation: Howard Center for Investigative Journalism at Arizona State University
speakers.bio: Lauren Mucciolo is the Executive Producer of ASU's Howard Center for Investigative Journalism. Her students' work has been recognized with 60+ collegiate and professional journalism awards, including a Pulitzer Prize finalist honor. Mucciolo has made more than a dozen broadcast and digital documentaries for PBS Frontline, which have received two RFK Journalism awards, five Emmy nominations, a SXSW Festival Jury Prize and a Royal Television Society best director award.

Mark J. Rochester is Executive Editor at the Sarasota Herald-Tribune. Previously, he was Senior News Director for Investigations for The Detroit Free Press. He has held senior management positions at The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, Associated Press, Denver Post, Newsday and The Indianapolis Star. An Indianapolis native, he has served as a juror for the Pulitzer Prizes at Columbia University.

session_title: Tools and techniques to investigate civilian war casualties from afar
description: This panel will describe new or newly expanded open source tools such as Airwars, OSMP, and Vantage that can measure civilian deaths and identify accountable parties, while avoiding high costs and safety risks. The panel will also highlight how on-the-ground field reporting in hostile environments can power OSINT-led investigations back in the newsroom, with examples from Ukraine and Gaza.

speakers.bio: Yousur Al-Hlou worked as a visual reporter at The New York Times from 2015-2024. Her work covering Russia’s war in Ukraine alongside many talented colleagues was awarded a George Polk Award, a DuPont Award, an Edward R. Murrow Award and the 2022 Pulitzer Prize for International Reporting. She earned her master’s degree from the Graduate School of Journalism at U.C. Berkeley.

Masha Froliak a journalist who has been covering the war in Ukraine. Together with Yousur Al-Hlou, they launched several critical investigations for The New York Times into likely war crimes of the Russian army in Ukraine. Their work includes Pulitzer-Prize winning reporting that exposed the Russian military unit that carried out the worst atrocities in Bucha.

Rowan Philp is a senior reporter and impact editor at the Global Investigative Journalism Network (GIJN). He was formerly chief reporter for South Africa’s Sunday Times. As a foreign correspondent, he has reported on news, politics, corruption, and conflict from more than two dozen countries around the world.

session_title: Understanding your legal rights when reporting on immigration and deportation
description:
Reporters Committee is developing a suite of resources for reporters who are covering immigration and deportation to make sure reporters know and understand their rights. This panel will give reporters and editors tools to protect themselves legally when reporting on these issues.

This session is sponsored by Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

speakers.bio: Melissa del Bosque is an award-winning investigative journalist, specializing in the U.S.-Mexico border region. She is the investigations editor for Lighthouse Reports and cofounder of The Border Chronicle. Her work has been published in The New Yorker, The Guardian, The Texas Observer, and numerous other media outlets.

speakers.affiliation: Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press
speakers.bio: Jennifer Nelson is a senior staff attorney with the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, where she leads its pre-publication and pre-broadcast review practice, oversees the publication of and updates to the Reporters Committee’s legal guides, and supervises its hotline for journalists. Nelson also regularly represents news organizations and journalists in public records, court access, and legal defense matters before federal and state courts.

Alejandro Serrano writes about Texas politics and government, with a focus on immigration and education issues, for The Texas Tribune. Since joining the Tribune, he has helped investigate the 2022 Uvalde school shooting, spent half a year on the US-Mexico border during a temporary assignment covering immigration, and documented a variety of major events in the state.

speakers.affiliation: Reporters Committee for Freedrom of the Press
speakers.bio: Gunita Singh is an attorney at Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press using FOIA and public records laws to get government documents for journalists and newsrooms. She has co-authored two publications on the effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on access to public records. She serves as board chair of LION Publishers.

session_title: AI 101: Coaching ChatGPT to help you with your coding and data tasks
description:
ChatGPT, widely misunderstood and in some cases misused, can be a powerful tool to improve efficiency in our day-to-day work. Give ChatGPT a few rows of publicly available data and ask it to write a data dictionary. We'll use ChatGPT to help write a public records request for us, have it help us make sense of data and we'll even use it to write a Python script to reshape unruly Excel data. The best part? You don't need to know Python to write this code.

Some data experience is helpful for this session, but not required. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

speakers.bio: Charles Minshew is the senior editor for data journalism at The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, working primarily with the investigative team and helping journalists across the AJC tell stories with data. Charles is the former director of data services for IRE. In 2012, Charles was on the staff of The Denver Post that won a Pulitzer Prize for Breaking News for coverage of a shooting at a theater in Aurora, Colorado.

session_title: Audio track: Juggling print and audio investigations (and how to do both, very different things at the same time)
description:
Collaborations between print and audio journalists have generated chart-topping, change-making, award-winning podcasts, vastly magnifying the reach of investigative stories. 

These collaborations have the power to bring stories to life, take listeners inside the reporting process, and explore universal themes unearthed in the reporting. 

But the difference between print and audio storytelling isn't just stylistic; Sometimes these mediums have different aims altogether, and these collaborations force journalists to contend with diverging ideas of "impact" and other questions.

In this panel, you'll hear from journalists who successfully navigated these crosswinds to create print-audio collaborations that have resonated nationally. You'll walk away inspired and equipped to pitch a podcast that draws on the best of each of these mediums.

speakers.bio: Najib Aminy is a reporter and producer at Reveal. His work has earned him accolades like the George Polk Award, Alfred E. duPont Award, and Edward R. Murrow Award. Before Reveal, he was Flipboard’s first news editor and has reported for Newsday and The Indianapolis Star. He’s a Stony Brook alum and a proud New York Knicks fan, and he's mainly working to feed his cat.

Laura Greanias is the interim investigations editor at The Seattle Times and executive producer of two nationally distributed and award-winning podcasts: The Last Ride (2023) and Lost Patients (2024). Previous leadership roles: the USA TODAY Network, LA School Report, Los Angeles Daily News and 15 years at the Los Angeles Times, including as executive news editor / deputy front page editor, foreign news editor and Metro morning assignment editor.

Will James reports, produces, and hosts documentary podcasts for the Seattle NPR station KUOW. He co-created the audio documentaries Lost Patients, which was nominated for a 2024 Peabody award; The Walk Home, winner of a national Edward R. Murrow Award; and Outsiders, which TIME called a "narrative feat" and one of the best podcasts of 2020.

Paige Pfleger is the criminal justice reporter at WPLN news in Nashville, where she has investigated gun dispossession, domestic violence and juvenile justice as a fellow with ProPublica’s Local Reporting Network. Her work was a finalist for a Livingston Award and an Investigative Reporters and Editors Award, and she has appeared nationally on NPR, The Washington Post, Marketplace and more.

session_title: Broadcast track: PIVOT! New market? New station? New role? New challenges.

speakers.bio: Jatara McGee is an investigative reporter/anchor at WPXI in Pittsburgh. She's a natural storyteller and sharp investigator. Her reporting has revealed corruption, fraud and misconduct. She graduated from the University of Maryland in 2015 and worked at WSAZ in Charleston, W.Va. and WLWT in Cincinnati. Jatara chairs NABJ's Investigative Task Force. She’s received an NABJ Salute to Excellence award, numerous Emmy nominations and two regional Edward R. Murrow awards.

Charlie's an investigative reporter at WGRZ-TV in Buffalo. His reporting has led to the resignation of powerful people and changes in New York State law. Charlie’s investigation of the Catholic Diocese of Buffalo revealed a cover-up of sexual abuse allegations and led to the resignation of Bishop Richard Malone  and the passage of New York's Child Victims Act. Charlie has received regional and national investigative reporting awards, including the Alfred I. duPont Award.

session_title: Google Sheets: Importing and data prep
description:
Don't give up if your data isn't presented in a neat spreadsheet. This session will teach you how to get data into a spreadsheet and prepare it for analysis. We will look at how to import text files, deal with data in a PDF, and get a table on a web page into a spreadsheet.

This session is good for: Anyone comfortable working in Google Sheets.

You must bring your own laptop (no tablets) to participate in this class, and you will need a free Google account to participate.

speakers.bio: Kara Newhouse loves using data to uncover and tell stories that hold public officials accountable and shed light on injustice. She is an investigative data reporter for Suncoast Searchlight in Florida and has previously worked for print, digital and broadcast outlets covering education and other topics. Kara has a master’s degree from the University of Maryland, where she was a fellow at the Howard Center for Investigative Journalism. She also writes children’s books.

session_title: Guiding your students through on-campus investigations
description: In communities where local newsrooms are shrinking and disappearing, college journalists are often the ones asking the toughest accountability questions. Join this information-packed session to discover best practices for well-informed campus reporting. This session will help student journalists (and their advisers) produce evidence-based, high-impact investigations on pressing topics like campus crime, immigration enforcement, sports stadium financing and student mental health.

speakers.affiliation: The Journalist’s Resource at Harvard Kennedy School
speakers.bio: Clark Merrefield is the senior editor for economics and legal systems at JR. He joined JR in 2019 after working as a reporter for Newsweek and The Daily Beast, as a researcher and editor on three books related to the Great Recession, and as a federal government communications strategist. He has been selected for fellowships in juvenile justice and solitary confinement at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, and his work has been awarded by IRE.

Naseem Miller is senior health editor at The Journalist’s Resource, a project of the Shorenstein Center at Harvard Kennedy School. In addition to covering health, she writes about the intersection of journalism and trauma. She’s also part of Dart Center’s training team. Miller was part of the Orlando Sentinel team named a 2016 Pulitzer Prize finalist for coverage of the Pulse nightclub mass shooting. She co-started and administers the Journalists Covering Trauma Facebook group.

Carmen Nobel is the program director and editor-in-chief of The Journalist’s Resource at Harvard Kennedy School's Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy. She broke into journalism in 1995 at The Winged M, a lifestyle magazine for a fancy athletic club in Portland, Oregon. Since then, she has written for Air Force Times, The Boston Globe, eWEEK, TheStreet, Harvard Business School Working Knowledge, NPR Science Friday, and many other publications.

speakers.affiliation: The Journalist's Resource at Harvard Kennedy School
speakers.bio: Denise-Marie Ordway is managing editor of The Journalist’s Resource at Harvard Kennedy School. Previously, she reported news in English and Spanish for several major news outlets in the U.S. and Central America. She received national and regional journalism awards and, in 2013, was a Pulitzer Prize finalist for an investigation of Florida A&M University she led. She's an Education Writers Association board member and fellow of Harvard’s Nieman Foundation for Journalism.

session_title: Gun violence reporting in the Trump era
description:
Time to get real: Media over the last 30 years is failing, complacency has lost us jobs and public trust, and harmful practices have led us to the very darkest pit of our existence in journalism. Meanwhile Americans die in the dark. It's time to break the cycle.

Gun violence coverage on our best days can often be reactive—dominated by mass shootings, political cycles, or other fleeting news moments. But as policies shift, sources disappear, and federal oversight weakens, journalists, particularly the editorial class, need to rethink how they cover guns and the communities affected by them.

This panel will explore how to find on-the-ground sources when traditional ones disappear, how federal rollbacks affect domestic violence, community safety, and policing, and how to avoid amplifying misinformation in fast-moving coverage. With media sometimes struggling to get gun reporting right in so-called “peace times,” the stakes are even higher in times of increased political instability.

session_title: How to report on anti-competitive behavior
description: From Big Tech to Main Street, companies allegedly use anti-competitive tactics to advantage themselves and hobble their rivals. Both in the U.S. and around the world, governments and people are investigating the dominant roles a handful of companies play in every industry. Hear from journalists who explain the basics of antitrust law, share tips on reporting on complaints of anticompetitive conduct and explain the government antitrust enforcement landscape. They will offer tips on how to develop sources on the competition beat, how to cover antitrust lawsuits and how to find stories from the agencies and courts tasked with enforcing the law. And finally they will offer suggestions about how to engage audiences to care about anti-competitive activities.

speakers.bio: A multiple Pulitzer Prize winner, Grimaldi is executive editor of the National Catholic Reporter, one of the oldest independent nonprofit news organizations in the country. Grimaldi is a seasoned investigative reporter who has worked for six newspapers, including The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal. A frequent college lecturer, he is on the steering committee of the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press and is past president of IRE.

David McCabe covers technology policy for The New York Times. In recent years, he has reported on the federal investigations into whether Google, Apple, Meta and Amazon broke antitrust laws. The government sued all four companies, and he now follows the cases as they wind through the courts. He shared a 2023 Free Speech & Open Government Award from the First Amendment Coalition for work that ensured press access to the antitrust trial over Google’s search business.

Karina Montoya is a senior reporter and policy analyst at the Open Markets Institute, covering antitrust and data privacy, with a focus on large digital platforms and AI. She contributes reporting and analysis to various news outlets and to Open Markets' legal research, exposing the harms of corporate power concentration and advocating for policy solutions. In her native Peru, she reported extensively on telecom, infrastructure and corporate corruption scandals.

Leah Nylen is a reporter for Bloomberg News and has covered antitrust for various news outlets, including Politico and MLex, for 14 years. In 2023, she won the Free Speech & Open Government Award from the First Amendment Coalition for her work on press access in the US v Google search trial. In 2014, she was an Abe Journalist Fellow focused on a project comparing antitrust enforcement in the US and Japan.

session_title: Hurricane Katrina: Lessons learned, 20 years later
description: Hurricane Katrina irrevocably changed New Orleans. The storm exposed failures in the region's federally designed levee system and changed the way local officials respond to and prepare for disasters. It rocked the city's medical community and raised questions about the ethics in emergencies. The city's recovery from the epic storm was also tainted by corruption. What lessons have local and state leaders learned from the storm and its chaotic aftermath, 20 years later?
track: Climate, 50th Anniversary, Beat reporting, Criminal legal system, Local news, Security

speakers.affiliation: Arnolt Center for Investigative Journalism at Indiana University
speakers.bio: Founding director of the Arnolt Center for Investigative Journalism at Indiana University. Formerly a long-time senior investigative producer at CNN in Atlanta and held a similar role at CBS News in D.C. Kathleen had an extensive career in newspapers before television production. She has received multiple awards, including IRE, national Emmy, Columbia DuPont, Peabody, and Murrow awards. She specializes in counter-terrorism, homeland security, congressional spending, and breaking news events.

Halle Parker covers public health inequities and environmental health for the news nonprofit Verite News in New Orleans. Before Verite, she covered environmental issues in Louisiana — with a special focus on environmental justice — for WWNO, the Times- Picayune / New Orleans Advocate and the Houma Courier. She also helped start, produce, host and report the podcast "Sea Change." Her work has appeared on Up First, Morning Edition and All Things Considered.

Jessica Williams is the metro editor for The Times-Picayune. The Times-Picayune is the largest news organization in New Orleans and its metro desk includes nearly two dozen reporters covering city and suburban politics, policy, criminal justice, business, health, culture and other topics. Williams is a native of New Orleans and a graduate of Loyola University.

Lee is Senior Vice President, News Strategy and Innovation for Gray Media. Before that, he was a longtime anchor and investigative reporter. For 15 years, Lee served as News Anchor and Chief Investigative Reporter at WVUE-TV in New Orleans.

session_title: Investigative reporting can save the journalism industry
description: We keep saying it — but for it to be true, we must make fundamental, sometimes uncomfortable changes. As Einstein warned, doing the same thing while expecting different results is madness. In this panel, funders and journalists confront the hard truth: audiences have moved on, trust has eroded and the old formulas aren't working like they used to. What are we going to do about it? This session will explore bold approaches to redefining investigative journalism with greater community agency and local impact and will discuss what it's going to take to regain trust — and achieve sustainability. The goal isn't just to survive; it's to thrive for the long term.

speakers.bio: Terry Baquet is editor-in-chief of Verite News and previously was Page One editor at The Times-Picayune
David Boardman is dean of the Klein College of Media and Communication at Temple University and previously chair of The Markup and executive editor/senior vice president of The Seattle Times.
Rhiannon Collette is journalism director at Arnold Ventures and previously was an energy reporter at the Houston Chronicle and investigative reporter at the Corpus Christi Caller-Times.

speakers.affiliation: Center for Integrity in News Reporting
speakers.bio: Rufus Friday is executive director of the new Center for Integrity in News Reporting and previously worked for Gannett and McClatchy, including publisher at the Tri-City Herald (WA) and Lexington Herald-Leader (KY).

Marisa Kwiatkowski is the director of journalism at Knight Foundation. She previously spent 20 years as a reporter, handling investigations at USA TODAY and local outlets in Michigan, South Carolina, and Indiana. Her work has sparked multi-agency investigations, led to criminal charges, resulted in resignations, and prompted changes to state and federal laws.

session_title: Networking: Journalists of color
description:
Mix and mingle, meet friends old and new, and build your professional community in this fun and informal networking session. This session is for journalists of color. 

This session is sponsored by ProPublica, The Texas Tribune, The Marshall Project and Grist. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

speakers.bio: Gonzalo Magaña is an award-winning journalist and director of special projects and audience engagement at ABC10, TEGNA’s ABC affiliate in Sacramento, California. He created the ABC10 Originals team, focused on long-form and investigative reporting, and launched the station’s Race and Culture content in 2021. With over 20 years of experience, including 12 in Spanish-language news, he's earned multiple duPont-Columbia, Murrow, and Emmy Awards, and two Peabody Award nominations.
Noy Thrupkaew is the director of partnerships and a reporting fellow at Type Investigations, a nonprofit investigative newsroom.

session_title: R 2: Data analysis and plotting
description:
We'll use the tidyverse packages dplyr and ggplot2, learning how to sort, filter, group, summarize, join, and visualize to identify trends in your data. If you want to combine SQL-like analysis and charting in a single pipeline, this session is for you. 

This session is good for: People who have worked with data operations in SQL or Excel and would like to do the same in R. Laptops will be provided.

speakers.affiliation: UC Berkeley Graduate School of Journalism
speakers.bio: Jennifer LaFleur teaches data journalism at UC Berkeley’s Graduate School of Journalism. She was previously a senior editor at the Center for Public Integrity. She has also worked at American University, Reveal from the Center for Investigative Reporting, ProPublica and several newspapers. She is a former IRE training director and previously served on IRE’s board. She is a board member of the Fund for Investigative Journalism.

session_title: Show & Tell: Unscheduled interviews, accountability
description:
Sign up to “Show & Tell” us about your best work and get constructive feedback from the moderator and audience. 

Sign-ups are required for presenters. Each presenter will have 15 minutes to share their work and receive feedback. All are welcome to attend!

Sign up here: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/10C084CA8AC29A4FBCE9-57104242-show

*These sessions will not be recorded.

session_title: The IRE board wants to hear from you: Forming a press freedom working group
description: As the attacks on press freedom intensify, the IRE board wants to hear from members about their priorities for IRE in this moment. Join us for a conversation about what's being planned, what else we can do and how you can help

session_title: Working with whistleblowers: Past, present and future
description:
This panel will examine the past, present and future landscape of journalists’ use of confidential sources and legal risks and protections for them.

Currently, the industry is facing heightened challenges as whistleblower protections weaken; what can the past tell us about what might be ahead?

Attendees will learn about the importance of safeguarding sources and the necessity to use good old-fashioned shoe-leather reporting skills that go beyond tools, such as Signal, to protect those who risk their careers for the sake of transparency and accountability. 

You'll walk away with a better understanding of how to navigate these complexities from those who have been doing it for decades and ensure critical information flows despite the mounting pressures.

speakers.bio: Len Downie is the former executive editor of The Washington Post, where he worked for 44 years as an investigative reporter, foreign correspondent and metro, national, and managing editor. The Post won a record 25 Pulitzer Prizes during his 17 years as executive editor. Since retiring from The Post, he has been a professor for 15 years at Arizona State's Walter Cronkite School of Journalism and Mass Communication.

Ross Garber is the principal of The Garber Group LLC, a law firm based in Washington, D.C. He also teaches Government Investigations and Impeachment Law at Tulane Law School in New Orleans. His clients have included public officials, journalists, and a variety of organizations in government investigations and high-stakes civil cases. He is a contributing author of the book Ethics in the Public Sector. Ross was previously a legal analyst for CNN.

Tracee Wilkins is an investigative reporter with more than 25 years in broadcast, and 20 years at NBC Washington. Her investigations focus heavily on areas of law enforcement, incarceration, racial justice and government accountability. She’s an Edward R. Murrow, multiple Emmy, and AP award winner. Wilkins was the Journalist of the Year for the Washington Association of Black Journalists in 2022.

speakers.affiliation: Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press

session_title: Audio track: Should your story be an audio documentary? Long-form narrative for national audiences
description: It's tempting to look for a long-form podcast in every investigation. But what are the elements of a great investigative podcast that resonate with a national audience? Editors and producers from Wondery, Reveal, This American Life and Embedded share their strategies for story selection and what their newsrooms look for in the stories they pursue.

speakers.bio: Rachel B. Doyle leads creative development for Wondery's Limited Series department, guiding investigative podcasts from research to greenlight. She specializes in six-part series, such as the Loeb Award-winning "Spellcaster: The Fall of Sam Bankman-Fried," and in shaping narratives that resonate with listeners and push the boundaries of investigative audio journalism. Before working in audio, she reported from over 20 countries while based in Berlin and Nairobi.
