Kate Howard is an editorial director at the Center for Investigative Reporting, which produces Reveal and Mother Jones. Previously, she was managing editor at the Kentucky Center for Investigative Reporting, where her team was a Peabody Award finalist for the investigative podcast Dig. Howard was a local news reporter working in newspapers and radio for nearly 14 years. She is a board member for IRE and Louisville Public Media, and she's based in Louisville, Kentucky.

Katie Simon is the Supervising Senior Editor for Embedded, NPR's home for documentary journalism. Before Embedded, she was a founding editor at StoryCorps. She's made long-form podcasts for WNYC and freelanced for ESPN. She got her start in audio as a reporter in Newark, NJ. Simon has won a DuPont award, two Peabody awards (five nominations), and has multiple Emmy nominations. She graduated from Kenyon College and Columbia University's School of Journalism.

session_title: Broadcast track: Me, myself & I-Team: Uplevel your investigation with or without a photographer

speakers.bio: Ashley Graham is the chief investigator and 6 p.m. anchor in Shreveport, Louisiana. She holds a Bachelor's degree in English from Emory University and a Master of Science in Journalism degree from Northwestern University. Her work in Michigan, Florida, and Louisiana brings viewers an in-depth look at issues that directly affect them.

session_title: Covering immigration on any beat
description: Covering immigration can be daunting, especially for those unable to keep tabs on the ever-changing policies or latest headlines. This class is for anyone interested in covering immigration beyond the border wall. In this session, you will learn to use public datasets to help find local, state and national stories about missing migrants, work visas and court challenges to immigration policy. We will also spend some time talking about best practices for covering the immigrant community.

speakers.bio: Kristian Hernández is a New York Times Local Investigations fellow based in Fort Worth, Texas, with more than a decade of experience covering immigration and criminal justice. Before joining the Times, he was an investigative reporter at the Center for Public Integrity and the Fort Worth Star-Telegram. Hernández has a master's degree in investigative journalism from American University and a bachelor’s in multimedia journalism from the University of Texas at El Paso.

Mary Sanchez is a syndicated columnist with Tribune Content Agency and a familiar face and voice in Kansas City media. Sanchez’s contributions include time as the senior reporter for Kansas City PBS and a metro columnist for The Kansas City Star; member of the Star’s editorial board, in addition to her years spent reporting on race, class, immigration, criminal justice and educational issues.

session_title: Finding stories hidden in your local government’s meeting agenda
description: Learn tips and tricks for uncovering interesting stories and sources through local government meetings. Panelists will discuss how they uncovered compelling stories by following local government public meetings. Whether you're monitoring committee hearings in the state legislature, regularly attending your local government's city council or commissioners court, or examining how agencies oversee police departments, this session will help you identify newsworthy developments, pinpoint unique accountability stories, discover new sources, and track issues that matter to your community.

speakers.bio: Huangpu is a government reporter at Spotlight PA, a non-profit newsroom covering Pennsylvania state policy and politics. She tracks legislation and its impact on communities across the state. A graduate of the Columbia Journalism School’s data journalism program, Huangpu previously worked at ABC’s World News Tonight and MSNBC.

McKenna Oxenden most recently covered Harris County for the Houston Landing on its government accountability team. Before that, she worked at The New York Times as a fellow on its breaking news desk. McKenna has also worked at her hometown paper, The Baltimore Sun, covering breaking news and criminal justice and as a general assignment reporter at the Tampa Bay Times. Her work has also appeared in the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, USA Today and the Washington Post.

Mark Puente, a two-time finalist for the Pulitzer Prize, leads the investigative reporting for The Marshall Project - Cleveland. Puente, a former truck driver, has 20 years in journalism and a proven track record in accountability reporting. He has worked for The (Cleveland) Plain Dealer, The Baltimore Sun, the Tampa Bay Times and the Los Angeles Times. At The Marshall Project, Puente has written about traffic stops, reentry services, judicial misconduct and jail deaths.

session_title: Google Sheets: Advanced pivot tables
description:
You've done a few pivot tables and are getting curious about what more you could do with them. What happens if you aggregate by more than one column? What are those "column" and "filter" boxes for? Come unlock the full potential of pivot tables in this intermediate spreadsheet class.

This session is good for: People familiar with spreadsheets and aggregating data with pivot tables, or anyone who has taken Sheets 1-3.

You must bring your own laptop (no tablets) to participate in this class, and you will need a free Google account to participate.

speakers.bio: Kenny Jacoby is an investigative reporter for USA TODAY. His investigations have centered on issues in sports, higher education and law enforcement. He is fluent in public records requests, spreadsheets and web scraping in Python.

session_title: Networking: Students
description: Mix and mingle with peers from throughout the world to find solidarity, make new friends, and build your professional community in this fun and informal networking session. This session is for students.

speakers.affiliation: University of Missouri / Report for America Corps Member

speakers.bio: Hope Moses, who is originally from Milwaukee, Wisconsin, is a master's candidate at Northwestern University's Medill School of Journalism. At Medill, she specializes in investigative and data reporting with interests in health, criminal and social justice, and topics that intersect with law and public policy. This summer, she will be a reporting intern at the Chicago Tribune, where she will use data to report on suburban and metro stories.

session_title: OSINT visual investigations
description:
A practical primer for open-source intelligence reporting and visual investigations. Learn the basics of geolocation and chronolocation, tracking ships and planes, and how to break news with satellite imagery.

This session is good for: people with some data experience. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.
track: Beat reporting, Data analysis, Data viz

speakers.bio: Michael Biesecker is a global investigative reporter for The Associated Press. Biesecker’s work tracking potential war crimes in Ukraine was recognized with the 2022 IRE Gold Medal, as well as the top award for investigative reporting from the Overseas Press Club of America. He was a contributor to the AP team that won the 2023 Pulitzer Prize for Public Service. Biesecker also teaches investigative and environmental reporting at Georgetown University.

session_title: R 3: Gathering and cleaning data
description:
Learn how to use R to scrape data from web pages, access APIs and transform the results into usable data. This session will also focus on how to clean and structure the data you've gathered in preparation for analysis using tidyverse packages.

This session is good for: People who have used R and have a basic understanding of how to retrieve data from APIs. Laptops will be provided.

speakers.bio: Aaron Kessler has been an active member of IRE for two decades. He’s an award-winning journalist, teacher, and project leader who specializes in investigative reporting and data analysis at the nexus of business and politics. He currently works on the data team at The Associated Press, based in Washington, DC. Aaron has been a shoe-leather reporter, writer, data practitioner, and coder, and uses those combined skills to uncover the truth behind issues of public importance.

session_title: Reporting on mass shootings, responsibly
description: This panel will talk about how to navigate reporting on such a large-scale tragedy. Some of the topics will include the contagion effect and how your reporting may or may not contribute to the described phenomenon. We’ll discuss what we’ve included in our coverage and what we haven’t and the process by which we came to those conclusions. Panelists will also discuss lessons learned from covering such events.
track: Reporting and writing strategies, Beat reporting

speakers.bio: Manny García is an award-winning news executive and a former president of the IRE. He is being honored this year in IRE's Ring of Honor. Manny is a mentor and newsroom leader. He is the recipient of the Benjamin C. Bradlee Editor of the Year award for his coverage of Uvalde. As a reporter and editor, he has been part of Pulitzer-Prize-winning projects.

Natalia Martinez is a multiple award-winning investigative journalist and Executive Producer for WAVE Originals. For 15 years her work has focused on corruption, law enforcement and violence. She produces documentary films and special content at WAVE News and Gray Media, pioneering a new approach to in-depth story-telling. Her latest released documentary, 23 Seconds: A Louisville Mass Shooting received praise for its approach to reporting on a mass shooter.

Naseem Miller is senior health editor at The Journalist’s Resource, a project of the Shorenstein Center at Harvard Kennedy School. In addition to covering health, she writes about the intersection of journalism and trauma. She’s also part of Dart Center’s training team. Miller was part of the Orlando Sentinel team named a 2016 Pulitzer Prize finalist for coverage of the Pulse nightclub mass shooting. She co-started and administers the Journalists Covering Trauma Facebook group.

session_title: Reporting on stigmatized public health issues
description: Stigma and shame often prevents treatment for public wellness issues like substance abuse, mental health, HIV/AIDS, and financial instability. This panel provides insight and best-practices when covering these stigmatized topics, as well as the importance of understanding the role of "culpable control" in storytelling and the role the media plays in access to care.

speakers.bio: Terri Langford is a University of Texas at Austin graduate and health reporter for The Texas Tribune. She has worked for several news organizations including the Associated Press, the Houston Chronicle, WNYC, KUT/Texas Standard and The Dallas Morning News.

Shefali Luthra covers reproductive health for The 19th, where her coverage of pregnancy-related health has been recognized with a Murrow Award and an Online Journalism Award. Her book UNDUE BURDEN: Life and Death Decisions in Post-Roe America investigated the consequences of abortion bans in the first year after the fall of Roe v. Wade and was a finalist for the Kirkus Prize. Before joining The 19th, she covered national health policy for KFF Health News.

Amy Silverman is a journalist, teacher and author in her hometown, Phoenix. She's executive producer of KJZZ-NPR's The Show and a columnist for PHOENIX magazine. Amy often focuses on intellectual disability and how to make journalism more accessible to and inclusive of people with ID – like her daughter, Sophie, who has Down syndrome. Amy's work has appeared on This American Life, ProPublica and Slate, among others. More at amy-silverman.com

session_title: Show & Tell: Anything goes (traditional)
description:
Sign up to “Show & Tell” us about your best work and get constructive feedback from the moderator and audience. 

Sign-ups are required for presenters. Each presenter will have 15 minutes to share their work and receive feedback. All are welcome to attend!

Sign up here: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/10C084CA8AC29A4FBCE9-57104082-show

*These sessions will not be recorded.

speakers.bio: Nicole has worked as an investigative journalist in television for more than 30 years. She most recently worked as the Executive Producer of Content Development for CBS News and Stations. She previously led the investigative team at KUSA in Denver.

session_title: Spinning story gold from piles of data and docs
description: No matter how powerful our findings from data and documents, we still need people to propel our story. We’ll show how you can dive into data, docs and other troves of records to find them. We’ll also touch on the needs of different media, showing, for example, how the right character for print might be the wrong character for TV.
track: Data analysis, Reporting and writing strategies

speakers.bio: Ivana is an investigative reporter covering the Alabama criminal justice system and prisons. A native of Birmingham, she has been a Livingston finalist and was named one of Tomorrow’s News Trailblazers by E&P Magazine. Her work has been recognized by the American Bar Association’s Silver Gavel Awards, IRE, the National Headliner Awards, and more. Ivana has experience in audio, digital, and print reporting and formerly hosted a daily live news show.

Craig Lyons is the managing editor at the Arnolt Center for Investigative Journalism. Lyons has spent over 15 years covering government agencies at the local, state, and federal levels in Michigan, Indiana, New Hampshire, Vermont, and Maine. Lyons’ work has earned recognition from the Chicago Headline Club, the Michigan Press Association, the Hoosier State Press Association, and the Indiana Chapter of the Society of Professional Journalists.

Taylor Mirfendereski is a two-time Peabody Award-winning multimedia investigative journalist. Her stories have led to new state laws, institutional reforms, and public policy changes protecting society’s most vulnerable populations, including people with disabilities, incarcerated people, and foster youth. She most recently worked at KING-TV in Seattle. She handles every aspect of digital and broadcast story production, from reporting and writing to photography and video.

session_title: Tracking prices and stock in the wake of economic uncertainty
description:
Swift changes in policy and reactions resulted in massive price hikes, but are more coming? Industry experts also warned about impacts on the supply chain- are we on our way to empty store shelves 2.0? In this session, we’ll look at available data and resources to track this and explain how policy is impacting your audience. 

This session is sponsored by Bright Data. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

speakers.bio: Jennifer launched a pro-bono data journalism program Bright Journalism, that now supports newsrooms and journalists around the world. After decades in the industry, Jennifer now leads communications and public relations at Bright Data, a web data infrastructure company for AI and BI. Here, she discovered an opportunity to support her former colleagues and peers by offering tools to extract and analyze data for free to newsrooms.

Award-winning investigative data journalist Alexander Cohen has exposed lobbying, campaign finance, government, and business secrets, built newsroom tools, and trained reporters nationwide. His work has appeared in Bloomberg News, The Center for Public Integrity, The Washington Post, The New York Times, Politico, The Atlantic, The Daily Beast, and other outlets.

session_title: Riverboat cruise
description:
Come help us celebrate IRE's 50th anniversary New Orleans style -- cruising along the mighty Mississippi.

This two-hour cruise will include live music, appetizers, a pasta station, dessert and an open bar. You won't want to miss this one-of-a-kind affair! Ticket proceeds will go into our 50th anniversary fund to support IRE training programs.

Boarding begins at 6 p.m. The barge will depart promply at 7 p.m.

More information: https://www.ire.org/training/conferences/ire-2025/ire25-riverboat-cruise-faq/

session_title: Audio track: Driveway moments: Crafting stories that stop listeners in their tracks
description: Investigative journalism meets powerful storytelling in this panel designed for audio creators aiming to create those unforgettable "driveway moments"—when listeners can’t turn off the story even after arriving at their destination. Panelists will explore how to build suspense, evoke emotion, and connect with audiences on a deeply personal level while staying true to the investigative rigor. From scene-setting to pacing, attendees will gain practical strategies for turning complex investigations into gripping, memorable audio experiences.

speakers.bio: Lauren Chooljian is a senior reporter/producer on NHPR's Document team, a narrative-driven, longform reporting project. She is the host and reporter behind The 13th Step, a podcast about sexual misconduct in the addiction treatment industry, which was a finalist for the 2024 Pulitzer Prize in audio reporting. Before joining NHPR in 2017, Lauren spent nearly six years as a reporter, producer and fill-in host for WBEZ in Chicago.

Meribah Knight is a senior reporter at Nashville Public Radio. She’s the host and creator of the Peabody Award-winning podcast "The Promise," as well as Serial’s "The Kids of Rutherford County" and NPR’s "Supermajority" (2025 Peabody nominee). Meribah has received numerous national awards, including the George Foster Peabody Award and the George Polk Award, and she was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize, the Goldsmith Award, and twice for a National Magazine Award.

Julieta Martinelli is an investigative reporter and senior producer leading narrative long form reporting on criminal justice and immigration at Futuro Media. She most recently reported and co-produced season 1 of "Suave," which was awarded the 2022 Pulitzer Prize in audio reporting and was the International Documentary Association's audio series of the year. She is the senior producer and host of season 2, which explores the complexities of re-entry.

Paige Pfleger is the criminal justice reporter at WPLN news in Nashville, where she has investigated gun dispossession, domestic violence and juvenile justice as a fellow with ProPublica’s Local Reporting Network. Her work was a finalist for a Livingston Award and an Investigative Reporters and Editors Award, and she has appeared nationally on NPR, The Washington Post, Marketplace and more.

session_title: Belonging under fire: In an era of backlash against diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts
description: Belonging Under Fire: In an era of backlash against diversity, equity, and belonging efforts—both inside newsrooms and in the broader society—how can investigative journalists deepen their own internal cultures while sharpening their external reporting on systems of exclusion? This panel explores how newsrooms can stay committed to equitable hiring and retention while also elevating stories about the erosion of civil rights, attacks on marginalized communities, and systemic barriers to truth-telling. How do we sustain equitable practices in our own newsrooms amid legal, political, and institutional resistance? How do we rebuild trust with communities whose lives and truths are too often overlooked or extracted? This session explores how a deep commitment to belonging—internally and externally—can make investigative journalism more ethical, impactful, and trusted. Panelists will examine how relational journalism practices and inclusive newsroom cultures together fuel more nuanced investigations and broader democratic participation. This session is presented in partnership with the Maynard Institute.

speakers.bio: Manny García is an award-winning news executive and a former president of the IRE. He is being honored this year in IRE's Ring of Honor. Manny is a mentor and newsroom leader. He is the recipient of the Benjamin C. Bradlee Editor of the Year award for his coverage of Uvalde. As a reporter and editor, he has been part of Pulitzer-Prize-winning projects.

Marla Jones Newman is the VP of People and Culture of Mother Jones/Reveal. She is an alumnus of the Maynard 200 Executive Leaders training program and the Executive Program for Nonprofit Leaders at Stanford University. Marla has over 20 years of HR experience employing best human capital practices to attract and retain talent. Throughout her career, she has created and implemented Diverse, Equitable, Inclusive, and Belonging initiatives.

speakers.affiliation: The Journalist's Resource at Harvard Kennedy School
speakers.bio: Denise-Marie Ordway is managing editor of The Journalist’s Resource at Harvard Kennedy School. Previously, she reported news in English and Spanish for several major news outlets in the U.S. and Central America. She received national and regional journalism awards and, in 2013, was a Pulitzer Prize finalist for an investigation of Florida A&M University she led. She's an Education Writers Association board member and fellow of Harvard’s Nieman Foundation for Journalism.

Martin Reynolds oversees fundraising, client relations, and external affairs at the Maynard Institute, where he also serves as lead Fault Lines® diversity trainer. He co-founded Oakland Voices, now in its 15th year, and formerly directed the Reveal Investigative Fellowship. A former editor-in-chief of The Oakland Tribune, he served as a lead editor on the Chauncey Bailey Project. He sits on Cityside’s board and once recorded a live album in Havana, Cuba, as a lyricist.

session_title: Broadcast track: Visual data on deadline

speakers.bio: Robin Carter is a Special Projects Photojournalist for NBC 5 Responds, using impactful storytelling to help North Texans navigate consumer issues. With over 30 years of experience in TV news across Virginia, Texas, and Florida, Robin’s work has earned 13 regional Emmy awards.

Ryann Grochowski Jones is the director of data journalism at ABC News and Owned Television Stations. Previously, she was the data editor at ProPublica and an investigative data reporter at inewsource in San Diego, California. Ryann received her master's degree from the University of Missouri School of Journalism, where she was a data librarian at IRE/NICAR. Ryann began her career as a municipal beat reporter for her hometown newspaper in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania.

Aubry Killion is a seven-time regional Emmy Award-winning investigative reporter for WDSU-TV in New Orleans. He excels in crafting compelling stories that simplify complex information, under tight deadlines.

session_title: Cracking the code: How to read local government budgets
description:
Local government budgets are plans — Hopes. Dreams. Needs. Priorities. They reflect power. They make promises. In this session, you’ll learn how to read them and how to find the enterprise stories in the numbers. I’ll also share takeaways from public finance professionals, including how they navigate the politics in the budgeting process. Lessons in this session apply to all local council, commission, school and authority budgets.

This session is good for all levels of experience! Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

speakers.affiliation: The Public Ledger / War Streets Media
speakers.bio: A veteran journalist, AmyJo Brown’s work focuses on the organizational challenges specific to doing good journalism at the local level, particularly related to government coverage. She is building The Public Ledger, a data tool & strategy designed to map local power structures. As a consulting editor, she works currently with the Texas Tribune & LNP Media Group. AmyJo was a 2022-2023 Knight Lab fellow at NU & founding project director of the Pittsburgh Media Partnership.

session_title: Ethically covering the impact of abortion bans
description: Twelve states have banned abortion and the federal government is eyeing unprecedented action to take those policies nationwide. On this panel, we'll help you understand how to cover the impact of these bans on real people, from women with complicated pregnancies, families who have lost loved ones, doctors facing pressure from their institutions and people who are being criminalized for performing or receiving care. Leave this panel with tangible tips on ethically approaching these thorny stories.
track: Gender & reproductive rights, Beat reporting, Criminal legal system

speakers.bio: Ziva Branstetter has edited and managed investigations honored with over 15 national awards. Since 2022, she has helped lead ProPublica's "Life of the Mother" investigation, exposing the deaths of five pregnant women in abortion-ban states, honored with the Pulitzer Prize for public service. She has held editing roles at The Washington Post and Reveal and founded The Frontier, an Oklahoma startup. She's a former IRE board member.

Cassandra Jaramillo is a national reporter at ProPublica, covering reproductive health and voting rights. She recently won the Pulitzer Prize in Public Service reporting, along with three colleagues, for revealing how state abortion bans have warped maternal medicine and led to preventable deaths. In 2023, she was a finalist for the Livingston Award and won an Edward Murrow for investigative radio reporting in a team effort at the Center for Investigative Reporting.

Eleanor Klibanoff is the women’s health reporter at The Texas Tribune, where she covers abortion, maternal health care, gender-based violence and LGBTQ issues, among other topics. She also cohosts the weekly politics podcast, TribCast. She started with the Tribune in 2021, and was previously with the Kentucky Center for Investigative Reporting in Louisville, where she reported, produced and hosted the Peabody-nominated podcast, “Dig.”

Shefali Luthra covers reproductive health for The 19th, where her coverage of pregnancy-related health has been recognized with a Murrow Award and an Online Journalism Award. Her book UNDUE BURDEN: Life and Death Decisions in Post-Roe America investigated the consequences of abortion bans in the first year after the fall of Roe v. Wade and was a finalist for the Kirkus Prize. Before joining The 19th, she covered national health policy for KFF Health News.

session_title: Investigating the impact of alternative energy
description: As the world races to decarbonize, demand for minerals like lithium, cobalt, and copper is surging—fueling a global mining boom. Large-scale wind and solar farms are also expanding rapidly, often with significant impacts on local communities and ecosystems. Much of this new development, both in the U.S. and globally, is happening on the lands of Indigenous Peoples and other marginalized groups, raising urgent questions about environmental justice and corporate accountability. This session will offer investigative reporters practical tools for covering the energy transition: how to connect with affected communities in the United States and internationally, trace supply chains to link harmful projects to major brands, and hold corporations and governments to account.

speakers.bio: Annie Burns-Pieper is Deputy Research Director at Inclusive Development International, a human rights NGO where she leads follow-the-money investigations into harmful corporate practices in the Global South. Also an investigative reporter, she has 15 years of experience with Canadian teams at The Globe and Mail, CBC, and CTV, and internationally with Al Jazeera. She specializes in public interest investigations focused on health, gender, and corporate accountability.

B. "Toastie" Oaster (they/them) is an award-winning Indigenous affairs journalist and a staff writer for High Country News. They write from the Pacific Northwest, and they are a citizen of the Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma.

Sheridan Prasso is a senior writer for investigations at Bloomberg. Her reporting has traced aluminum in the Ford F-150EV to deforestation and pollution in the Amazon rainforest. As a long-time China specialist, she has also explored the environmental impact of China's quest for iron ore in Africa; exposed forced labor in US solar supply chains, including polysilicon from Xinjiang; and linked fast-fashion retailer Shein to forced-labor cotton using laboratory testing.

session_title: Lights! Camera! Investigation!
description: The panelists want to invite the audience to join us in exploring the ways that novels and movies can help with structuring narrative investigations and getting past writing obstacles. The panelists will show clips of films or play snippets of recorded novels that served as creative fodder for powerful journalistic stories. The audience is encouraged to bring their own examples of movies, novels or short stories that helped in developing an investigative story. At the end we’ll compile a group list.

speakers.bio: Jennifer Forsyth is the Washington Investigations Editor for The New York Times, tasked with exposing corruption. Previously, she was The Wall Street Journal’s deputy chief of investigations. She’s had the privilege of editing stories by dogged reporters that have won a Pulitzer Prize, a Gerald Loeb award and the Worth Bingham award for investigative journalism. A collaboration with Frontline was an Emmy finalist for outstanding investigative documentary.

Elizabeth Koh is an investigative reporter on the Boston Globe’s Spotlight Team, writing about health care, social services and government accountability. Previously, she was a Seoul correspondent for The Wall Street Journal and a state politics reporter at the Miami Herald. She has been a Pulitzer finalist twice: in 2021 with Journal colleagues for stories on Covid-19 in nursing homes, and in 2025 as part of a Globe team covering the collapse of a major hospital chain.

J. David McSwane is an award-losing reporter for ProPublica, an award-winning investigative nonprofit. His reporting on COVID profiteers led to his first book, "Pandemic, Inc." He is under contract for a second book based on his 2024 investigation "Eat What You Kill." He sucks at pickleball.

session_title: Master class: It’s just video…until a storyteller creates an experience
description:
Tried and true drivers of the narrative: focus, surprise, suspense, and character are powerful tools. It’s time to put them to work in your stories. Together, let’s answer the questions, why do we laugh, why do we cry, why do we care — and how can we make it happen for our viewers more often? Boyd Huppert will open wide the toolbox that’s helped him earn an unprecedented 26 National Edward R. Murrow Awards in both hard news and feature reporting. 

Topics will include:
* Creating interactive – not passive – viewing experiences
* The first :30 -- hooking viewers with powerful opens
* How to avoid emotion-draining clichés
* Unlocking the hidden power in sentences
* Literary devices that will breathe life in your writing 
* Creating moment-driven stories viewers will remember long after the newscast ends 

Bring your notepad. This session will be loaded with practical tips to bring back to your newsroom and your next story.  

Preregistration is required and seating is limited.

speakers.bio: During his 41-year career in television news, Boyd Huppert has become widely known as a video storyteller and teacher. Boyd is marking his 29th year at KARE TV in Minneapolis. Boyd also serves as National Storytelling Coach for the 49 newsrooms of TEGNA. Boyd's work has earned 26 National Edward R. Murrow Awards, multiple National Headliner and Sigma Delta Chi Awards, the Scripps Howard Award, a national Emmy, and 168 regional Emmys.

session_title: Master class: Managing investigators… or how to lead journalists born to challenge authority (50th Anniversary Edition)
description:
You asked for it! More training for investigative managers! Since 2022, IRE has held seven master class sessions and trained more than 250 members on this exact topic. And the session at IRE25 will be BIG! We're throwing in some new, exciting features for our organization's 50th anniversary!

Here's why: We know managing investigative journalists comes with an extra layer of challenges because their very job (and likely their personality) makes them hyper-alert to authority figures. This course is designed to give you some tools and tactics to lead individuals and entire teams of investigators more effectively. Learn from five investigative managers from different media at different stages of their leadership careers. How did they launch into their roles, and what experience have they gained along the way?

This course is for current investigative managers and anyone aspiring to step into such a position in the future. Topics will include: managing compassionately, hiring challenges, transitioning to management, forging partnerships, building relationships, handling resource cuts, organization/structure, tough decisions/conversations, in-house training/growth, delivering feedback, creating inclusive opportunities, and juggling responsibilities/projects/work.

Preregistration is required and seating is limited.

speakers.bio: Josh Hinkle is KXAN’s director of investigations and innovation, leading the station’s duPont and IRE Award-winning investigative team on multiple platforms. He also leads KXAN’s political coverage as executive producer and host of “State of Texas,” a weekly statewide program focused on the Texas Legislature and elections. In 2021, he was elected to the IRE Board of Directors and currently serves as its vice president.

Dianna Hunt is national editor/news director at ICT/Indian Country Today. She directed and edited the Pulitzer Prize-finalist breaking news coverage of Hurricane Harvey while metro editor at the Houston Chronicle, and also worked for the Dallas Morning News, Fort Worth Star-Telegram and other publications. She served three terms on the IRE board and is currently on the boards for the Fund for Investigative Journalism and Investigative Editing Corps.

Kat Stafford is the global race and justice editor for Reuters. She has received several awards for her work, including the National Press Club Journalism Institute's 2023 Neil and Susan Sheehan Award for Investigative Journalism and the 2024 Spirit of Diversity Award from Wayne State University's Journalism Institute for Media Diversity. She was a 2022 University of Michigan Knight-Wallace fellow.

Mc Nelly Torres is an award-winning investigative journalist and former editor at the Center for Public Integrity where she led a team investigating inequality. Before, Torres worked as an investigative producer for NBC6 in Miami and co-founded FCIR.org. She is a product of newspapers including the Sun-Sentinel and the San Antonio Express-News. Torres was the first Latina elected to the IRE board of directors. In 2022, Torres was a recipient of the Gwen Ifill Award.

Nicole has worked as an investigative journalist in television for more than 30 years. She most recently worked as the Executive Producer of Content Development for CBS News and Stations. She previously led the investigative team at KUSA in Denver.

session_title: Navigating interviews on sensitive topics and in challenging settings
description: Effective interviewing is crucial to impactful journalism, but these interactions can quickly become fraught in environments where sources are vulnerable or institutions are opaque. We'll teach you how to navigate these obstacles across different beats and communities, including in jails and prisons, child detention centers, indigenous communities and medical settings.
track: "Equity - inclusion - accessibility", Reporting and writing strategies

speakers.bio: Lauren Caruba is an investigative reporter for The Dallas Morning News. She previously covered health, medicine and the COVID-19 pandemic at the San Antonio Express-News. Her 2023 series on a nationwide epidemic of preventable bleeding deaths was recognized by IRE, the Philip Meyer Awards, the Online News Association and the National Association of Science Writers. She is a three-time finalist for the Livingston Awards.

Greg Fisher is a west coast producer for CBS News 48 Hours. Greg has been a network broadcast producer for more than 30 years, and a supervisor at 48 Hours. Greg spent 16 years as an investigative producer for ABC News 20/20 and PrimeTime. Greg has won the National Press Club Award, an Emmy Award for Investigative Reporting and Breaking News, a duPont-Columbia Award and others. He began his career as a radio and newspaper reporter.

Kelly Garcia reports on youths, prisons and the court system. Before joining Injustice Watch in 2022, Kelly was a staff writer at the Chicago Reader, where she wrote about news and politics on the Southwest Side. In 2022, the Chicago Journalists Association named her Emerging Journalist of the Year for her reporting on the private music festivals occupying Douglass Park.

Neal Morton writes about education and young people in the American West for the Hechinger Report, where he covers K-12 schools in 10 states. He previously worked with the Education Lab team for The Seattle Times and reported on public and higher education in Nevada and Texas.

session_title: Networking: Freelancers
description: Mix and mingle, meet friends old and new, and build your professional community in this fun and informal networking session. This session is for people who work as freelancers.

speakers.bio: Elaine Aradillas has spent her career writing about crime. For 15 years, she worked at PEOPLE magazine as a senior writer and covered high-profile national cases, including 20 mass shootings. Her expertise has been featured on Dateline, GMA, HLN and more. She co-authored a book and taught journalism at Syracuse University. She has three documentaries in development. She earned an MS at Columbia University’s Graduate School of Journalism and a BA at the University of Texas.

Candace Y.A. Montague is a journalist based in Washington, DC, with over 15 years of experience covering health, gender equality, and social justice for local and national publications. She is an award-winning freelancer and a member of the Washington Association of Black Journalists, the National Association of Black Journalists, and the Ida B. Wells Investigative Society.

session_title: One-on-one with Barry Nash & Co. (Saturday)
description:
Barry Nash and his team return to IRE to provide personalized coaching sessions. If you have questions about any aspect of your delivery — your appearance, how you use your voice, how you can perform most effectively in the field or in the studio — this is an opportunity you won’t want to miss. Barry has been working with talent at all levels of experience and ability for over 30 years.

Please note: Participants should bring recent footage on a flash drive, webpage/online link, or storage drive (Google or Dropbox).

Click here to sign up: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/10C084CA8AC29A4FBCE9-57105395-barry#/

session_title: Show & Tell: Ideas workshop: Come show or discuss your project that hasn't aired yet to get feedback/ideas
description:
Sign up to “Show & Tell” us about your best work and get constructive feedback from the moderator and audience. 

Sign-ups are required for presenters. Each presenter will have 15 minutes to share their work and receive feedback. All are welcome to attend!

Sign up here: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/10C084CA8AC29A4FBCE9-57104366-show

*These sessions will not be recorded.

speakers.bio: Ross Weidner is the Assistant News Director at ABC11 WTVD, the ABC-owned television Station in Raleigh-Durham-Fayetteville, North Carolina. Ross is an experienced newsroom leader who specializes in breaking news response, special projects team management, data journalism and quick-turn investigations. Prior to his current role, Ross worked as a special projects producer and investigative producer at WLS in Chicago.

session_title: Storyball: Finding ideas in sports data
description:
Sports is absolutely drowning in data and there is a large and hungry audience for sports content. Alongside that, there's a large and growing open-source sports analytics community that data journalists should be a part of. In this hands-on class, I will take you through examples of ways to use traditional data journalism tools like R and the Tidyverse to bring in up-to-the-moment sports data and do sophisticated analysis that you can immediately visualize to add context to seasons, leagues and sports.

This session is good for people comfortable running commands on their computers. Attendees will need to bring their own laptop (no tablets) for the training and should have a GitHub account.

speakers.bio: Derek Willis teaches and does data journalism at the Philip Merrill College of Journalism at the University of Maryland. He's been coming to NICAR since the late 1990s.

session_title: Unsung documents
description: Veteran investigative reporters reprise a classic panel and list obscure but powerful documents that anyone can use to turbocharge a project or bulk-up daily beat coverage. They also provide practical guidelines for unearthing, scrutinizing, managing and cross-referencing routine documents to unleash their full investigative power.

speakers.bio: A multiple Pulitzer Prize winner, Grimaldi is executive editor of the National Catholic Reporter, one of the oldest independent nonprofit news organizations in the country. Grimaldi is a seasoned investigative reporter who has worked for six newspapers, including The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal. A frequent college lecturer, he is on the steering committee of the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press and is past president of IRE.

Thompson is an award-winning investigative correspondent and senior editor for investigations for NPR. Before joining NPR in 2019, she spent 22 years covering law enforcement and political corruption for The Washington Post, and was part of teams that won the Pulitzer for National Reporting in 2002 and 2016. She was the reporting coach on the NPR podcast "No Compromise," which won the Pulitzer Prize for Audio Reporting in 2021.

session_title: Using OpenRefine, a power tool for cleaning data
description:
Learn how to use OpenRefine, a powerful tool for quickly cleaning up dirty data. You'll learn about faceting, simple clustering, applying common data transformations and more.

This session is good for people with basic experience working with data. Laptops will be provided.

speakers.bio: Christian McDonald is an associate professor of practice and the innovation director in the School of Journalism and Media at the University of Texas at Austin, where he teaches classes on data, coding, and news products. His last newsroom position was as data and online projects editor at the Austin American-Statesman. In his 28 years in journalism, he also worked at the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, East Valley (Arizona) Tribune and the Longview (Texas) News-Journal.

session_title: One-on-one coaching for audio journalists (Saturday)
description: Audio journalists can sign up for a one-on-one coaching session at various times during the conference. Click here to sign up: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/10C084CA8AC29A4FBCE9-57105620-audio#/

session_title: A year in local investigations: Watchdog story ideas
description: Learn new and old tricks from the stories and reporters featured in the Local Matters newsletter, which spotlights a selection of great local watchdog journalism every Sunday. By showcasing a year of great work by radio, TV and newspaper reporters, we'll share tactics and tips for digging deep into stories at your local media outlet.

speakers.bio: Bethany Barnes is the deputy investigative editor at the Tampa Bay Times. Barnes previously worked at The Oregonian, where her coverage of Portland Public Schools prompted the Education Writers Association to name her the nation’s best education reporter. Before that, she was a reporter in Las Vegas. Barnes is one of four journalists who put together Local Matters, a free weekly newsletter that rounds up the nation's best local investigative reporting.

speakers.affiliation: The Times-Picayune | The New Orleans Advocate

session_title: Audio track: “Getting to yes” with NPR’s Embedded: Writing the perfect podcast pitch
description:
You’ve been crunching the numbers and following the paper trail for years. You’re confident that your investigation is going to reveal something new, and you think it’d make a great narrative podcast series. In a crowded industry, how do you catch the ear of the people who can help you do it?

NPR’s Embedded team will help you tell the story of your story. In this interactive session, we’ll dive into the essential elements we look for in serialized podcasts, teaching you how to identify compelling characters, formulate sticky questions and create narrative momentum. Along the way, you’ll learn how to pitch Embedded — NPR’s home for ambitious, deeply reported documentary series.

speakers.bio: As senior producer for NPR’s Embedded podcast, Adelina Lancianese works on documentary series such as “Supermajority," which was named one of the best podcasts of 2024 by The New Yorker. Her work has also been recognized by the National Press Foundation, the Peabody awards and the Murrow awards. Formerly, Adelina was a producer for NPR shows Rough Translation, On Our Watch and Louder Than A Riot, and she co-led the Story Lab Workshop. Adelina was a 2017 Kroc fellow.

Katie Simon is the Supervising Senior Editor for Embedded, NPR's home for documentary journalism. Before Embedded, she was a founding editor at StoryCorps. She's made long-form podcasts for WNYC and freelanced for ESPN. She got her start in audio as a reporter in Newark, NJ. Simon has won a DuPont award, two Peabody awards (five nominations), and has multiple Emmy nominations. She graduated from Kenyon College and Columbia University's School of Journalism.

Luis Trelles is a senior editor at NPR’s Embedded, where he helps shape ambitious, documentary-style podcast series like “Alternate Realities”, “A Good Guy”, and “The Last Cup.” He has worked with a range of storytellers to develop narrative approaches tailored to each project. Before joining Embedded, he edited for Latino USA and began his audio career at Radio Ambulante, where he focused on telling nuanced, character-driven stories from across Latin America.

session_title: Broadcast track: Art of the interview

speakers.bio: Scott Friedman leads the NBC 5 Investigates team at the NBC network-owned television station in Dallas-Fort Worth. He is a two-time Peabody, duPont-Columbia, and IRE Award winner.

Andy Pierrotti is a national award-winning investigative reporter with WANF-TV, CBS in Atlanta recognized with the duPont Columbia Award, George Foster Peabody, multiple Emmy and Edward R. Murrow awards.

Chief Investigator Darcy Spears has won 23 Emmys, 10 (including 2 national) Edward R. Murrow Awards, AP awards, and is in the Nevada Broadcasters Association Hall of Fame. She's a graduate of U.C. Berkeley and the Medill School of Journalism.

session_title: How to write character-driven features about climate change and the environment
description: There may be no topic in contemporary journalism more dauntingly abstract than climate change: Carbon emissions are invisible and impersonal, and even though their consequences are increasingly apparent in the environment around us, the link between those effects and human action is frustratingly opaque. However, the scale of the challenge requires journalists to find ways to connect this seemingly overwhelming process to recognizable human dilemmas and conflicts. This panel discusses the ways that reporters can center human (and non-human) drama to better illuminate contemporary environmental dilemmas.

speakers.bio: Adam Mahoney is the national climate and environment reporter at Capital B News. He has reported from more than a dozen U.S. states and Palestine, Mexico, Uganda, and Vietnam for newspapers including the New York Times and The Guardian. He is the co-author (with Judith Enck) of The Problem with Plastic: How We Can Save Ourselves and Our Planet Before It's Too Late (The New Press), he lives in New Orleans, Louisiana.

Naveena Sadasivam is an investigative journalist at Grist who covers the oil and gas industry and climate change. She previously worked at the Texas Observer, Inside Climate News, and ProPublica and has won accolades from the Society of Environmental Journalists, Society of Professional Journalists, Online News Association, and Radio Television Digital News Association. She is based in Oakland, California.

John Thomason is the Features Editor at Grist, a nonprofit newsroom that has covered climate change since its founding in 1999. Prior to joining Grist in 2020, John was the Research Editor at The Intercept. He has edited stories that have won awards from the American Society of Magazine Editors, the Hillman Foundation, the Online News Association, and the Radio Television Digital News Association.

Boyce Upholt is a writer and "nature critic" based in New Orleans. His first book, The Great River: The Making and Unmaking of the Mississippi, was published by W.W. Norton in 2025 and won the Willie Morris Award for Southern Writing.

session_title: Internet Archive, Wayback Machine & TV News Archive: Everything you need to know
description:
What exactly is “in scope” for the mission of “Universal Access To All Knowledge”?
Come for an overview and update.  With a special focus on efforts to preserve material from the US Government as part of our Democracy’s Library program. 
Mark Graham, Director of the Wayback Machine will outline core services, especially those most useful to investigative journalism.  
Please come with your questions and most importantly your requests.  We are always interested in learning how we can be a better library.

speakers.bio: Mark Graham is the director of the Wayback Machine at the Internet Archive, overseeing the daily archiving of millions of Web pages. He previously served as senior vice president at NBC News Digital and iVillage and co-founded Rojo Networks. Mark also played a key role in AOL’s Internet Center and co-founded PeaceNet and the Association for Progressive Communications. He began his career while in the U.S. Air Force advocating for nuclear disarmament.

session_title: Leveraging AI to enhance political accountability
description: How can AI be used to hold politicians accountable for their promises, claims and speech? This session will share the findings of a landscape study on how AI is being used by journalists around the country today. We will demonstrate one of the tools that has been leveraged by Wisconsin Watch and others—Gigafact Parser, a shared database for journalists that summarizes and analyzes audio and video records of politicians’ speeches. Attendees can expect to learn about Parser and other cutting-edge tools, hear case studies for their use, and get a better understanding of the state of AI in journalism.

speakers.bio: Matthew DeFour started in September 2022 as Wisconsin Watch's first state bureau chief. Previously at the Wisconsin State Journal, he covered state and local government for 16 years, including four years as state politics editor. He has a BSJ and MSJ from Northwestern University's Medill School of Journalism. He was honored by his peers as the 2020 Wisconsin Watchdog of the Year.

speakers.affiliation: Consulting Project Lead, Product & AI Studio
speakers.bio: Justen Fox began his career in technology working with digital media and publishing organizations such as The New Republic, Time, and Vox Media, before leading product teams at Bankrate and Run for Something. For the past six years, he has served as a fractional product and engineering consultant. He is currently a Project Lead with the American Journalism Project’s Product & AI Studio, where he supports local newsrooms in integrating generative AI tools into their work.

Chandran Sankaran is the founder and CEO of Gigafact, a nonprofit accelerating local fact checking in the U.S. Sankaran has previously been a successful software entrepreneur. He has degrees in engineering and computer science from the Indian Institute of Technology and Yale University. Sankaran is based in the San Francisco Bay Area, and he is a member of the advisory committee of Press Forward Silicon Valley.

Robyn is Gigafact’s director of operations. She is responsible for building and supporting the network, guiding the product roadmap, and ensuring high impact results for publishers. Robyn is a former researcher at USC Annenberg School of Journalism, where she taught courses on journalism and propaganda. Prior to that, she worked as a campaign manager in Alaska and as a public affairs consultant with the National Journal in Washington, DC. Robyn lives in Salt Lake City.

session_title: Me Too isn’t over: Lessons from both sides of sexual harassment and violence investigations
description: What have we learned since the Me Too movement reached a zenith in 2017? For starters, sexual misconduct is everywhere (including the journalism industry) and requires diligent and trauma-informed reporting. This panel will cover hard-learned lessons from eight years of reporting and editing sexual misconduct investigations — and from unexpectedly finding ourselves as sources on the other side. We’ll cover the ways we still get this reporting wrong, from pushing traumatized sources too hard to go on-record, to discounting nontraditional records like journal entries or social media messages, to the he-said-she-said of it all. And, we’ll finally put to rest the notion that lived experience is a disqualifier for journalists covering this topic.

speakers.bio: Cara Kelly is an editor-at-large for The Barbed Wire. Her reporting has uncovered sexual misconduct in massage schools, ride-share companies, and the Boy Scouts. She spent five years on USA Today’s investigations team after covering the Me Too movement as entertainment editor. Now based in D.C., she’s also an adjunct professor at American University and an honorary member of the Texas press corps after a yearlong investigation for Texas Monthly.

Olivia Messer is editor-in-chief of The Barbed Wire. Her decade of investigative reporting on the Texas Legislature has exposed sexual abuse and led to reforms. A Houston native and former Waco crime reporter, she’s written for The Daily Beast, Rolling Stone, Slate, and more. Now based in Austin, Olivia’s debut novel, Something’s Wrong With the Girls, is forthcoming from Rare Bird.

Award-winning journalist Leslie Rangel is a first-gen daughter of Mexican and Guatemalan immigrants and the senior editor of investigations at The Barbed Wire. She’s Emmy-nominated, UN-recognized, and reports at the intersection of wellness, race, gender, and justice. A former TV anchor and 2023 Chauncey Bailey fellow, she co-authored Journalists Break News, Don’t Let It Break You and founded The News Yogi mental wellness coaching practice.

session_title: Networking: International journalists
description:
Mix and mingle, meet friends old and new, and build your professional community in this fun and informal networking session.
This session is for people who work outside of the U.S.

speakers.bio: Patricia Marcano is an investigative journalist and editor from Venezuela. She is part of the editorial team at Armando.info (a Venezuelan media outlet), and her work includes covering corruption, money laundering, and human rights violations, as well as coordinating the newsroom and the Venezuelan chapter of the FinCEN Files and the Pandora Papers. She is currently a Fulbright Scholar pursuing a master's degree in journalism at Ohio University and an Alfred Friendly Press Partners Fellow.

Paroma Soni is a Data and Graphics Reporter at Politico, where she covers trade, agriculture, and immigration. She was previously an Associate Visual Journalist at FiveThirtyEight. Based in New York City, she is also on the IRE Board.

session_title: SHOWCASE: Finding inspiration in the face of change
description: The journalism industry has faced a tremendous amount of challenges and changes. How does investigative journalism persevere — and grow?

speakers.bio: Keri Blakinger is an investigative reporter at the Houston Chronicle and author of the memoir Corrections in Ink. Last year, she was a Pulitzer finalist for her story about the Dungeons & Dragons players of Texas Death Row. This year, she produced an Oscar-nominated short documentary, “I Am Ready Warden.” She’s also worked at the NY Daily News, The Marshall Project and the LA Times and is a 2025 New America Fellow.

Len Downie is the former executive editor of The Washington Post, where he worked for 44 years as an investigative reporter, foreign correspondent and metro, national, and managing editor. The Post won a record 25 Pulitzer Prizes during his 17 years as executive editor. Since retiring from The Post, he has been a professor for 15 years at Arizona State's Walter Cronkite School of Journalism and Mass Communication.

David Fahrenthold is an investigative reporter in the New York Times' Washington bureau, writing about the world of nonprofits. He joined The Times in 2022, after 21 years at the Washington Post. He won the 2017 Pulitzer Prize for National Reporting for his reporting on President Trump's charitable giving -- or lack thereof.

session_title: Show & Tell: Political investigations
description:
Sign up to “Show & Tell” us about your best work and get constructive feedback from the moderator and audience. 

Sign-ups are required for presenters. Each presenter will have 15 minutes to share their work and receive feedback. All are welcome to attend!

Sign up here: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/10C084CA8AC29A4FBCE9-57104480-show

*These sessions will not be recorded.

session_title: Strategies for investigating offshore companies
description:
This hands-on session will show you how to use publicly available information to identify who owns and benefits from companies that are set up in jurisdictions with comprehensive corporate secrecy. In an era of increasing transnational corruption, being able to publicly expose who is behind a company and the deals in which they participate will be critical for accountability journalism. While having a leak or an inside source that exposes this information would be ideal, this is not something we can rely on and there are other approaches. This training will draw from years of experience piercing the veil around such secretive companies.

This session is good for all levels! Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

speakers.affiliation: Platform to Protect Whistleblowers in Africa
speakers.bio: John is an investigative journalist focused on corruption, corporate misconduct, money-laundering and leaks. He runs collaborative projects for the Platform to Protect Whistleblowers in Africa (PPLAAF). John also trains journalists and civil society on investigative techniques, including for French group OpenFacto. He also develops simulated follow-the-money investigations, which he has delivered in Angola, France, Nigeria and the United States.

Douglas Gillison covers financial regulation for Reuters in Washington and was previously senior Congo investigator at the anticorruption organization The Sentry. He was also an investigative reporter and editor from 2006 to 2011 for the former Cambodia Daily in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, where he covered human rights, national security, the environment and the Khmer Rouge trials.

session_title: Web scraping with R
description:
If you need data that's trapped on a website, writing some code to scrape the page could be your solution. This entry-level class will show you how to use the rvest package within the R programming language to harvest data from a website into a data file. We’ll cover the basic structure of HTML and tackle a few websites from easy to difficult.

This class is good for anyone who is comfortable writing some basic R code. Some understanding of HTML is helpful but not required. Attendees must bring their own laptops (no tablets) with R and RStudio installed, along with the packages "tidyverse" and "rvest."

speakers.bio: Liz Lucas is an associate professor and the Houston Harte Chair in Journalism at Mizzou, where she teaches classes in problem solving with data and AI. Previously she was the senior training director at IRE.

session_title: Audio track: Evolving narratives in audio storytelling about crime
description: Journalists hate the term "true crime." But true crime podcasts have captivated audiences, and the genre is evolving beyond its traditional confines. This panel explores how investigative journalists and storytellers are redefining true crime by focusing on systemic issues, deeper narratives and ethical storytelling. Panelists will share their experiences crafting compelling audio that goes beyond "whodunit," balancing audience engagement with sensitivity, accuracy and accountability. Attendees will gain insights into innovative reporting techniques, narrative structure and the ethical dilemmas of audio storytelling in this increasingly popular medium.

speakers.bio: Nicole Dungca is an investigative reporter at The Washington Post. She is the co-host of the podcast Broken Doors, which examined the use of no-knock warrants in the American justice system, and one of the authors of Searching for Maura, an illustrated investigation into the Smithsonian Institution's collection of human remains. She currently serves as the president of the Asian American Journalists Association.

Sukey Lewis is a criminal correspondent and host of On Our Watch, a podcast from KQED about the shadow world of law enforcement accountability. In 2018, she co-founded the California Reporting Project, a coalition of newsrooms across the state focused on obtaining previously sealed internal affairs records. Sukey has also investigated the bail bonds industry, California's wildfires and the high cost of jail phone calls.

Julieta Martinelli is an investigative reporter and senior producer leading narrative long form reporting on criminal justice and immigration at Futuro Media. She most recently reported and co-produced season 1 of "Suave," which was awarded the 2022 Pulitzer Prize in audio reporting and was the International Documentary Association's audio series of the year. She is the senior producer and host of season 2, which explores the complexities of re-entry.

Parker Yesko is a reporter for The New Yorker's Pulitzer Prize-winning podcast In the Dark. For Season 3 of the podcast, Parker examined why no U.S. Marines were punished for the 2005 killings of 25 civilians in Haditha, Iraq. She compiled the largest known database of alleged war crimes committed by American service members in Iraq and Afghanistan since 9/11. Parker's reporting for Season 2 helped to free a man, Curtis Flowers, from Mississippi's death row.

session_title: Broadcast track: Secrets for success: IRE Award winners show how to elevate your investigation

speakers.bio: Amy Davis is a duPont-Columbia and 2024 IRE Award-winning investigative journalist whose reporting has changed laws, exposed corruption, and put criminals behind bars. With four regional Emmys and honors from the Texas AP, her work hits where it hurts—and helps where it matters. Off-camera, she's raising three fearless truth-seekers of her own. Her mission: dig deep, speak loud, and never back down.

Melissa del Bosque is an award-winning investigative journalist, specializing in the U.S.-Mexico border region. She is the investigations editor for Lighthouse Reports and cofounder of The Border Chronicle. Her work has been published in The New Yorker, The Guardian, The Texas Observer, and numerous other media outlets.

A four-time IRE award winner, Jeremy Finley is the chief investigative reporter and evening anchor at WSMV-TV in Nashville, TN. An internationally published novelist, his books have been featured on NPR, People Magazine and the New York Post. As an advocate for writers, he the host of the literary public affairs show A WORD ON WORDS on Nashville Public Television. He lives in Nashville with his wife and daughters.

Jack Sapoch is an open source investigative journalist at Lighthouse Reports, where he works on cross-border investigations into migration, border enforcement, and state violence. He combines remote sensing, digital forensics, and 3D modeling to reconstruct incidents and expose hidden systems of control. His work has contributed to investigations which have been recognized with honors including the IRE Award, the Sigma Award, and the One World Media award.

Andrea Slaydon is a duPont Columbia award-winning TV producer with 20+ years of experience in investigative journalism and news production. Currently, Andrea is a Senior Investigative Producer/Special Projects Producer at KPRC (NBC Houston). She co-leads a team of nine investigative journalists and co-manages all promotable stories and projects for the news department. Andrea is a proud wife and mother of two.

session_title: Crowdsourcing data for your next investigation
description:
This panel will showcase three investigations built around crowdsourced data, with an emphasis on the tools that you can use for your next big story. 

We will share Bloomberg News' reporting on how Uber and Lyft “locked out” drivers from work in order to game the city’s minimum wage law. Bloomberg News built an automated WhatsApp tipline that circulated to drivers across New York City to crowdsource over 7,000 screenshots of lockouts from nearly 900 drivers. 

Reporters will discuss using social media videos to trawl for tips on immigrant raids and building intake forums to standardize tips from sources.

We will share tips on how to maximize participation from sources, validate messy user-submitted data, and how to combine shoe-leather reporting with the affordances of automation.
track: Tools & Tech, Data analysis, Beat reporting

speakers.bio: Cassandra Garibay is a Bay Area-based engagement reporter for ProPublica, working on community-sourced investigations. Cassandra has previously reported on housing and health equity issues across California for El Tímpano, Fresnoland, the Fresno Bee and the San Luis Obispo Tribune. She also previously served as the USC Center for Health California Engagement Editor.

Leon Yin is an investigative data journalist at Bloomberg News. He builds datasets and develops methodologies to report on technology. Before joining Bloomberg, he worked at The Markup and served as a research engineer at NYU.

session_title: Deep dive: Two friends on what they’ve learned along the way
description: Ginger Thompson and Ken Armstrong go way back. Both longtime investigative journalists, their resumes include Pulitzers, Peabodys, Polks. They worked together at ProPublica. And the Chicago Tribune. And, four decades ago, they worked together at their college newspaper, the Purdue Exponent. (Their staff was quite something. The cartoonist went on to co-write and co-direct Pixar’s “Up.”) They’ll talk craft, lessons learned, how to do stories that make a difference, how to grow and keep growing—and what they owe to their college paper.

speakers.bio: Ken Armstrong is an editor and reporter on Bloomberg’s global I-team. He’s won Pulitzers for investigative and explanatory reporting and shared in two staff Pulitzers for breaking news. Other awards include a Peabody for radio and the National Magazine Award for feature writing. He co-wrote the story that became the Netflix series, “Unbelievable.” He was the McGraw Professor of Writing at Princeton and co-authored the book “Scoreboard, Baby,” winner of the Edgar Award.

Ginger Thompson is a managing editor at ProPublica, with decades of experience as a reporter, including as a Latin America correspondent. Before joining ProPublica, Ginger worked at the New York Times, the Chicago Tribune, The Baltimore Sun and the Los Angeles Times. Her work has won numerous awards, including the Pulitzer Prize.

session_title: Finding stories in IRS filings
description:
In this training, journalists will learn how to find and read various IRS filings and how to identify potential stories within them. Attendees will be given concrete examples of stories that came through the analysis of IRS filings.

This session is good for all levels! Laptops will be provided.

speakers.bio: David Armiak is research director and an investigative journalist with the Center for Media and Democracy. David joined CMD in 2015, has conducted extensive investigations on dark money, corporate corruption, and right-wing networks, and is responsible for filing and analyzing hundreds of public records requests every year.

session_title: Finding the story: Transportation data
description:
This hands-on class will introduce you to key datasets and story ideas for investigating transportation. Learn about working with data on DUI crashes and pedestrian crashes, as well as DUI enforcement data from arrests and courts. 

This session is good for journalists with some experience using spreadsheets. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

session_title: How student journalists are leading real-world investigative reporting across the U.S.
description: This panel will showcase student-led investigative reporting with real-world impact, from holding some of the most powerful in the state accountable to uncovering new information about unsolved civil rights murders. Faculty and students involved in this work will talk about the do's and don'ts of relying on students to lead investigative work, as well as what they are actually able to accomplish.

speakers.bio: Lee Ann Anderson is a  rising senior attending the University of Florida majoring in journalism. She's been a reporter with Fresh Take Florida, WUFT News and The Alligator, and she also freelanced for Mainstreet Daily News. She has written about the ongoing court case about an impending social media ban in Florida and investigated Florida Democrats running candidates in district they lived hundreds of miles from.

Christopher Drew holds the Fred Jones Greer Jr. Endowed Chair at Louisiana State University's Manship School of Mass Communication. He also has been a reporter for The New York Times, the Chicago Tribune, The Wall Street Journal and The Times-Picayune. He co-wrote "Blind Man's Bluff," a bestselling book about submarine spying during the Cold War.

Sarah Gamard is a program manager for the Center for Community News, specializing in strengthening local news across the U.S. via university-led news partnerships. Before, she covered government and politics for several news outlets in Louisiana, Maryland, Delaware and D.C.

speakers.affiliation: University of Florida College of Journalism and Communications
speakers.bio: Rick Hirsch is director of the Collier Prize for State Government Accountability at the University of Florida, one of the largest awards in the U.S. A career reporter and editor, he served as managing editor of the Miami Herald from 2011 to 2021. During his tenure as ME, the Herald earned two Pulitzer Prizes and was named a finalist five times. He was part of five other Miami Herald Pulitzers as a reporter and editor.

session_title: How to background people in an hour
description: Whether covering a mass shooting or a political scandal, reporters need to know how to thoroughly and quickly background people and companies involved in breaking news events and long-term investigations. In this panel, journalists will share concrete tips on how to mine social media accounts, maximize Nexis searches, unearth public records, find friends and relatives and turn hunches into distinctive stories.
track: Reporting and writing strategies, Public records

speakers.bio: Michael Biesecker is a global investigative reporter for The Associated Press. Biesecker’s work tracking potential war crimes in Ukraine was recognized with the 2022 IRE Gold Medal, as well as the top award for investigative reporting from the Overseas Press Club of America. He was a contributor to the AP team that won the 2023 Pulitzer Prize for Public Service. Biesecker also teaches investigative and environmental reporting at Georgetown University.

Jennifer Gollan is an investigative reporter at the San Francisco Chronicle. Investigations she led have prompted new federal and state laws and national rules for police chases. An investigation she led into deadly police pursuits was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize in National Reporting in 2025. Among her other honors: an IRE Award, an Emmy Award, two Hillman Prizes, two Sigma Delta Chi Awards and the Robert F. Kennedy Journalism Award.

Yami Virgin, an Emmy and AP Award-winning Investigative Reporter and Anchor at KABB/WOAI in San Antonio, is recognized in Texas and Wisconsin. She hosts and produces the Edward R. Murrow Award-winning podcast, "Immigration Crisis: The Fight for the Southern Border." Known for endless sources at local, state, and national levels, Yami brings two decades covering immigration, crime, and border policy. She is finishing a Master's in Digital Audience Analytics.

session_title: Networking: Women
description: Mix and mingle, meet friends old and new, and build your professional community in this fun and informal networking session. This session is for people who identify as women. This session is sponsored by The Washington Post. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

speakers.bio: Marisa Kwiatkowski is the director of journalism at Knight Foundation. She previously spent 20 years as a reporter, handling investigations at USA TODAY and local outlets in Michigan, South Carolina, and Indiana. Her work has sparked multi-agency investigations, led to criminal charges, resulted in resignations, and prompted changes to state and federal laws.

session_title: Show & Tell: Consumer on your side
description:
Sign up to “Show & Tell” us about your best work and get constructive feedback from the moderator and audience. 

Sign-ups are required for presenters. Each presenter will have 15 minutes to share their work and receive feedback. All are welcome to attend!

Sign up here: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/10C084CA8AC29A4FBCE9-57104565-show

*These sessions will not be recorded.

speakers.bio: Caresse Jackman is an award-winning National Consumer Investigative Reporter at InvestigateTV-Gray Media. Before InvestigateTV, she was a consumer investigative reporter at WSMV in Nashville, Tennessee. She has prior reporting experience at WWL in New Orleans, WJRT in Flint, Michigan, and WCBI in Columbus, Mississippi.

Jason Knowles is well known for warning viewers about the latest rip- offs and scams. Since he began his work as the station's Consumer Investigative Reporter, he's exposed dozens of alleged con-artists on camera and recovered thousands of dollars for consumers who say they were wronged by large companies and local businesses. He's also uncovered potential Red-Light Camera Traps, Real Estate Scams and problems with toxic Lead Paint and Lead Water in our community.

session_title: Staying alive: Inside secrets on how to thrive through job moves, layoffs and newsroom drama
description: In this discussion and Q&A, Larry Graham will share some of his experiences placing journalists in some of the top newsrooms in the country and offer insights on topics like negotiating severance, navigating career pivots, making the most out of a job or promotion offer and even leveraging multiple offers for the best deal possible. Whether you've just been fired, laid off, or you’re interested in taking the next step in your career, these are answers you won’t hear anywhere else.

speakers.bio: Daphne Duret is a staff writer for The Marshall Project. She reports on policing issues across the country. She was previously on the investigations team at USA Today. Before that, she covered legal issues for The Palm Beach Post and has worked at the St. Louis Post Dispatch and The Miami Herald.

Founder of The Diversity Pledge Institute, Larry provides leadership coaching while working with organizations on long-term strategies for recruiting and maintaining underrepresented talent. Larry spent most of his career in sports, working in newsrooms like ESPN, The San Diego Union-Tribune and several others. After leaving the newsroom, Larry was the deputy director of local news transformation at the American Press Institute, training newsrooms in change management.

session_title: Visualizations for your investigation
description:
Visualizations are increasingly important in storytelling. Reporters and producers in the newsroom can benefit from learning basic chart-making concepts, enabling them to enhance their stories with clear and impactful data visuals when needed.

This session will introduce participants to using Datawrapper to create charts for individuals who want to develop clear, engaging, and impactful visualizations for their stories. This session will provide practical guidance on selecting the right chart types and customizing visual elements, making it ideal for journalists and storytellers looking to enhance their data presentations.

This session is good for beginners and all levels of experience. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

speakers.bio: Cam Rodriguez is a data and investigative reporter based in Chicago, and is currently a Local Investigations Fellow at The New York Times. She previously worked with teams at Chalkbeat, USA TODAY, South Side Weekly, the Detroit Free Press, WTTW and the Better Government Association. When she’s not digging in archives or making another pot of coffee, she’s usually playing with maps, watching rom-coms or exploring the Midwest with her dog.

session_title: Writing short: Narratives don't have to be long!
description: Well-crafted narratives help engage readers in investigative reports that convey complex information. Compelling narratives don't need to be 4,000 + words.  We explain what you need -- and don't need -- to tell a story in fewer words.

speakers.bio: Walt Bogdanich has been awarded three Pulitzer Prizes — two at The New York Times and one at The Wall Street Journal — and was a Pulitzer finalist twice. Before joining The Times in 2001, he produced reports for 60 Minutes and ABC News. He has also produced investigations for Frontline and New York Times television. Previously, Bogdanich worked at The Plain Dealer and Cleveland Press. He co-authored the book “When McKinsey Comes to Town.”

Jenifer McKim is the editor of investigations and podcasts at GBH News in Boston. She is a multimedia journalist who has worked in many newsrooms, including the OC Register, The Boston Globe, and the San Juan Star in Puerto Rico. She's the recipient of dozens of awards, including two national Edward R. Murrow Awards and a finalist nod for the Pulitzer Prize in Public Service.

speakers.affiliation: Ida B. Wells Society for Investigative Reporting

session_title: IRE Awards luncheon
description:
A highlight of the IRE conference, the IRE Awards luncheon begins at 12:30 p.m. in rooms Bissonet, Carondelet and Acadia.
