We will present the 2024 IRE Awards and salute some of the best investigative work of the past year. Admission to the luncheon is included in your conference registration. Conference name tags are required for entry.

The IRE Awards luncheon is co-sponsored by NBC News/NBCUniversal Local.

session_title: Audio track: Editing the investigative podcast
description: Experienced editors share their best tips on deciding when to pursue long-form audio stories, developing story arcs that grip listeners and guiding your team through creating a revelatory and impactful podcast.

speakers.bio: Kate Howard is an editorial director at the Center for Investigative Reporting, which produces Reveal and Mother Jones. Previously, she was managing editor at the Kentucky Center for Investigative Reporting, where her team was a Peabody Award finalist for the investigative podcast Dig. Howard was a local news reporter working in newspapers and radio for nearly 14 years. She is a board member for IRE and Louisville Public Media, and she's based in Louisville, Kentucky.

Brendan McCarthy is Spotlight Editor at the Boston Globe. He oversees the newsroom’s investigative work as well as its data team. He has led projects that have been awarded a Pulitzer Prize, Peabody Award, Columbia-Dupont Award, and IRE honors. He previously served as founding editor of the Kentucky Center for Investigative Reporting and worked as a reporter at The Times-Picayune in New Orleans.

Peniley Ramírez is an Emmy and IRE Award-winning investigative journalist. Co-CEO and Executive Director of Futuro Media. She writes a column for Reforma. She was a correspondent for Univision and authored a book on corruption and the drug war. Under her leadership, Futuro Media has received Murrow and Nonprofit News awards, and has been nominated for the Peabody, the Loeb, and two Emmys. She holds a Master’s in Business and Economics Journalism from Columbia University.

session_title: Automating your beat
description:
Have you ever encountered a document that's difficult to search or a collection of documents containing tables that you want to extract and analyze? Join this session to learn how you can extract data from handwritten reports and tables buried in PDFs, uncover patterns in extensive document sets using regular expressions and AI tools, convert emails into searchable PDFs, monitor local government websites for real-time changes and much more. 

This session is good for beginners and people interested in extracting data from documents. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

speakers.bio: Jill Castellano is a data reporter for The Marshall Project. Jill has worked for ABC-owned television stations, The Salt Lake Tribune, The Desert Sun, inewsource and USA TODAY, earning a Pulitzer Prize for explanatory reporting in 2018 for her work on the deaths of undocumented border crossers. Jill was editor-in-chief of the University of Pennsylvania student newspaper, The Daily Pennsylvanian.

session_title: Broadcast track: AI AI AI: Three fakes and a real

speakers.bio: Jamie Grey is the Director of Investigations for Gray Media's national investigative team, InvestigateTV, which produces video and digital investigative reports for the company's stations in 113 markets, as well as for a daily and weekend show. She loves dogs, football, and data - and data about dogs and football.

speakers.affiliation: Craig Newmark Graduate School of Journalism at CUNY
speakers.bio: Andy Lehren is editorial director for the Center for Collaborative Investigative Journalism and director of investigative reporting at CUNY’s Graduate School of Journalism. He is on the IRE Board of Directors. A former investigative reporter for The New York Times and NBC News, he has won over 100 journalism honors, including Polk, Peabody, Emmys, multiple IRE awards, contributed to a Pulitzer, and was part of a Pulitzer finalist team. Works extensively in data journalism, including for NICAR.

session_title: Covering economic development incentives: What it really means to give companies public dollars
description: When the Washington Post reported Elon Musk's companies have received at least $38 billion in economic development subsidies, grants, and loans, it provoked some uproar in light of Musk's allegations of government overspending. But Musk is just one of many CEOs who have benefited from large subsidy packages given in the name of economic development. In this session, learn how to find out what companies are getting incentives (with the help of Good Jobs First's Subsidy Tracker and other public financial documents), the impact to public budgets, how to make sense of "economic impact" reports, and how to dig into deals to be able to answer - are the deals, which involve turning over public money to private companies, worth it?

speakers.bio: Paula directs the business reporting for nonpartisan and nonprofit Bridge Michigan. Her coverage emphasizes accountability and policy, mostly focused on economic development incentive spending. Recent awards include first place for explanatory journalism from SABEW and the 2024 Public Service award from the Michigan Press Association. Paula also reported on a statewide environmental team at MLive.com, and has edited at the Ann Arbor News and the Detroit Free Press.

Arlene Martínez joined Good Jobs First, a nonprofit corporate and government watchdog, in 2020. Before joining GJF, (which maintains the Subsidy, Violation, and Tax Break Tracker databases), she was a reporter with the USA TODAY Network/Ventura County Star, The Morning Call, the LA Times and Hispanic Link News Service, where her work focused on the choices people in power make when it comes to who and what gets prioritized.

J. Dale Shoemaker is a journalist in Buffalo, New York, with the nonprofit news outlet Investigative Post, covering stories at the intersection of government and economics. Among other topics, he's investigated how local tax breaks rob rural schools of revenue and how subsidies often flow to companies that don't need the money. Most recently, he's exposed a highly-subsidized restaurateur for stealing from his employees.

session_title: Covering science in the political spotlight
description: In the fast-changing policy landscape of 2025, government officials have distanced scientific evidence from political decision-making and frequently ignored scientific consensus. Misleading claims about issues ranging from fluoridating water to vaccine safety to climate change impacts are drawing scientific evidence into the spotlight, and this controversy warrants deeper reporting to get to the gist of the evidence. Speakers will explore how they've investigated science at the center of political controversy, and give concrete advice on how to cut through political cross-talk with evidence, unearth the interests at play in these controversies, and portray complex evidence clearly for their audiences.

speakers.bio: Jen Christensen is a  Peabody-award-winning writer/producer with CNN.com/CNN's where she currently works with the medical unit. She also serves as the Vice President for Broadcast with NLGJA the Association of LGBTQ+ Journalists and is NLGJA's long-time national convention co-chair.

Elena is a writer and editor focused on science. At SciLine, she works with journalists to provide them with scientific information and expertise for their stories. She creates guides to scientific evidence that can deepen news stories and interviews scientists to produce video footage for reporters' use. Elena has covered the early months of COVID for NPR, written local stories for the Providence Journal, and reported biology features for Quanta Magazine.

Lisa Song is a reporter at ProPublica who covers how environmental regulations (or the lack thereof) affect communities, human health and the natural world. She's currently focused on the EPA and related agencies that oversee science and the environment.

Alison Young has reported on health, science, environment and consumer issues for USA Today, the Detroit Free Press, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution and others. Until May, when Houston Landing closed its newsroom, she was the nonprofit’s associate editor for investigations, a reporting and coaching role. She is the author of "Pandora’s Gamble: Lab Leaks, Pandemics, and a World at Risk," which was named to Kirkus Reviews’ Best Books of 2023. She is a past president of IRE.

session_title: Deep dive: Dealing with pushback
description: David Enrich’s new book, “Murder the Truth,” details how the powerful—billionaires, politicians, corporations—use litigation and threats to stifle reporting that could hold them accountable. Enrich will talk with Lauren Chooljian, to which a chapter of his book is devoted. Chooljian was subjected to vandalism and threats while investigating sexual misconduct; four men were ultimately convicted of criminal charges in connection with a campaign to silence her station’s work. They’ll discuss the intimidation tactics being used against journalists, and what reporters and editors (and their lawyers) can do when faced with them.

speakers.bio: Lauren Chooljian is a senior reporter/producer on NHPR's Document team, a narrative-driven, longform reporting project. She is the host and reporter behind The 13th Step, a podcast about sexual misconduct in the addiction treatment industry, which was a finalist for the 2024 Pulitzer Prize in audio reporting. Before joining NHPR in 2017, Lauren spent nearly six years as a reporter, producer and fill-in host for WBEZ in Chicago.

David Enrich is a deputy investigations editor at the New York Times. He is the bestselling author of four books, most recently "Murder the Truth: Fear, the First Amendment, and a Secret Campaign to Protect the Powerful."

session_title: Finding the story: Taking a deeper dive into the housing and homelessness crisis
description:
Finding an affordable home —and keeping it— is now a challenge for practically all Americans. With the right data, an individual anecdote can become a story that questions public policy and promotes solutions. In this session, we will explore several data sources that you can use in both daily coverage and long-term projects related to this housing and homelessness crisis, including federal databases, research projects, and local dashboards.

Basic knowledge of working with spreadsheets is helpful, but not required. Laptops will be provided.

speakers.bio: Juan Pablo Garnham is the Communication and Policy Engagement Manager for Eviction Lab, a housing research center based in Princeton University. Previously he worked with The Texas Tribune, El Diario in New York City, CityLab, Univision and several outlets in his home country of Chile. Among his areas of interest are housing, homelessness, immigration and urbanism. He lives in Portland, Oregon.

session_title: How to investigate digital threats
description: How to investigate digital threats (disinformation campaigns, online scams, harassment, and anonymous hate speech websites), and expose the bad actors behind them. In this panel, leading media manipulation journalists will share effective tips and easy-to-use tools to expose this sinister cyber world.

speakers.bio: Anna Massoglia is an independent investigative analyst. She serves as director of investigations at the Sunlight Research Center and as an advisor to multiple newsrooms, academic institutions and nonprofits. Anna previously led OpenSecrets’ editorial and investigations team. She holds degrees in political science and psychology from North Carolina State University and a J.D. from the University of the District of Columbia School of Law.

session_title: Investigating DOGE
description: Elon Musk has said that the Department of Government Efficiency, also known as DOGE, is a transparent cost-cutting government initiative, but its inner workings have largely been opaque. What is DOGE? Who is DOGE? These journalists have been working to uncover the actions of the federal initiative, as well as its impact, and will share tips on how national, local and beat reporters can cover DOGE.

speakers.bio: Sophie Alexander is a reporter for Bloomberg News, where she writes about the ultra-rich and how their wealth and power impact society. Her work has spanned a billionaire’s near-total control of a Hawaiian island home to 3,000 people, fraud, safety concerns, and sexual misconduct allegations at celebrity disaster relief nonprofits and a disgraced insurance tycoon’s attempt to have 50 children. She is based in New York.

Sophia Cai is a White House reporter at POLITICO and co-author of West Wing Playbook, a daily newsletter about Donald Trump’s unprecedented overhaul of the federal government. Before joining POLITICO, she covered Congress and the 2024 presidential campaign for Axios and the White House for Bloomberg News.

David Fahrenthold is an investigative reporter in the New York Times' Washington bureau, writing about the world of nonprofits. He joined The Times in 2022, after 21 years at the Washington Post. He won the 2017 Pulitzer Prize for National Reporting for his reporting on President Trump's charitable giving -- or lack thereof.

NPR Cybersecurity Correspondent Jenna McLaughlin has been reporting on the intersection of technology and national security for over a decade at publications including CNN, Foreign Policy Magazine, Mother Jones, and now NPR. Since the inauguration, McLaughlin has been investigating the activities of DOGE, particularly focused on the legal and security implications of their access to massive amounts of highly sensitive data about Americans.

Annie Waldman is an investigative reporter at ProPublica, specializing in health care. She joined ProPublica in 2014 and was a finalist for the Explanatory Reporting Pulitzer in 2025 for a series on how insurance companies deny mental health care. She is based in New Orleans.

session_title: Master class: Under pressure: Real life in real time with breaking news - pre-registered attendees only
description:
One of the hottest sessions at every IRE Conference! How would you and your newsroom fare in digging out little-known facts and information under the pressure of a breaking news deadline? One of the best ways to get better is to practice.

This is a real-life scenario where you can learn to break news without leaving your computer. The skills learned in this session can also be used for turning daily general assignment stories when there’s not breaking news. This session regularly fills up and the tipsheet that comes with it is in high demand. If you're interested, get there early to get a seat.

Preregistration is required and seating is limited.
track: Reporting and writing strategies, Beat reporting

speakers.bio: Stephen Stock is chief investigative reporter at WVUE Fox8 New Orleans and contributing correspondent for Gray’s InvestigateTV. Specializing in public corruption, safety and transportation, Stock was a founding member of CBS News and Stations Innovation Lab and helped build investigative teams in San Francisco, Miami and Orlando. He teaches at IRE, newsrooms and universities around the US. He’s won a Peabody, du-Pont, national SPJ, three Murrows, six AP awards and 18 Emmys.

session_title: Networking: Educators
description: Mix and mingle with peers from throughout the world to find solidarity, make new friends, and build your professional community in this fun and informal networking session. This session is for those who teach journalism. This session is sponsored by Scripps Howard Fund. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

speakers.affiliation: UC Berkeley Graduate School of Journalism
speakers.bio: Lisa Armstrong is a journalist currently covering mainly incarceration, with credits in The Guardian, The New Yorker, The Texas Tribune and other outlets. She produced a documentary for CBS News and has used her audio and documentary work to partner with musicians, poets and other artists for live performances that were featured at Carnegie Hall and SXSW. She is a professor at the UC Berkeley Journalism School and also teaches journalism in California prisons.

Mark Horvit is a professor at the University of Missouri School of Journalism, where he teaches investigative reporting, a reporting project capstone and other stuff. He is also chair of the Journalism Professions faculty. Horvit previously served as executive director of  IRE and NICAR, where he conducted training in investigative reporting and data journalism throughout the world. Horvit worked as a reporter and editor for 20 years in Texas, the Carolinas and Florida.

session_title: Open mic: Avoiding burnout: Focus on reporter mental health
description:
This is one of five “Open Mic” sessions where you can listen to AND participate in a lively discussion about important issues facing our industry and impacting our daily work. All are welcome to attend!
*These sessions will not be recorded.

session_title: Scraping documents with Python + Natural PDF
description:
Come kick the tires on Natural PDF, a new Python library by Jonathan Soma to extract the contents of PDFs using simple, straightforward code. Natural PDF is built on top of pdfplumber and offers powerful tools for analyzing and extracting data from even the worst PDFs.

This session is good for people with some Python experience. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

speakers.bio: Jonathan Soma is the Knight Chair in Data Journalism at Columbia Journalism School, where he directs both the Data Journalism Master of Science program and the summer intensive Lede Program. He regularly publishes tutorials on everything from basic Python and analysis to ai2html and machine learning. At the moment, he unfortunately cannot stop talking about AI, and in his free time, he runs a tiny cat rescue.

session_title: Scraping without coding using Google Sheets
description:
"Scraping" is a catch-all word for grabbing information off a web page and into your spreadsheet - whether the website wants you to or not. This session will introduce easy, hands-on methods for scraping data from a live webpage without having to learn any code. We will use the ImportHTML and ImportXML formulas in Google Sheets. Scraping beginners welcome!

This session is good for all levels! This session will be taught using Google Sheets, a laptop and Google account will be required to participate.

speakers.bio: Samantha Sunne is a freelance journalist based in New Orleans and the Interim Editor at MuckRock. She has received several national grants and awards for investigative reporting and teaches at conferences, universities, and newsrooms around the world. Her first book, co-authored with trainer Mike Reilley, “Data + Journalism: A Story-Driven Approach to Learning Data Reporting,” is used in journalism classrooms around the country.

session_title: What the Real Housewives can teach you about investigative journalism
description: What can we learn about investigative reporting from the Real Housewives franchise? Plenty. Preparing for accountability interviews, recognizing and dismantling bias in storytelling/narrative perspective — and how to bring the receipts. Get ready for the reunion!

speakers.bio: Cary Aspinwall is an investigative reporter for The Marshall Project. She previously reported for The Dallas Morning News and is a co-founder of The Frontier. Her work has been recognized with a Gerald Loeb Award, as a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize in local reporting, and the National Magazine Awards for public interest.

speakers.affiliation: Investigative Project on Race and Equity
speakers.bio: Marissa Evans is the investigations editor with the Investigative Project on Race and Equity. Previously a health reporter at the Los Angeles Times, she covered race, healthcare, and entertainment. While at the Star Tribune, where her investigative work exposed how the state allowed private hospitals to seize tax refunds from individuals with unpaid medical bills, leading to legislative action in 2021 aimed at ending the policy.

Arionne Nettles is a professor, culture reporter, and audio aficionado who serves as the Garth C. Reeves Eminent Scholar Chair and instructor for digital journalism at Florida A&M University. As a journalist, her stories often examine Chicago's history, culture, and racial and class disparities. She is the author of We Are the Culture: Black Chicago’s Influence on Everything and Journalism for Dummies.

session_title: Audio track: Carving out space for local audio investigations
description: When you’re a reporter in a small, local newsroom it can be hard to find time to work on investigative projects. On this panel, four local audio reporters with experience on investigative projects will talk about how they managed to carve out space and energy to chip away at investigations while juggling daily news and still being present in their newsrooms. This panel will be helpful for any local reporter – in audio, or not! -  who wants to make the jump into investigative journalism.
track: Beat reporting, Reporting and writing strategies, Audio/radio

speakers.bio: Alex Hall is an enterprise and accountability reporter for KQED, San Francisco's NPR station. She covers courts, criminal justice, and East Bay politics. Before KQED, Alex was an investigative reporting fellow at Wisconsin Public Radio and Wisconsin Watch. Her audio documentary about a series of deadly COVID-19 outbreaks at Foster Farms won a national Edward R. Murrow award and was named an IRE award finalist.

Anna King reports for Northwest Public Broadcasting. She covers the wide opens of Washington and Oregon. Her latest large-scale project is Not One Drop Of Blood. The documentary film digs into mysterious cattle mutilations in rural Oregon. She also created the popular podcast Ghost Herd. Anna’s earned: two Gracie awards, a Sigma Delta Chi Award in Breaking News, Washington State University’s Woman of the Year and this year she’s been nominated for a regional Emmy.

Paige Pfleger is the criminal justice reporter at WPLN news in Nashville, where she has investigated gun dispossession, domestic violence and juvenile justice as a fellow with ProPublica’s Local Reporting Network. Her work was a finalist for a Livingston Award and an Investigative Reporters and Editors Award, and she has appeared nationally on NPR, The Washington Post, Marketplace and more.

Camille Phillips is the education reporter for Texas Public Radio in San Antonio. Her work includes an investigation into reports that special education teachers often get hurt at work, Golden Pennies, which breaks down the reasons Texas school funding still isn’t fair, and The Enduring Gap, which explores the Latino college gap in San Antonio, what can be done to close it, and what the rest of the country can learn from it.

session_title: Broadcast track: Lightning Talks
description:
Come to this session to hear rapid-fire lecture from broadcast pros. Moderated by Charlie McLravy; talks will include:
1 Jailhouse Interviews
2 How to pitch your investigative story to your managers
3 Investigative Reporting Through the Black Lens
4 Tips for Negotiating your new contract 
5 How to win over your Promotions Team - and why it matters
6 Don't Miss the Moment
7  Don't forget to decompress! (focus on reporter mental health)

speakers.bio: Greg Fisher is a west coast producer for CBS News 48 Hours. Greg has been a network broadcast producer for more than 30 years, and a supervisor at 48 Hours. Greg spent 16 years as an investigative producer for ABC News 20/20 and PrimeTime. Greg has won the National Press Club Award, an Emmy Award for Investigative Reporting and Breaking News, a duPont-Columbia Award and others. He began his career as a radio and newspaper reporter.

After 12 years as a news director in Toledo and Grand Rapids, Rick Gevers in 1995 began a career as a talent agent for on-air TV news people. He also publishes a weekly newsletter on news manager comings and goings which is widely read.

Nate Morabito is an award-winning investigative reporter at WCNC-TV. Nate joined WCNC's team in his hometown of Charlotte, North Carolina, in July 2018 after spending 14 years with WJHL-TV in Johnson City, Tennessee. His investigations have led to changes in federal and state laws, public policy, and the outcome of criminal investigations and convictions. In 2017, he was named a finalist for an IRE Award.

Award-winning journalist Leslie Rangel is a first-gen daughter of Mexican and Guatemalan immigrants and the senior editor of investigations at The Barbed Wire. She’s Emmy-nominated, UN-recognized, and reports at the intersection of wellness, race, gender, and justice. A former TV anchor and 2023 Chauncey Bailey fellow, she co-authored Journalists Break News, Don’t Let It Break You and founded The News Yogi mental wellness coaching practice.

Katie Wilcox is the I-Team Executive Producer at 12News in Phoenix, where she leads her team to produce data-driven investigations that expose waste, fraud and abuse. Katie also worked as a data journalist in Denver at 9NEWS and Rocky Mountain PBS. Her work has prompted legislation and policy changes in Colorado and Arizona. Katie grew up in southwest Iowa and graduated from the University of Iowa with her bachelor’s degrees in economics and journalism.

session_title: Campus wars: Tools & techniques to investigate the battle over higher ed
description: Trump and his aides are withholding huge sums of money and barring international students from college campuses, aiming to shift the ideological tilt of higher education. Colleges are fighting back in court and in Congress. Documents, data and source work reveal what’s really going on in the trenches.

speakers.bio: Torsheta Jackson, the award-winning education and equity reporter for the Mississippi Free Press through Report for America, has 19 years of experience as an educator. She is dedicated to telling personal stories of systemic injustice in Mississippi’s education system, particularly in under-resourced and historically excluded communities. She also serves as program manager for the Mississippi Free Press Youth Media Project. Her work has appeared in YES! Magazine, Mississippi Scoreboard, Eater, Jackson Advocate, and more.

Vimal Patel is a higher education reporter for the New York Times. Before he joined the Times in 2021, he was a reporter for the Chronicle of Higher Education, in Washington DC, where he wrote about graduate education, social mobility, and free expression. He started his career at The Eagle, a daily in Bryan-College Station, covering Texas A&M University. He graduated from Colorado State University.

Jessica Priest covers higher education for the Texas Tribune in partnership with Open Campus. She joined in 2022 as an engagement reporter for the ProPublica/Texas Tribune unit, contributing to a Pulitzer Prize finalist series. Her previous work at outlets like USA Today, the Fort Worth Report and the Victoria Advocate focused on criminal justice, the environment, and local government. Her reporting has led to reforms and a new trial for a death row inmate.

Stephens is a Ferris Professor and Founding Director of Princeton’s Journalism Program. He was previously a long-time investigative reporter at The Washington Post. He’s a three-time winner of the George Polk Award and a three-time finalist for the Pulitzer Prize. Stephens has judged the IRE and many other contests, and twice served on Pulitzer Prize juries. A frequent public speaker, he is also an advisor and former Fund for Investigative Journalism board member.

session_title: Extracting data from PDFs with off-the-shelf tools
description:
Join this class to learn how to “liberate” trapped data locked inside of PDF’s. This class will cover basic approaches for getting text out of PDF documents using powerful and freely available tools. Participants will be introduced to basic concepts and walked through tackling common challenges encountered with tricky PDF documents.

This session is good for: People who are unfamiliar with PDF-to-text tools or would like to learn how these tools can be used for extracting difficult text from images embedded in a PDF document. Laptops will be provided.

speakers.bio: Maggie Mulvihill is a veteran reporter, data journalism trainer, news entrepreneur, First Amendment advocate, and attorney. An Associate Professor of the Practice in Computational Journalism at Boston University, Mulvihill’s students have won numerous regional and national awards, including this year's IRE top student honor for a collaboration with The Howard Center for Investigative Journalism at the University of Maryland.

session_title: Finding and using historical documents in investigative stories
description: Methods from the practices of archivists, librarians, and historians can help journalists surface and use historical documents. In this session, learn about incorporating history into deep-dive stories.
track: Public records, Reporting and writing strategies

speakers.bio: Alexia Fernández Campbell is an investigative reporter at Bloomberg Industry. Her work has exposed widespread wage theft at the USPS and potential business fraud in the federal Paycheck Protection Program. Her radio and magazine series“40 Acres and a Lie,” won a duPont-Columbia Award, a National Magazine Award and an IRE Phil Meyer Award. Alexia previously worked at The Center for Public Integrity, Vox, The Atlantic, National Journal, and the South Florida Sun-Sentinel.

Nadia is a reporter and producer for Reveal, from the Center for Investigative Reporting. She has worked on a wide range of investigative stories, including the Big Lie, immigration, the post-Roe healthcare crisis, gun violence, and more. Most notably, Nadia co-reported and produced the historical investigation Forty Acres and a Lie, exploring a reparation that wasn’t, and the wealth gap that remains. The project was a finalist for the 2025 Pulitzer Prize.

Cam Rodriguez is a data and investigative reporter based in Chicago, and is currently a Local Investigations Fellow at The New York Times. She previously worked with teams at Chalkbeat, USA TODAY, South Side Weekly, the Detroit Free Press, WTTW and the Better Government Association. When she’s not digging in archives or making another pot of coffee, she’s usually playing with maps, watching rom-coms or exploring the Midwest with her dog.

Mc Nelly Torres is an award-winning investigative journalist and former editor at the Center for Public Integrity where she led a team investigating inequality. Before, Torres worked as an investigative producer for NBC6 in Miami and co-founded FCIR.org. She is a product of newspapers including the Sun-Sentinel and the San Antonio Express-News. Torres was the first Latina elected to the IRE board of directors. In 2022, Torres was a recipient of the Gwen Ifill Award.

session_title: Finding the story: Court records
description:
In this interactive hands-on session, bring your laptop and practice with us as we show you new tools to help you analyze complex court records - especially on deadline. This hands-on session focuses primarily on two powerful analysis tools: Google Pinpoint and Draftable. We’ll also briefly discuss PACER and RECAP, bread-and-butter tools to help you locate court records across the country.  We’ll keep this session lively with fun challenges, so come hang out with us!  

This session is good for: everyone! No previous data experience is required. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.
track: Story ideas, Criminal legal system, Beat reporting

speakers.bio: Daniel Connolly is a senior reporter for Law360, the legal news service. He won a first-place SABEW award and was named a Loeb Award finalist for his investigation of a debt relief law firm. He previously wrote for The (Memphis) Commercial Appeal and USA Today and wrote a narrative nonfiction work called “The Book of Isaias” about children of immigrants. He served on IRE’s contest committee for the 2024-2025 season.

session_title: Finding the story: DOGE-cancelled contracts
International journalists, American press freedom and what's happening now
description: On this panel, two international journalists and two press freedom experts will discuss the rapidly increasing threats to independent journalism and how reporters can protect themselves physically, mentally, and digitally, as well as what journalists from the United States can learn from their international counterparts who have worked under repressive and chaotic regimes.

speakers.bio: Iram Abbasi is a multimedia journalist and current fellow at the Alfred Friendly Press Partners program at the Missouri School of Journalism. She has reported for the BBC World Service and Voice of America. In 2013, she received the BBC News Award for bilingual election coverage from Pakistan’s most restive province, reported under threats from extremists and military surveillance. Recently laid off from VOA, she continues to report on transnational repression.

speakers.affiliation: Inter-American Press Association / Latin American Network for Journalism in Exile
speakers.bio: Salvadoran journalist and editor specialized in economics and human rights. Has led the economic sections of the main newspapers in El Salvador. Currently working at the Inter-American Press Association, developing programs for journalists and media at risk in Latin America. Coordinator of the Latin American Network for Journalism in Exile. Living in the US since 2022.

Kathy Jones is the Committee to Protect Journalists' director of research & analysis. For more than two decades, she has helped shape and tell stories with data, reporting and visuals for news organizations including Reuters, Bloomberg, and Newsweek. She has produced groundbreaking data-driven stories on topics ranging from the financial crisis to film awards, and launched global content and polling programs. She holds a degree in journalism from the University of Florida.

Louise Kiernan is director of strategic initiatives and a professor at Northwestern University's Medill School of Journalism. She launched the first regional office of ProPublica and oversaw its expansion throughout the Midwest and worked in a range of roles at the Chicago Tribune, including enterprise editor and writing coach. Kiernan was lead writer on a project that won the Pulitzer Prize for explanatory reporting and has been a Pulitzer finalist.

speakers.affiliation: Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press

session_title: Policing by algorithm: Covering AI in law enforcement
description: AI is rapidly reshaping policing—sometimes in ways even police themselves don't fully understand. From AI-powered facial recognition leading to wrongful arrests to automated systems drafting police reports, these technologies raise urgent questions about accuracy, bias, and accountability. This panel brings together investigative journalists and researchers who have exposed the risks and real-world consequences of AI in policing. Panelists will offer a behind-the-scenes look at how their investigations came together, and insights/tips for journalists interested in doing this reporting in their own communities.

speakers.bio: Jamiles Lartey is a New Orleans-based staff writer for The Marshall Project and the primary author of the outlet's award-winning "Closing Argument" newsletter. Previously, he worked as a reporter for the Guardian covering issues of criminal justice, race, and policing. In 2016, He was named “Michael J. Feeney Emerging Journalist of the Year” by the National Association of Black Journalists.

Doug MacMillan is a business and tech investigations reporter at the Washington Post, writing stories that hold powerful companies accountable, examine questionable uses of emerging technologies and expose harmful business practices across a wide range of industries, from assisted living homes to immigrant detention centers. He lives in Washington, D.C.

Hannah Riley Fernandez is a writer, communications expert, and advocate based in Atlanta. She works at the Center for Just Journalism, supporting journalists and newsrooms who do reporting on public safety issues.

session_title: Regular expressions: Puzzling out clean data
description:
Regular expressions are a pattern-matching syntax used in spreadsheets and programming languages, providing a powerful skill to slice, dice and clean up dirty data. They may look intimidating, but they are really just puzzles. We'll learn the fundamentals of "regex" to save you time cleaning your next batch of data.
 
This session is good for: People who have ever done more than one search/replace actions to clean a data set, or had to split an address, or otherwise want to conquer their fears of regex. Bring your own laptop. We’ll just be using a browser for this hands-on lesson.

speakers.bio: Christian McDonald is an associate professor of practice and the innovation director in the School of Journalism and Media at the University of Texas at Austin, where he teaches classes on data, coding, and news products. His last newsroom position was as data and online projects editor at the Austin American-Statesman. In his 28 years in journalism, he also worked at the Atlanta Journal-Constitution, East Valley (Arizona) Tribune and the Longview (Texas) News-Journal.

session_title: Reporting on corporate-driven health crises
description: From ultra-processed foods and cigarettes to PFAS and air pollution: commercial products and processes are major contributors to disease, death and economic harm. We will share practical approaches to covering industry-driven health crises, with an emphasis on connecting those stories to real people in harm’s way. Topics to include: how industry shapes health narratives, reporting on emerging threats, humanizing climate coverage and – yes – how to approach health reporting in an era of MAHA and regulatory layoffs. You will not leave empty-handed: we will point you to sources, data, story ideas, and more!
track: Business, Beat reporting, Criminal legal system, Story ideas, Public records

speakers.bio: Ben Hallman is founder and executive director of The Examination, a global health investigative newsroom. He was previously a senior editor for the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists and deputy editor at The Trace.

Christina Jewett covers the F.D.A. at The New York Times. Before she came to The Times in 2021, she worked at several nonprofit news organizations: KFF Health News, Reveal from The Center for Investigative Reporting and ProPublica. She wrote stories that led to arrests, changes in state laws and the release of millions of records to the public. Her work has been recognized with a George Polk Award, James Batten Medal and Barlett and Steele gold award. She grew up in Indiana and lives in Maryland.

Sharon Lerner covers the EPA and environmental issues at ProPublica. She has written about threats posed by pesticides, plastic-based fuels and other chemicals and have reported extensively on PFAS, a family of industrial pollutants linked to cancer, infertility, developmental harm and immune dysfunction. She is based in New York.

session_title: Show & Tell: Spanish-language projects
description:
Sign up to “Show & Tell” us about your best work and get constructive feedback from the moderator and audience. 

Sign-ups are required for presenters. Each presenter will have 15 minutes to share their work and receive feedback. All are welcome to attend!

Sign up here: https://www.signupgenius.com/go/10C084CA8AC29A4FBCE9-57104646-show

*These sessions will not be recorded.

speakers.bio: Myriam Masihy is a bilingual Consumer investigative reporter for Telemundo 51 and NBC6 South Florida, who has helped viewers recover over $3 million. She has earned 22 Emmy Awards. She is also the producer of several documentaries, including Lessons from the Jungle (Secretos de la Selva) and Healing Through Food (Comida Como Cura), that stream across Telemundo and NBC platforms nationwide.

session_title: Telling the human story behind the investigation: Crafting a stand-alone narrative within a global reporting project
description:
In this conversation with 2025 Livingston Award winner for international reporting Nicole Sadek, we’ll explore how to craft a powerful stand-alone narrative that deepens and contextualizes the broader themes of a collaborative investigative series. 

When the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, the nonprofit that led the Panama Papers investigation, partnered with 26 media outlets to expose how Western oil companies bypassed laws and ethics to profit from the Kazakhstan-Russia pipeline, reporter Nicole Sadek was asked to continue her team’s research into Berezovka — a now-abandoned village in Kazakhstan ravaged by toxic exposure. She connected with former residents, environmental advocates, and officials from the World Bank and United Nations, and traveled to the village to illuminate the serious health issues suffered by its former residents and the underreported human costs of global industry.

This session is sponsored by the Wallace House Center for Journalists. IRE retains control of content, including the topic and speaker selection, for all conference sessions.

speakers.bio: Nicole Sadek is an investigative reporter at the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, a nonprofit collaborative newsroom known for the Panama Papers and the Pandora Papers. Nicole is the winner of the 2024 Livingston Award for International Reporting.

session_title: IRE membership meeting
description: IRE Executive Director Diana Fuentes and IRE Board President Brian Rosenthal will lead a membership meeting for all IRE members at 5:30 p.m. in Bissonet. Following the membership meeting, the results of the board of directors and contest committee elections will be announced.

session_title: AI 101: Coaching ChatGPT to help you with your coding and data tasks (repeat)
description:
ChatGPT, widely misunderstood and in some cases misused, can be a powerful tool to improve efficiency in our day-to-day work. Give ChatGPT a few rows of publicly available data and ask it to write a data dictionary. We'll use ChatGPT to help write a public records request for us, have it help us make sense of data and we'll even use it to write a Python script to reshape unruly Excel data. The best part? You don't need to know Python to write this code.

Some data experience is helpful for this session, but not required. Attendees will need to bring their own laptops (preferably no tablets) for the training.

speakers.bio: Charles Minshew is the senior editor for data journalism at The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, working primarily with the investigative team and helping journalists across the AJC tell stories with data. Charles is the former director of data services for IRE. In 2012, Charles was on the staff of The Denver Post that won a Pulitzer Prize for Breaking News for coverage of a shooting at a theater in Aurora, Colorado.

session_title: Google Sheets 1: Getting started with spreadsheets (repeat)
description:
In this introduction to spreadsheets, you'll begin analyzing data with Google Sheets, a simple but powerful tool. You'll learn how to enter data, navigate spreadsheets and conduct simple calculations like sum, average and median. 

This session is good for: Data beginners.

You must bring your own laptop (no tablets) to participate in this class, and you will need a free Google account to participate.

speakers.bio: Shadab Nazmi is a data visualization editor at Bloomberg News for the APAC region. He develops and edits data visualizations and guides data visualization reporters with graphics ideas for breaking news and rolling news coverage. He is based in Hong Kong.

session_title: International collaborations for global investigative impact
description: International investigations are made stronger by partnerships and collaborations that are able to drawn on strengths of different individuals and newsrooms. But these projects can also be fraught with challenges - who owns the investigative tools, who does the writing, whose editing works best? This panel will discuss how to make global investigations work for everyone by sharing examples of what has worked and what hasn’t, and highlighting best practices.

speakers.bio: Amruta Byatnal is the Asia Editor at Thomson Reuters Foundation’s Context newsroom. She leads all climate, inequality, tech, and LGBTQ+ coverage in the region, and also oversees the publication's newsletters. Amruta is currently based in London and has lived and reported from India and the United States.

Melissa del Bosque is an award-winning investigative journalist, specializing in the U.S.-Mexico border region. She is the investigations editor for Lighthouse Reports and cofounder of The Border Chronicle. Her work has been published in The New Yorker, The Guardian, The Texas Observer, and numerous other media outlets.

Reed Richardson is the managing editor at the Global Investigative Journalism Network. He is based in New York City, has worked in digital media for nearly 20 years, and has a Master’s degree in journalism from the Graduate School of Columbia University, New York.

session_title: Resilience by design: Mindset interventions for journalists
description: Investigative journalist and Stanford fellow Aaron Glantz and mindset coach Parul Somani present a groundbreaking approach to resilience, inspired by successful “cancer mindset” interventions. Learn how reframing adversity can help journalists adapt, build community, and thrive in tough times. Attendees will leave with practical self-reflection prompts and tools to strengthen their mental health so they leave IRE empowered to prevail in tough times ahead.

speakers.bio: Aaron Glantz is a two-time Peabody Award-winner, Pulitzer finalist, and fellow at Stanford University’s Center for the Advanced Study of Behavioral Sciences. Projects he’s led have sparked new laws that curtailed the opioid epidemic, improved care for U.S. military veterans, and kept the FBI’s international war crimes office open. His work has appeared in the New York Times, Los Angeles Times, NPR, NBC News, ABC News, Reveal, The Guardian, and the PBS Newshour.

Parul Somani is a business executive turned mindset coach empowering high-achievers to navigate change with clarity and confidence. With degrees from MIT and Harvard Business School, Parul served as Senior Manager at Bain & Company and in leadership roles at Silicon Valley start-ups for over 15 years. Following an aggressive cancer diagnosis, Parul discovered tools and actionable insights that apply to managing both personal and professional challenges. She is now a sought-after keynote speaker, trusted by Fortune 100 companies like Oracle and Bristol Myers Squibb, and leading organizations, including the World Economic Forum and American Cancer Society. Parul has guest lectured at Harvard Business School, been featured in Forbes, MIT Technology Review, and Stanford Health Care films on survivorship and mindset, and is the upcoming author of The Path of Least Regret. Learn more at parulsomani.com.

session_title: The art of fact-checking
description: Many newsrooms don’t spend resources on fact-checking, leaving reporters exposed to potential corrections, public embarrassment, or even litigation. Given the current political climate and the new administration’s aggressive stance toward watchdog journalism, it’s more important than ever to learn how to vet your own work and protect yourself. This session, featuring three longtime investigative researchers, will teach reporters how to approach their reporting with an eye toward fact-checking.

speakers.bio: Ethan Corey is the research and projects editor at The Appeal, where he also serves as interim managing editor.
Mariam Elba is a research reporter at ProPublica, where she works on locally-focused investigations, and national maternal health coverage. She is based in New York.
Nina Zweig is research editor at Type Investigations, where she also oversees the Inside/Out Journalism Project for incarcerated reporters.

session_title: Demystifying crime data: Learning the tools to effectively evaluate crime trends
description: Crime data can be challenging to acquire, analyze, and communicate even in the best of circumstances. In this session, Jeff Asher will discuss the major pitfalls and struggles to effectively incorporating crime data into understanding crime at the local, state, and national levels while accounting for the uncertainty of working with imperfect information. This session will also include discussion of the tools any journalist can use to better use crime data in their reporting.

session_title: Developing curriculum for the next generation of journalists
description: While we often hear that youth is wasted on the young, educators know that it's a two-way street in how we can learn from who we teach. We'll discuss what are our non-negotiables in journalism education and where perhaps we should reframe our thinking in order to prepare the next generation of journalists to do meaningful work with impact and cope with the tumult of the newsroom industry.

speakers.bio: Christopher Drew holds the Fred Jones Greer Jr. Endowed Chair at Louisiana State University's Manship School of Mass Communication. He also has been a reporter for The New York Times, the Chicago Tribune, The Wall Street Journal and The Times-Picayune. He co-wrote "Blind Man's Bluff," a bestselling book about submarine spying during the Cold War.

speakers.affiliation: UC Berkeley Graduate School of Journalism
speakers.bio: Jennifer LaFleur teaches data journalism at UC Berkeley’s Graduate School of Journalism. She was previously a senior editor at the Center for Public Integrity. She has also worked at American University, Reveal from the Center for Investigative Reporting, ProPublica and several newspapers. She is a former IRE training director and previously served on IRE’s board. She is a board member of the Fund for Investigative Journalism.

speakers.affiliation: Craig Newmark Graduate School of Journalism at CUNY
speakers.bio: Andy Lehren is editorial director for the Center for Collaborative Investigative Journalism and director of investigative reporting at CUNY’s Graduate School of Journalism. He is on the IRE Board of Directors. A former investigative reporter for The New York Times and NBC News, he has won over 100 journalism honors, including Polk, Peabody, Emmys, multiple IRE awards, contributed to a Pulitzer, and was part of a Pulitzer finalist team. Works extensively in data journalism, including for NICAR.

session_title: Everything you want to know about tracking political influence and money in politics
description: For anyone looking to dive into the world of money in politics, this session is for you! Whether it's corporate influence campaigns, dark money, foreign lobbying or anything in between, we've tracked it. The three panelists are OpenSecrets alumni with at least 30 years of collective experience working with money-in-politics data, documents and other information crucial to reporting on how special interest groups influence policy and shape laws and regulations at the state and federal level. We'll walk through the basics for where to find information and leave plenty of time for questions afterward.

speakers.bio: Soorin Kim in an investigative data reporter at ABC News covering the second Trump presidency. She specializes in following money in politics -- how political contributions, lobbying and other influence operations move those in power. During the 2024 election, she covered President Donald Trump's reelection campaign as a campaign embed reporter.

speakers.affiliation: Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW)
speakers.bio: Robert is the VP for research and data at Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW), where he leads efforts to investigate dark money, corruption and other malfeasance. Prior to joining CREW, he founded the dark money tracking program at OpenSecrets, where he won SPJ’s Sigma Delta Chi award for his reporting. He has collaborated with major outlets nationwide like NPR, Washington Post and CNN on reporting focused on dark money and conflicts of interest.

Anna Massoglia is an independent investigative analyst. She serves as director of investigations at the Sunlight Research Center and as an advisor to multiple newsrooms, academic institutions and nonprofits. Anna previously led OpenSecrets’ editorial and investigations team. She holds degrees in political science and psychology from North Carolina State University and a J.D. from the University of the District of Columbia School of Law.

session_title: Google Sheets 2: Formulas & sorting (repeat)
description:
Much of Google Sheets' power comes in the form of formulas. In this class, you'll learn how to use them to analyze data with the eye of a journalist. Yes, math will be involved, but it's totally worth it! This class will show you how calculations like change, percent change, rates and ratios can beef up your reporting.

This session is good for: Anyone who has taken Google Sheets 1 or has been introduced to spreadsheets.

You must bring your own laptop (no tablets) to participate in this class, and you will need a free Google account to participate.

speakers.bio: Jordan Elder is an Investigative Data Journalist for News 4 and Fox San Antonio. Her specialty is taking numbers from drab to fab—creating engaging stories using maps, graphics, and interactive tools. Her work helps both TV viewers and online readers better understand critical issues affecting their communities.

session_title: Google Sheets 3: Filtering & pivot tables (repeat)
description:
A look at the awesome power of pivot — and how to use it to analyze your dataset in minutes rather than hours. We'll work up to using a pivot table by first sorting and filtering a dataset, learning how to find story ideas along the way.

This session is good for: Anyone familiar with formulas, sorting and filtering in a spreadsheet program.

You must bring your own laptop (no tablets) to participate in this class, and you will need a free Google account to participate.

session_title: Organizing your investigation
description: Whether you use Post-Its, a white board, a spreadsheet or an old-fashioned yellow pad, keeping your head above a flood of information is crucial to your investigation’s success. This session will tap examples for techniques to navigate the key phases of organizing your story in any medium: managing material; pruning and pivoting; and visualizing the story.
track: Tools & Tech, Reporting and writing strategies

speakers.bio: Daniela Ibarra is an award-winning investigative reporter at KSAT in her hometown, San Antonio, Texas. Before returning home, she worked at KTXS and then KTUL in Oklahoma, where her reporting was credited with changing state law. She served on the national boards of the Society of Professional Journalists and the National Association of Hispanic Journalists. Daniela graduated from the University of North Texas. Ibarra is one of IRE's 2025 Chauncey Bailey Journalist of Color Investigative Reporting Fellows.

Katey Rusch is an investigative journalist at UC Berkeley’s Investigative Reporting Program. With Casey Smith, she won the 2024 Goldsmith Prize and was a Pulitzer finalist for uncovering how California police hid officer misconduct. Her work has driven statewide reforms and earned a George Polk Award. She previously worked in local TV news and holds degrees from UC Berkeley and Northwestern University’s Medill School of Journalism.

session_title: The lasting effects of extreme weather
description: Whether it’s flooding, rising seas or drought, wildfire or uncertain drinking water supplies, each city and state is experiencing the effects of climate change in its own way. But where do you find climate data and narratives, and what’s the best way to tell your city’s climate story? This panel will bring together some of the best reporters and communicators on the climate/weather beat to discuss how they use data, science and lived experience of their sources on the ground as the foundation for reporting that reveals the science behind climate impacts and the people affected.

speakers.bio: Keely Arthur is a Murrow and Emmy-winning investigative reporter for WRAL, where she leads the "Call Keely” 5 On Your Side franchise. She’s recovered $1.3 million by exposing corporate and government failures and resolving consumer complaints. Named Investigative Reporter of the Carolinas for two consecutive years, her reporting has sparked meaningful legislative and policy changes. Keely is deeply committed to protecting everyday people and holding the powerful accountable.

Justin Garcia is an investigative reporter at the Tampa Bay Times. His work has led to the resignation of a police chief, an executive director of the Florida Republican Party and has spurred internal investigations at several law enforcement agencies. He's also reported about hurricanes, extreme weather and storm infrastructure for several years.

speakers.affiliation: The Times-Picayune | The New Orleans Advocate
speakers.bio: Sam Karlin is an investigative reporter for The Times-Picayune | The New Orleans Advocate, where he covers climate adaptation and infrastructure. He has covered hurricanes, terror attacks and other natural disasters for the Times-Picayune and Reuters. He previously covered politics and the oil and gas industry.

Gordon Russell is deputy editor of The Boston Globe's Spotlight Team. Before moving to Boston in 2024, he served as managing editor of investigations for The Times-Picayune and The Advocate, where he worked for 25 years.
